embarrassment.eng_def: the feeling of being embarrassed, or something that makes you feel embarrassed
embarrassment.chi_def: 尷尬，窘迫；侷促不安；令人尷尬的事

embassy.eng_def: the group of people who represent their country in a foreign country
embassy.chi_def: 大使館全體人員，使館館員
embassy.eg: We used to be friendly with some people who worked at the Swedish Embassy.

embassy.eng_def: the building that these people work in
embassy.eg: The Ambassador held a reception at the embassy.

embrace.eg: This was an opportunity that he would embrace.

embrace.eng_def: to hold someone tightly with both arms to express love, liking, or sympathy, or when greeting or leaving someone
embrace.eg: She saw them embrace on the station platform.

embrace.eng_def: to include something, often as one of a number of things
embrace.eg: Linguistics embraces a diverse range of subjects such as phonetics and stylistics.

embrace.eng_def: the act of holding someone tightly with both arms to express love, liking, or sympathy, or when greeting or leaving someone
embrace.eg: She greeted me with a warm embrace.

emerge.eng_def: to appear by coming out of something or out from behind something
emerge.eg: She emerged from the sea, blue with cold.

emerge.eng_def: to come to the end of a difficult period or experience
emerge.chi_def: （從困境中）擺脫出來，存活下來
emerge.eg: The Prince emerged unscathed from the scandal.

emerge.eng_def: to become known, especially as a result of examining something or asking questions about it
emerge.chi_def: （尤指經過審查或訊問後）為人知曉，顯露，暴露
emerge.eg: The facts behind the scandal are sure to emerge eventually.

emergency.eng_def: something dangerous or serious, such as an accident, that happens suddenly or unexpectedly and needs fast action in order to avoid harmful results
emergency.chi_def: 緊急情況；不測事件；突發事件
emergency.eg: How would disabled people escape in an emergency?

emigrate.eng_def: to leave a country permanently and go to live in another one
emigrate.eg: Millions of Germans emigrated from Europe to America in the 19th century.

emotion.eng_def: a strong feeling such as love or anger, or strong feelings in general
emotion.eg: Like a lot of men, he finds it hard to express his emotions.

emperor.eng_def: a male ruler of an empire

emphasis.eng_def: the particular importance or attention that is given to something
emphasis.eg: I think we should put as much emphasis on preventing disease as we do on curing it.

emphasis.eng_def: the extra force that is given to a word or part of a word when it is spoken
emphasis.eg: The emphasis is on the final syllable.

emphasize.eng_def: to show that something is very important or worth giving attention to
emphasize.eg: I'd just like to emphasize how important it is for people to learn foreign languages.
Tight jeans will only emphasize any extra weight that you are carrying.

emphatic.eng_def: done or said in a strong way and without any doubt
emphatic.eg: Poland reached the final of the championship yesterday with an emphatic 5–0 victory over Italy.

empire.eng_def: a group of countries ruled by a single person, government, or country
a very large and important business or organization
empire.eg: In the space of just ten years, her company has grown from one small retail outlet to a multi-million-dollar empire.

employ.eng_def: to have someone work or do a job for you and pay them for it
employ.eg: How many people does your company employ?
Sophisticated statistical analysis was employed to obtain these results.
He was busily employed in lacing up his shoes.

employee.eng_def: someone who is paid to work for someone else
employee.eg: The number of employees in the company has trebled over the past decade.

employer.eng_def: a person or organization that employs people
employer.eg: We need a reference from your former employer.

employment.eng_def: the fact of someone being paid to work for a company or organization
employment.eg: Employment levels are unlikely to rise significantly before the end of next year.
Are you in employment at the moment?
How can you justify the employment of capital punishment?

empty.eng_def: not containing any things or people
not sincere or without any real meaning
empty.chi_def: 無誠意的；空洞的；無意義的
空虛的；無目標的，無意義的；百無聊賴的
empty.eg: He says his life has been completely empty since his wife died.

empty.eng_def: to remove everything from inside something
empty.eg: I emptied the closet and put my belongings into the black overnight case.
The place emptied pretty quickly when the fight started.

empty.eng_def: an empty bottle or other container, especially one that contained drink
empty.eg: Don't forget to recycle the empties.

enable.eng_def: to make someone able to do something, or to make something possible
enable.eg: Computerization should enable us to cut production costs by half.

enact.eng_def: to put something into action, especially to make something law
enact.chi_def: 實行，實施；（尤指）制定（法律）
enact.eg: A package of economic sanctions is to be enacted against the country.

enact.eng_def: to perform a story or play
enact.eg: The stories are enacted using music, dance and mime.

enactment.eng_def: an occasion on which people re-enact an event
enactment.eg: a re-enactment of the battle of Gettysburg

enclose.eg: The park that encloses the monument has recently been enlarged.

enclose.eng_def: to send something in the same envelope or parcel as something else
enclose.chi_def: 隨信（或包裹）附上；附入，封入
enclose.eg: Please enclose a curriculum vitae with your application.

enclosure.eng_def: an area surrounded by fences or walls
enclosure.chi_def: 圍起來的區域；圍場；圍地

enclosure.eng_def: the act of putting fences around land
enclosure.eg: An early example of privatization was the enclosure of public land for use by wealthy landlords.

enclosure.eng_def: something that is put in the same envelope or parcel as something else

encounter.eng_def: a meeting, especially one that happens by chance
encounter.chi_def: 偶然相遇，邂逅，不期而遇
encounter.eg: I had an alarming encounter with a wild pig.

encounter.eng_def: an occasion when people have sex, usually with someone they have not met before
encounter.chi_def: （對象通常爲陌生人的）性經歷

encounter.eng_def: an occasion when two teams play against each other
encounter.eg: In their last encounter with Italy, England won 3–2.

encounter.chi_def: 邂逅，不期而遇，偶然碰到
encounter.eg: On their way home they encountered a woman selling flowers.

encounter.eng_def: to experience something, especially something unpleasant
encounter.chi_def: 遭遇，遇到（尤指不愉快的事情）
encounter.eg: When did you first encounter these difficulties?

encourage.eng_def: to make someone more likely to do something, or to make something more likely to happen
encourage.eg: We were encouraged to learn foreign languages at school.

encourage.eng_def: to talk or behave in a way that gives someone confidence to do something
encourage.eg: They've always encouraged me in everything I've wanted to do.

encouragement.eng_def: words or behaviour that give someone confidence to do something
encouragement.eg: Children need lots of encouragement from their parents.

encouragement.eng_def: words or behaviour that make something more likely to happen
encouragement.eg: We give positive encouragement to applications from older candidates.

encyclopedia.eng_def: a book or set of books containing many articles arranged in alphabetical order that deal either with the whole of human knowledge or with a particular part of it, or a similar set of articles on the internet
encyclopedia.chi_def: 百科全書；（某一學科的）專科全書，大全

end.eng_def: the part of a place or thing that is furthest away from the centre
end.eg: This cable should have a plug at one end and a socket at the other.

end.eng_def: the final part of something such as a period of time, activity, or story
end.eg: I always like to leave my desk clear at the end of the day.
We were all by her bedside when the end finally came.

end.eng_def: either of the two halves of the field in some sports
end.eg: The teams change ends at half-time so that neither side has an unfair advantage.

end.eng_def: one of the two players in American football who begin play furthest from the ball

end.eg: Having agreed upon the matter of payment, he brought the interview to an end.

end.eng_def: finally, after something has been thought about or discussed a lot
end.eg: We were thinking about going to Switzerland, but in the end we went to Austria.

end.eng_def: for hours, days, etc. without stopping
end.eg: He used to lock himself in his bedroom for hours on end and refuse to talk to anyone.
Everyone wishes the war would come to an end soon.

end.eng_def: a small part of something that is left after most of it has been used
end.eg: She makes quilts out of fabric bolt ends.
Do you have a particular end in mind?

end.eng_def: in order to achieve this aim
end.eg: He wanted science students to take an interest in the arts, and to this end he ran literature classes at his home on Sunday afternoons.

end.eng_def: the parts of a task or process connected with one particular type of activity or person
end.chi_def: （和某類活動或人相關的）部分，方面
end.eg: Rick's more involved with the financial end of things.

end.eng_def: the area of activity for which someone is responsible
end.chi_def: （某人）份內的事情；（某人的）職責範圍：
end.eg: We've kept our end of the deal - let's see if they keep theirs.

end.eng_def: to finish or stop, or to make something finish or stop
end.eg: When is your meeting due to end?

endanger.eng_def: to put someone or something at risk or in danger of being harmed, damaged, or destroyed
endanger.eg: He would never do anything to endanger the lives of his children.

endeavor.eg: Engineers are endeavouring to locate the source of the problem.
In spite of our best endeavours, it has proven impossible to contact her.

ending.eng_def: the last part of a story
ending.eg: People want love stories with happy endings.

ending.eng_def: a part added to the end of a word
ending.eg: To make the plural of "dog", you add the plural ending -s.

endurance.eng_def: the ability to keep doing something difficult, unpleasant, or painful for a long time
endurance.eg: Running a marathon is a test of human endurance.

endure.eng_def: to suffer something difficult, unpleasant, or painful
endure.eg: We had to endure a nine-hour delay at the airport.

endure.eng_def: to continue to exist for a long time
endure.eg: The political system established in 1400 endured until about 1650.

enemy.eng_def: a person who hates or opposes another person and tries to harm them or stop them from doing something
enemy.eg: He's made a few enemies in this company.

enemy.eng_def: a country, or the armed forces of a country, that is at war with another country
enemy.eg: The enemy had succeeded in stopping our supplies from getting through.
Familiarity is the enemy of desire.

energetic.eng_def: having or involving a lot of energy
energetic.chi_def: 精力充沛的；充滿活力的

energy.eng_def: the power and ability to be physically and mentally active
energy.eg: Since I started eating more healthily I've got so much more energy.

energy.eng_def: the total of all your power and ability to be mentally and physically active
energy.eg: I'm going to channel all my energies into getting a better job.

energy.eng_def: the power from something such as electricity or oil that can do work, such as providing light and heat
energy.eg: The energy generated by the windmill drives all the drainage pumps.

enforce.eng_def: to make people obey a law, or to make a particular situation happen or be accepted
enforce.chi_def: 使服從（法律）；（強制）實行，執行，把…強加於
enforce.eg: It isn't always easy for the police to enforce speed limits.

enforcement.eng_def: the activity of making certain that the laws of an area are obeyed

engage.eg: I have engaged a secretary to deal with all my paperwork.

engage.eng_def: to interest someone in something and keep them thinking about it
engage.eg: The debate about food safety has engaged the whole nation.

engage.eng_def: to make one part of a machine fit into and move together with another part of a machine
engage.eg: When the large gear wheel engages (with the smaller one), the mill stone will start to go round.

engage.eng_def: to attack or begin to fight someone
engage.eg: Enemy planes engaged the troops as they advanced into the mountains.

engage.eng_def: to teach someone, especially a class of children, or to keep someone busy
especially of a writer, musician, artist, etc. interested in and taking part in politics
engage.chi_def: （尤指作家、音樂家、藝術家等）積極介入政治的

engagement.eg: They announced their engagement at the party on Saturday.

engagement.eng_def: an arrangement to meet someone or do something at a particular time
the act of beginning to fight someone, or a period of time in a war

engine.eng_def: a machine that uses the energy from liquid fuel or steam to produce movement
the part of a railway train that pulls it along
something that provides power, often economic power, for other things
engine.chi_def: 動力，推動力（常指經濟動力）
engine.eg: For much of the 19th century Britain was the workshop of the world and the engine of economic growth.

engineer.eng_def: a person whose job is to design or build machines, engines, or electrical equipment, or things such as roads, railways, or bridges, using scientific principles
engineer.chi_def: 工程師；工程（或機械）設計人員

engineer.eng_def: a person whose job is to repair or control machines, engines, or electrical equipment
engineer.chi_def: 機修工；技師；技工；機械師

engineer.eng_def: to arrange cleverly and often secretly for something to happen, especially something that is to your advantage
engineer.chi_def: （尤指爲自己的利益）密謀策劃，精心安排
engineer.eg: Left-wing groups engineered a coup against the military government.

engineer.eng_def: to design and build something using scientific principles

engineering.eng_def: the work of an engineer, or the study of this work

enhance.eng_def: to improve the quality, amount, or strength of something
enhance.eg: These scandals will not enhance the organization's reputation.

enjoy.eng_def: to get pleasure from the situation that you are in
enjoy.chi_def: 過得愉快；感到快樂；玩得痛快
enjoy.eg: I don't think Marie is enjoying herself very much at school.

enjoy.eng_def: something you say to someone when you have given that person something and you want them to enjoy it
to have something good or lucky
enjoy.eg: Even though he's 86, he enjoys excellent health.

enjoyable.eng_def: An enjoyable event or experience gives you pleasure.
enjoyable.chi_def: 使人快樂的；令人愉快的；有樂趣的

enjoyment.eg: Knowing the ending already didn't spoil my enjoyment of the movie.

enlarge.eng_def: to become bigger or to make something bigger
enlarge.eg: They've enlarged the kitchen by building over part of the garden.

enlarge.eng_def: to print a bigger copy of a photograph or document

enlargement.eg: I am pleased to announce the enlargement of the History Department by three new teachers.

enlargement.eng_def: something, especially a photograph, that has been enlarged
enlargement.chi_def: 擴大物，放大物；（尤指）放大照片
enlargement.eg: I had an enlargement of my graduation photo done for my grandparents.

enlighten.eng_def: to provide someone with information and understanding, or to explain the true facts about something to someone
enlighten.eg: Should the function of children's television be to entertain or to enlighten?

enlightenment.eg: Can you give me any enlightenment on what happened?

enlightenment.eng_def: in Hinduism and Buddhism, the highest spiritual state that can be achieved
enlightenment.chi_def: （印度教和佛教中的）般若，智慧，覺悟

enlightenment.eng_def: the period in the 18th century in Europe when many people began to emphasize the importance of science and reason, rather than religion and tradition
enlightenment.chi_def: （18世紀歐洲推崇科學和理性、質疑宗教和傳統的）啓蒙運動

enough.eng_def: as much as is necessary; in the amount or to the degree needed
enough.eg: Is there enough dessert/Are there enough desserts for everyone?

enough.eng_def: as much as or more than is wanted
enough.eg: I've got enough work to do at the moment, without being given any more.

enough.eng_def: something you say when you want something to stop
enough.eg: Enough is enough - I don't want to argue with you any more.

enough.eng_def: something you say to tell someone that you understand what they have said and that there is no need to say any more
enough.eg: "Someone has to explain the situation to her." "Enough said."

enough.eng_def: to want something to stop because it is annoying you
enough.chi_def: 受夠了；煩透了；再也無法忍受了
enough.eg: I've had enough - I'm going home.

enough.eng_def: used to tell someone to stop behaving badly
enough.chi_def: 不要那樣，夠了（用於制止不好的行爲）
enough.eg: That's enough, Peter. Give those toys back, please.

enough.eng_def: used after an adjective, adverb, or verb to mean to the necessary degree
enough.chi_def: （用於形容詞、副詞或動詞後）足夠地
enough.eg: Is the water hot enough yet?

enough.eng_def: used after an adjective or adverb to mean quite
enough.chi_def: 很，十分（用於形容詞、副詞後）
enough.eg: He's bad enough, but his brother is far worse.

enrich.eng_def: to improve the quality of something by adding something else
enrich.eg: Fertilizer helps to enrich the soil.

enrich.eng_def: to make something or someone richer
enrich.eg: He claimed that the large stores were enriching themselves at the expense of their customers.

enroll.eng_def: to put yourself or someone else onto the official list of members of a course, college, or group
enroll.eg: Is it too late to enrol at the college?

enrollment.eng_def: a system that allows students to go to a college without having any special qualifications for it
enrollment.chi_def: （不限制入學資格的）開放招生制

ensure.eng_def: to make something certain to happen
ensure.eg: The airline is taking steps to ensure safety on its aircraft.

enter.eng_def: to come or go into a particular place
enter.eg: The police entered (the building) through/by the side door.

enter.eng_def: to be included in a competition, race, or exam, or to arrange for someone else to do this
enter.chi_def: （爲…）報名參加（競賽、考試等）；安排…參加
enter.eg: Both men have been entered for/in the 100 metres in Paris next month.

enter.eng_def: to put information into a computer, book, or document
enter.eg: You have to enter a password to access the database.

enter.eng_def: to make a particular type of statement officially
enter.eg: The prisoner entered a plea of not guilty.

enter.eng_def: to become a member of a particular organization, or to start working in a particular type of job
enter.chi_def: 成爲…的一員，加入；開始從事
enter.eg: Ms Doughty entered politics/Parliament after a career in banking.

enter.eng_def: to begin a period of time
enter.eg: The project is entering its final stages.

enter.eng_def: the key on a computer keyboard that is used to say that the words or numbers on the screen are correct, or to say that an instruction should be performed, or to move down a line on the screen
enter.eg: Move the cursor to where it says "New File" and press enter.

enterprise.eng_def: an organization, especially a business, or a difficult and important plan, especially one that will earn money
enterprise.chi_def: 組織；（尤指）公司，企業；（尤指營利性的、艱巨而重大的）計劃，事業
enterprise.eg: Don't forget this is a commercial enterprise - we're here to make money.

enterprise.eng_def: eagerness to do something new and clever, despite any risks
enterprise.chi_def: 事業心；進取心；創業精神；冒險精神
enterprise.eg: They've shown a lot of enterprise in setting up this project.

entertain.eng_def: to keep a group of people interested or enjoying themselves
entertain.eg: We hired a magician to entertain the children.

entertain.eng_def: to invite someone to your home and give food and drink to them
entertain.eg: We entertain a lot of people, mainly business associates of my wife's.

entertain.eng_def: to hold something in your mind or to be willing to consider or accept something
entertain.eg: The General refused to entertain the possibility of defeat.

entertainment.eng_def: shows, films, television, or other performances or activities that entertain people, or a performance of this type
entertainment.chi_def: 娛樂，娛樂節目；娛樂表演
entertainment.eg: There's not much in the way of entertainment in this town - just the cinema and a couple of pubs.

enthusiasm.eng_def: a feeling of energetic interest in a particular subject or activity and an eagerness to be involved in it
enthusiasm.chi_def: 巨大興趣；熱情；熱忱；熱心
enthusiasm.eg: One of the good things about teaching young children is their enthusiasm.

enthusiasm.eng_def: a subject or activity that interests you very much
enthusiasm.chi_def: 激發熱情的事物；熱衷的活動；熱愛的事物
enthusiasm.eg: One of his greatest enthusiasms was yoga.

enthusiastic.eg: You don't seem very enthusiastic about the party - don't you want to go tonight?

entire.eng_def: whole or complete, with nothing missing
entire.chi_def: 全部的；整個的；完全的；完整的
entire.eg: Between them they ate an entire cake.

entitle.eng_def: to give someone the right to do or have something
entitle.eg: Being unemployed entitles you to free medical treatment.

entitle.eng_def: to give a title to a book, film, etc.
entitle.eg: Her latest novel, entitled "The Forgotten Sex", is out this week.

entrance.eng_def: a door, gate, etc. by which you can enter a building or place
entrance.eg: There are two entrances - one at the front and one around the back.

entrance.eng_def: the act of coming onto a stage, by an actor or dancer
entrance.eg: He makes a spectacular entrance in act two draped in a gold sheet.

entrance.eng_def: the act of a person coming into a room in an ordinary situation, although often because there is something noticeable about it
entrance.eg: I noticed her entrance because she slipped and fell in the doorway.

entrance.eng_def: the right to enter a place
entrance.eg: The management reserve the right to refuse entrance.

entrance.eng_def: Someone or something that entrances you is so beautiful or interesting that you cannot stop listening to or watching him, her, or it.
entrance.eg: He has entranced millions of people with his beautifully illustrated books.

entry.eng_def: the act of entering a place or joining a particular society or organization
entry.eg: A flock of sheep blocked our entry to the farm.

entry.eng_def: a door, gate, etc. by which you enter a place
entry.eg: I'll wait for you at the entry to the park.

entry.eng_def: a separate piece of information that is recorded in a book, computer, etc.
entry.eg: They've updated a lot of the entries in the most recent edition of the encyclopedia.

entry.eng_def: a piece of work that you do in order to take part in a competition, or the act of taking part in a competition
entry.eg: There have been a fantastic number of entries for this year's poetry competition.

envelope.eng_def: a flat, usually square or rectangular, paper container for a letter

envious.eng_def: wishing you had what another person has
envious.eg: I'm very envious of your new coat - it's beautiful.

environment.eng_def: the air, water, and land in or on which people, animals, and plants live
environment.eg: Certain chemicals have been banned because of their damaging effect on the environment.

environment.eng_def: the conditions that you live or work in and the way that they influence how you feel or how effectively you can work
environment.eg: The office is quite bright and airy - it's a pleasant working environment.

environmental.chi_def: 自然環境的；有關環境的
environmental.eg: People are becoming far more aware of environmental issues.

envy.eng_def: to wish that you had something that another person has
envy.eg: I envy her ability to talk to people she's never met before.

envy.eng_def: the feeling that you wish you had something that someone else has
envy.eg: I watched with envy as she set off for the airport.

envy.eng_def: to be liked and wanted by a lot of people
envy.chi_def: 是令…羡慕（或嫉妒）的對象
envy.eg: Her hair is the envy of the office.

epidemic.eng_def: the appearance of a particular disease in a large number of people at the same time
a particular problem that seriously affects many people at the same time
happening a lot and affecting many people
epidemic.eg: Poverty in this country has reached epidemic proportions .

episode.eng_def: a single event or group of related events
episode.chi_def: 事件；（相關的）一連串事件；一段經歷
episode.eg: This latest episode in the fraud scandal has shocked a lot of people.

episode.eng_def: one of the single parts into which a story is divided, especially when it is broadcast on the television or radio
episode.chi_def: （尤指電視或廣播節目的）一集，一節，片斷

equal.eng_def: the same in amount, number, or size
equal.eg: One litre is equal to 1.76 imperial pints.

equal.eng_def: the same in importance and deserving the same treatment
equal.eg: All people are equal, deserving the same rights as each other.

equal.eng_def: skilled or brave enough for a difficult duty or piece of work
equal.chi_def: （能力、勇氣）勝任的，合適的，相當的
equal.eg: It's a challenging job but I'm sure you'll prove equal to it.

equal.eng_def: someone or something that has the same importance as someone or something else and deserves the same treatment
equal.chi_def: （應獲得同等待遇的）同等重要的人或物
equal.eg: The good thing about her as a boss is that she treats us all as equals.

equal.eng_def: to be the same in value or amount as something else
equal.chi_def: 與某物（質量或數量）相等

equal.eng_def: to achieve the same standard or level as someone else, or the same standard or level as you did before
equal.chi_def: 達到（他人或自己過去的）相同標準或水準
equal.eg: We raised over $500 for charity last year and we're hoping to equal that this year.
He disputed the idea that more money equals better education.

equality.eng_def: the right of different groups of people to have a similar social position and receive the same treatment
equality.chi_def: （社會地位、待遇上的）平等；均等

equate.eng_def: to consider one thing to be the same as or equal to another thing
equate.chi_def: 同等看待；使等同；使相等
equate.eg: He complained that there was a tendency to equate right-wing politics with self-interest.

equation.eng_def: a mathematical statement in which you show that two amounts are equal using mathematical symbols
a statement containing chemical symbols, used to show the changes that happen during a particular chemical reaction
a difficult problem that can only be understood if all the different influences are considered
equation.eg: Managing the economy is a complex equation of controlling inflation and reducing unemployment.

equation.eng_def: the act of considering one thing to be the same as or equal to another
equation.eg: There is a tendency in movies to make the equation between violence and excitement.

equip.eng_def: to provide a person or a place with objects that are necessary for a particular purpose
equip.eg: It's going to cost $4 million to equip the hospital.

equip.eng_def: to give someone the skills needed to do a particular thing
equip.chi_def: 使有準備；使有能力；訓練
equip.eg: The goal of the course is to equip people with the skills necessary for a job in this technological age.

equipment.eng_def: the set of necessary tools, clothing, etc. for a particular purpose
the act of equipping a person or place

equivalent.eng_def: having the same amount, value, purpose, qualities, etc.
equivalent.eg: She's doing the equivalent job in the new company but for more money.

equivalent.eng_def: something that has the same amount, value, purpose, qualities, etc. as something else
equivalent.eg: There is no English equivalent for "bon appetit" so we have adopted the French expression.

era.eng_def: a period of time of which particular events or stages of development are typical

erase.eng_def: to remove something, especially a pencil mark by rubbing it
erase.chi_def: 抹去，擦掉（尤指鉛筆字跡）
erase.eg: It's in pencil so you can just erase anything that's wrong.

erase.eng_def: to remove recordings or information from a magnetic tape or disk
erase.chi_def: 抹去（磁帶內容）；刪除（磁片裡的文件）
erase.eg: A virus erased my hard disk.

erase.eng_def: to cause a feeling, memory, or period of time to be completely forgotten
erase.chi_def: （從頭腦中）清除，消除；忘卻（感覺、記憶等）
erase.eg: He is determined to erase the memory of a disappointing debut two years ago.

erase.eng_def: to remove or destroy something, especially something that shows that that person or thing ever existed or happened
erase.eg: The president said NATO expansion would finally erase the boundary line in Europe artificially created by the Cold War.
the nuclear erasure of entire populations

eraser.eng_def: a small piece of rubber used to remove the marks made by a pencil
eraser.eg: If you draw or write in pencil you can always rub out your mistakes with an eraser.

erect.eng_def: to build a building, wall, or other structure
erect.eg: The war memorial was erected in 1950.

erect.eng_def: to raise something to a vertical position
erect.eg: They erected a marquee to accommodate 500 wedding guests.

erect.eng_def: standing with your back and neck very straight
erect.eg: He's very tall and erect for his 78 years.

erect.eng_def: When a part of the body, especially soft tissue, is erect, it is harder and bigger than usual, often pointing out or up.

erode.eng_def: to rub or be rubbed away gradually
erode.eg: Wind and rain have eroded the statues into shapeless lumps of stone.

erode.eng_def: to slowly reduce or destroy something
erode.eg: His behaviour over the last few months has eroded my confidence in his judgment.

errand.eng_def: a short journey either to take a message or to take or collect something
errand.eg: I'll meet you at six, I've got some errands to do/run first.

error.eg: He admitted that he'd made an error.
Not telling the staff before they read the news in the papers was an error of judgment.

error.eng_def: to understand that you were wrong to behave in a particular way and start to behave differently
error.chi_def: 知錯能改；意識到自己的做法錯誤而開始改正

erupt.eng_def: When a volcano erupts, it explodes and flames and rocks come out of it.
erupt.eg: Since the volcano last erupted, many houses have been built in a dangerous position on its slopes.
At the end of a hot summer, violence erupted in the inner cities.

erupt.eng_def: to suddenly express your feelings in a noisy way
erupt.chi_def: 爆發（感情）；激烈地表達（感情）
erupt.eg: The crowd erupted in applause and cheering.

erupt.eng_def: If spots erupt on your skin, they suddenly appear.
erupt.eg: Two days after he'd been exposed to the substance, a painful rash erupted on his neck.

escalate.eng_def: to become or make something become greater or more serious
escalate.chi_def: （使）增強；（使）擴大；（使）加劇；（使）惡化
escalate.eg: His financial problems escalated after he became unemployed.

escalator.eng_def: a set of stairs moved up or down by electric power on which people can stand and be taken from one level of a building to another, especially in shops, railway stations, and airports
escalator.eg: I'll meet you by the up/down escalator on the second floor.

escape.eng_def: to get free from something, or to avoid something
escape.chi_def: 逃走，逃脫，逃離；逃避，避開

escape.eng_def: to press the key on a computer keyboard that allows you to leave a particular screen and return to the previous one or to interrupt a process
escape.chi_def: 退出，結束（電腦運行程式）
escape.eg: Escape from this window and return to the main menu.

escape.eng_def: the act of successfully getting out of a place or a dangerous or bad situation
escape.eg: He made his escape on the back of a motorcycle.

escape.eng_def: a loss that happens by accident
something that helps you to forget about your usual life or problems
escape.chi_def: （對現實的）逃避，迴避；解脫之物：
escape.eg: Romantic novels provide an escape from reality.

escape.eng_def: the key on a computer keyboard that allows you to leave a particular screen and return to the previous one or to interrupt a process
escape.eg: Press Esc to return to the main menu.

escort.eng_def: to go with a person or vehicle, especially to make certain that he, she, or it leaves or arrives safely
escort.chi_def: （尤指爲了確保某人安全到達或離開某地）護衛，護送，押送
escort.eg: Several little boats escorted the sailing ship into the harbour.

escort.eng_def: to go with someone and show them a place
escort.eg: People on the tour will be escorted by an expert on archaeology.

escort.eng_def: to go to a social event with someone, especially a person of the opposite sex
escort.chi_def: 陪伴（尤指異性）參加社交活動
escort.eg: Who will be escorting her to the ball?

escort.eng_def: a person who goes with another person as a partner to a social event
escort.chi_def: （通常指異性的）社交聚會陪伴者
escort.eg: "But I can't go to the dance without an escort," she protested.

escort.eng_def: someone who is paid to go out to social events with another person, and sometimes to have sex
escort.chi_def: 受僱陪同某人外出社交的人（常指年輕女子）
escort.eg: He hired an escort to go to the dinner with him.

escort.eng_def: a person or vehicle that goes somewhere with someone to protect or guard them
escort.eg: The members of the jury left the court with a police escort.

escort.eng_def: the state of having someone with you who gives you protection or guards you
escort.eg: The prisoners were transported under military escort.

especially.eng_def: very much; more than usual or more than other people or things
especially.eg: She's not especially interested in sport.
I chose this especially for your new house.

essay.eng_def: a short piece of writing on a particular subject, especially one done by students as part of the work for a course
essay.chi_def: （尤指學生寫的作爲課程作業的）短文；論說文；小品文，散文
essay.eg: For homework I want you to write an essay on endangered species.
The procedure was first essayed in 1923.

essence.eng_def: the basic or most important idea or quality of something
essence.eg: The essence of his argument was that education should continue throughout life.

essence.eng_def: relating to the most important characteristics or ideas of something
essence.eg: In essence, both sides agree on the issue.

essence.eng_def: to be the most important thing
essence.eg: In any of these discussions, of course, honesty is of the essence.

essence.eng_def: a strong liquid, usually from a plant or flower, that is used to add a flavour or smell to something
essence.chi_def: （通常取自植物或花的）香精，香料，精油

essential.eg: Government support will be essential if the project is to succeed.

essential.eng_def: a basic thing that you cannot live without
essential.chi_def: 必需品；不可缺少的東西
essential.eg: Because I live in a remote village, I regard my car as an essential.

establish.eng_def: to start a company or organization that will continue for a long time
to start having a relationship with, or communicating with another person, company, country, or organization
establish.chi_def: 與…建立關係；與…開始往來
establish.eg: There is a strong need to establish effective communication links between staff, parents, pupils, and external bodies.

establish.eng_def: to cause something or someone to be accepted in or familiar with a place, position, etc.
establish.eg: His reputation for carelessness was established long before the latest problems arose.

establish.eng_def: to be in a successful position over a long period of time
establish.eg: He has established himself as the leading candidate in the election.

establish.eng_def: to discover or get proof of something
establish.eg: Before we take any action we must establish the facts/truth.

establishment.eng_def: a business or other organization, or the place where an organization operates
the important and powerful people who control a country or an organization, especially those who support the existing situation
establishment.chi_def: （尤指支持維持現狀的）當權派，統治集團，權勢集團
establishment.eg: Critics said judges were on the side of the establishment.

establishment.eng_def: the process of starting or creating something, for example, an organization
establishment.eg: Since its establishment in 1945, the United Nations has played a dominant role in the development of international law.

estate.eng_def: a large area of land in the country that is owned by a family or an organization and is often used for growing crops or raising animals
estate.chi_def: （位於鄉村的）大片私有土地，莊園，種植園
estate.eg: It's a typical country estate with a large house for the owner, farm buildings, and estate workers' houses.

estate.eng_def: everything that a person owns when they die
estate.chi_def: （個人死後留下的全部）財産，遺産
estate.eg: She left her entire estate to her niece.

estate.eng_def: a group of houses or factories built in a planned way
estate.chi_def: （按規劃建造的）住宅區，工業區

estate.eng_def: a car with a lot of space behind the back seat and an extra door at the back for putting in large objects

esteem.eng_def: respect for or a good opinion of someone
esteem.eg: There has been a drop in public esteem for teachers.

esteem.eng_def: to respect someone or have a good opinion of them
esteem.eg: Her work is highly esteemed by all her colleagues.

estimate.eng_def: to guess or calculate the cost, size, value, etc. of something
estimate.eg: Government sources estimate a long-term 50 percent increase in rail fares.

estimate.eng_def: a guess of what the size, value, amount, cost, etc. of something might be
estimate.eg: The number of people who applied for the course was 120 compared with an initial estimate of between 50 and 100.

eternal.eng_def: lasting forever or for a very long time
eternal.eg: The company is engaged in the eternal search for a product that will lead the market.

eternity.eng_def: time that never ends or that has no limits
eternity.eg: They haven't been given these rights for (all) eternity - they should justify having them just like most other people have to.
The movie went on for what seemed like an eternity.

ethic.eng_def: a system of accepted beliefs that control behaviour, especially such a system based on morals
ethic.chi_def: 行爲準則，倫理；（尤指）道德體系，道德規範

ethic.eng_def: the study of what is morally right and what is not

ethical.eng_def: relating to beliefs about what is morally right and wrong

ethnic.eng_def: relating to a particular race of people
ethnic.eg: A question on ethnic origin was included in the census.

ethnic.eng_def: from a different race, or interesting because characteristic of an ethnic group that is very different from those that are common in western culture
ethnic.chi_def: 異族的；具有民族特色的；異國風味的

ethnic.eng_def: a person belonging to an ethnic group

evacuate.eng_def: to move people from a dangerous place to somewhere safe
evacuate.chi_def: （把人從危險的地方）撤離，撤出，疏散，轉移
evacuate.eg: The police evacuated the village shortly before the explosion.

evaluate.eng_def: to judge or calculate the quality, importance, amount, or value of something
evaluate.eg: It's impossible to evaluate these results without knowing more about the research methods employed.

evaluation.eng_def: the process of comparing a job with other jobs in an organization and deciding how much the person who is doing the job should be paid

eve.eng_def: the period or day before an important event
eve.eg: Mrs Clayton was speaking to Arab journalists in Paris on the eve of her visit to Egypt.

eve.eng_def: the first woman, according to the biblical story of how the world was made
eve.chi_def: 夏娃（《聖經》中描述的世界上第一個女性）

even.eng_def: used to show that something is surprising, unusual, unexpected, or extreme
even.chi_def: （用來表示令人驚訝、不同尋常、出乎意料或極端的事物）甚至，連，即使
even.eg: I don't even know where it is.
I tried to reason with him, but even as I started to explain what had happened he stood up to leave.

even.eng_def: used to say that if something is the case or not, the result is the same
even.eg: Even if you take a taxi, you'll still miss your train.

even.chi_def: 儘管這樣／那樣；雖然情況如此／是那樣
even.eg: I've thought about it so much, but even now I can't believe how lucky I was to survive the accident.

even.eng_def: despite what has just been said
even.eg: I had a terrible headache, but even so I went to the concert.
Even though he left school at 16, he still managed to become prime minister.

even.chi_def: （用於強調比較）甚至更，愈加，還
even.eg: The next 36 hours will be even colder with snow showers becoming more widespread.

even.eng_def: used when you want to be more exact or detailed about something you have just said
even.chi_def: （用於引出更準確或更詳細的說法）甚至可以說，更確切地說，其實
even.eg: I find some of his habits somewhat unpleasant, disgusting even.

even.eng_def: flat and smooth, or on the same level
even.chi_def: 平坦的，平滑的；處於同一平面的
even.eg: We resurfaced the floor because it wasn't even.

even.chi_def: 平穩的；均勻的；變化不大的
even.eg: You should try to work at an even rate instead of taking it easy one day and working flat out the next.
Both sides played well - it was a very even contest.

even.eng_def: equally likely to happen as to not happen
even.chi_def: （發生與不發生的）機會相等的；（正反的）可能性參半的
even.eg: The chances of her getting the job are about evens.

even.eng_def: used to refer to a situation in which you risk money on something where the risk is equally balanced, and will pay back twice the amount of money that is paid if it is successful
forming a whole number that can be divided exactly by two
even.eg: 6 is an even number and 7 is an odd number.
Sheila was awarded a scholarship in chemistry, and now her brother has evened the score with a scholarship in economics.

evening.eng_def: the part of the day between the end of the afternoon and night
a friendly way of greeting someone when you meet them in the evening
evening.eg: Evening, Tom! Where are you off to this evening?

event.eng_def: anything that happens, especially something important or unusual
event.chi_def: （尤指重大或不尋常的）事情，事件
event.eg: This year's Olympic Games will be the biggest ever sporting event.

event.eng_def: one of a set of races or competitions
event.eg: The women's 200 metre event will be followed by the men's 100 metres.

event.eng_def: used to emphasize that what happened was not what you expected
event.chi_def: （強調出乎意料）結果，到頭來（卻）
event.eg: We had expected to arrive an hour late, but in the event we were early.
In the event of a strike, the army will take over responsibility for firefighting.
I might go home next month, but in any event, I'll be home for Christmas.

event.chi_def: （在兩種情況下）無論哪種情況，無論怎樣
event.eg: I can't decide whether to accept the New York or the Chicago job, but in either event I'll have to move.

event.chi_def: 如果是那樣的話，如果那種情況發生
event.eg: There's a possibility of my flight being delayed. In that event I'll phone to let you know.

eventual.eng_def: happening or existing at a later time or at the end, especially after a lot of effort, problems, etc.
eventual.chi_def: 最終的，最後的（尤指在付出很大努力或出現很多問題後形成的最終結果）
eventual.eg: The Dukes were the eventual winners of the competition.

ever.eg: Nothing ever happens here in the evening.

ever.eng_def: better, bigger, etc. than at any time before
ever.chi_def: 比以前任何時候都好／大／多（等等）
ever.eg: We are spending more than ever on education.

ever.eng_def: as big, fast, etc. as at any time before
ever.chi_def: 像往常一樣大／快／好（等等）
ever.eg: The restaurants are as good as ever and no more expensive.
United's record in cup competitions grows ever more impressive.
He's been depressed ever since he got divorced.

ever.eng_def: in the same way as always
ever.eg: As ever, I was the last to find out.

ever.eng_def: used at the end of a letter as a way of saying goodbye to someone you know well
ever.chi_def: （熟人之間通信時用於書信末尾署名前的套語）你永遠的朋友

ever.eg: The orchestra is to perform its last ever concert/last concert ever tomorrow night at the Albert Hall.

ever.eng_def: in questions, used to emphasize the question word
ever.chi_def: （用於疑問句中強調疑問詞）究竟，到底
ever.eg: How ever did he manage that?

evergreen.eng_def: An evergreen plant, bush, or tree has leaves for the whole year.
always seeming fresh or remaining popular
evergreen.chi_def: 永葆青春的；不衰的；持久的

evergreen.eng_def: a plant, bush, or tree that has leaves for the whole year

every.eng_def: used when referring to all the members of a group of three or more
every.chi_def: （三個或三個以上的人或事物組成的群體中的）每一個，每個；全部，整體
every.eg: The police want to interview every employee about the theft.
Opponents of the war are considered every bit as patriotic as supporters.
We catch the majority of people, but hunting down every last tax evader is impossible.
The game was hindered by a fierce wind that swept the ball every which way.

every.chi_def: 無論從哪方面看；在各方面
every.eg: This movie is in every way a masterpiece of cinematography.

every.eng_def: all the things that you need or want
every.eg: There'll be an assistant there to see to your every need.

every.eng_def: used to show that something is repeated regularly
every.chi_def: （表示有規律地重複發生）每，每隔，每…之中
every.eg: Computers can perform millions of calculations every second.
Every now and again/then they'll have a beer together.
Every so often I treat myself to a meal in an expensive restaurant.

every.eng_def: the greatest possible or that can be imagined
every.chi_def: 最好的；最大的；最有可能的
every.eg: I'd like to wish you every success in your new job/happiness in your new home.

evidence.eng_def: one or more reasons for believing that something is or is not true
evidence.eg: The police have found no evidence of a terrorist link with the murder.
His desire to win an Olympic medal is evidenced by his performances throughout this season.

evident.chi_def: 顯然易見的；明白的，明顯的
evident.eg: The full extent of the damage only became evident the following morning.

evil.eng_def: morally bad, cruel, or very unpleasant
evil.chi_def: 道德敗壞的；邪惡的，惡毒的；討厭的

evil.eng_def: If the weather or a smell is evil, it is very unpleasant.
evil.chi_def: 天氣或氣味討厭的；令人不舒服的；令人作嘔的

evil.eng_def: something that is very bad and harmful
evil.chi_def: 邪惡（之事）；罪惡（行為）；禍害；災禍
evil.eg: Each new leader would blame his predecessor for all the evils of the past.

evolution.eng_def: the way in which living things change and develop over millions of years
a gradual process of change and development

evolve.eng_def: to develop gradually, or to cause something or someone to develop gradually
evolve.chi_def: （使）逐步發展；（使）逐步演變；（使）逐漸形成；（使）進化

exact.eng_def: in great detail, or complete, correct, or true in every way
to demand and get something, sometimes using force or threats

exact.eg: Heart surgery exacts tremendous skill and concentration.

exaggerate.eng_def: to make something seem larger, more important, better, or worse than it really is
exaggerate.eg: The threat of attack has been greatly exaggerated.

exaggeration.eng_def: the fact of making something seem larger, more important, better, or worse than it really is
exaggeration.eg: Sal estimates over 60 people were there but I think that's a slight exaggeration.

exam.eng_def: a test of a student's knowledge or skill in a particular subject
exam.eg: American students ranked fourth in those taking the geography exam.

examination.eng_def: the act of looking at or considering something carefully in order to discover something

examine.eng_def: to look at or consider a person or thing carefully and in detail in order to discover something about them.
examine.eg: Forensic scientists are examining the wreckage for clues about the cause of the explosion.

examine.eng_def: to test someone's knowledge or skill in a particular subject
examine.eg: We were examined on European history.

examinee.eng_def: someone who is taking an examination
examinee.eg: Before the real test, the examinee is given a simple practice exercise.

examiner.eng_def: someone whose job is to decide how well someone has done in an examination
examiner.eg: The candidates listed below have failed to satisfy the examiners.

example.eng_def: something that is typical of the group of things that it is a member of
example.eg: Could you give me an example of the improvements you have mentioned?

example.eng_def: a way of helping someone to understand something by showing them how it is used
example.eg: Study the examples first of all, then attempt the exercises on the next page.

example.eng_def: used when giving an example of the type of thing you mean
example.eg: Offices can easily become more environmentally-friendly by, for example, using recycled paper.

example.eng_def: a person or a way of behaving that is considered suitable to be copied
example.eg: He's a very good example to the rest of the class.

example.eng_def: a punishment that is intended to warn others against doing the thing that is being punished, or a person who receives such a punishment
example.eg: The judge made an example of him and gave him the maximum possible sentence.

exceed.eng_def: to be greater than a number or amount, or to go past an allowed limit
exceed.chi_def: 超過，超出（數量）；超越（規定的範圍）
exceed.eg: The final cost should not exceed $5,000.

excel.eng_def: to be extremely good at something
excel.eg: Rebecca always excelled in languages at school.

excel.eng_def: to do something better than you usually do
excel.chi_def: 比平常做得好；超水準的發揮
excel.eg: The British team have excelled themselves this year to reach the finals.

excellence.eg: The school is noted for its academic excellence.

excellent.chi_def: 卓越的；優秀的；傑出的；極好的

except.eg: The museum is open daily except Monday(s).

excepting.eg: All the people who were on the aircraft have now been identified, excepting one.

exception.eng_def: someone or something that is not included in a rule, group, or list or that does not behave in the expected way
exception.eg: Men are usually quite good at map-reading but Tim is the exception.

exception.eng_def: to not treat someone or something according to the usual rules
exception.eg: We don't usually accept late applications, but in this case we will make an exception.

exception.eng_def: to be offended or made angry by something or someone
exception.chi_def: 因…而不悅；生…的氣；因…而憤恨
exception.eg: Why did you take exception to what he said? He was only joking.

exceptional.eng_def: much greater than usual, especially in skill, intelligence, quality, etc.
exceptional.chi_def: （尤指在技能、才智、品質等方面）卓越的，傑出的，不同凡響的

excerpt.eng_def: a short part taken from a speech, book, film, etc.
excerpt.chi_def: （演講、書、電影等的）摘錄，節錄，片斷
excerpt.eg: An excerpt from her new thriller will appear in this weekend's magazine.

excess.eng_def: an amount that is more than acceptable, expected, or reasonable
excess.eg: An excess of enthusiasm is not always a good thing.

excess.eng_def: actions far past the limit of what is acceptable
excess.chi_def: 過分的行為；越軌行為；暴行
excess.eg: For many years people were trying to escape the excesses (= cruel actions) of the junta.

excess.eng_def: a part of the cost of an accident, injury, etc. that you agree to pay yourself when you buy insurance
excess.eg: She has an excess of £200 on her home insurance policy.
Cut off any excess pastry and put it to one side.

excessive.eg: Excessive exercise can sometimes cause health problems.

exchange.eng_def: the act of giving something to someone and them giving you something else

exchange.eg: There was a brief exchange between the two leaders.

exchange.eng_def: an arrangement in which students from one country go to stay with students from another country
exchange.chi_def: （不同國家學校間的）交換生計畫
exchange.eg: Are you going on the French exchange this year?

exchange.eng_def: to give something to someone and receive something from that person
exchange.eg: It's traditional for the two teams to exchange shirts after the game.

exchange.eng_def: to take something back to a shop where it was bought and get something else instead
exchange.chi_def: （因為購買的商品不合適而去商店）換貨
exchange.eg: If you don't like the gift, you can exchange it.

excite.eng_def: to make someone have strong feelings of happiness and enthusiasm
excite.chi_def: 激發（情感）；使激動；使興奮
excite.eg: Nothing about my life excites me at present.

excite.eng_def: to cause a particular reaction in someone
excite.eg: This product has excited a great deal of media interest.

excitement.eng_def: a feeling of being excited, or an exciting event
excitement.chi_def: 激動，興奮；令人興奮的事情
excitement.eg: Robin's heart was pounding with excitement.

exclaim.eng_def: to say or shout something suddenly because of surprise, fear, pleasure, etc.
exclaim.chi_def: （因吃驚、害怕、喜悅等）呼喊，驚叫

exclude.eng_def: to prevent someone or something from entering a place or taking part in an activity
exclude.eg: Women are still excluded from the club.

exclude.eng_def: to decide that something is not true or possible
exclude.chi_def: 排除…；不考慮…；認為…不可能
exclude.eg: We can't exclude the possibility that he is dead.

exclusive.eng_def: limited to only one person or group of people
exclusive.chi_def: 專用的，專有的；獨有的，獨佔的
exclusive.eg: This room is for the exclusive use of guests.

exclusive.eng_def: expensive and only for people who are rich or of a high social class

exclusive.eg: Is the total exclusive of service charges?

exclusive.eng_def: not possible at the same time
exclusive.chi_def: 相互排斥的；互不相容的
exclusive.eg: Some people think that uncontrolled economic growth and environmental stability are mutually exclusive.

exclusive.eng_def: a story that is published in one magazine, website, etc., and no others
exclusive.chi_def: 獨家新聞；獨家報道；獨家專訪
exclusive.eg: The newspaper published an exclusive about the escape.

excuse.eg: Please excuse me for arriving late - the bus was delayed.

excuse.eng_def: a polite way of attracting someone's attention, especially of someone you do not know
excuse.chi_def: （用於禮貌地引起他人、尤其是陌生人的注意）勞駕，打擾
excuse.eg: Excuse me, does this bus go to Oxford Street?

excuse.eng_def: used to politely ask someone to move so that you can walk past them
excuse.chi_def: （用於禮貌地請求別人讓路）借過，勞駕，對不起
excuse.eg: Excuse me, can I just get past?

excuse.eng_def: used to tell someone politely that you are leaving
excuse.eg: Excuse me a moment, I'll be with you shortly.

excuse.eng_def: used to say sorry for something you have done by accident
excuse.chi_def: （用於無意做了某事後致歉）對不起
excuse.eg: Did I take your seat? Do excuse me.

excuse.chi_def: （用於表示異議）請原諒，對不起
excuse.eg: Excuse me but aren't you forgetting something?

excuse.eng_def: used to politely ask someone to repeat something they have said because you have not heard it
excuse.chi_def: （用於沒聽清楚某事禮貌地請別人重複）對不起，請再說一遍

excuse.eng_def: a reason that you give to explain why you did something wrong
excuse.eg: He'd better have a good excuse for being late.

excuse.eng_def: a false reason that you give to explain why you do something
excuse.eg: She was just looking for an excuse to call him.

excuse.eng_def: to explain why you cannot be present somewhere
excuse.chi_def: 因為不能到場表示歉意
excuse.eg: Please make my excuses at the meeting on Friday.

excuse.eng_def: to give false reasons why you cannot do something
excuse.eg: You're always making excuses for not helping me.

execute.eng_def: to kill someone as a legal punishment
to do or perform something, especially in a planned way
execute.chi_def: （尤指有計劃地）實施，履行，表演

execute.eng_def: If you execute someone's will, you deal with that person's money, property, etc., according to the instructions in it.

execution.eng_def: the legal punishment of killing someone
execution.eg: Execution is still the penalty in some states for murder.

execution.eng_def: the act of doing or performing something, especially in a planned way
execution.chi_def: （尤指有計劃的）實行，履行，表演
execution.eg: Sometimes in the execution of their duty the police have to use firearms.

executive.eng_def: someone in a high position, especially in business, who makes decisions and puts them into action
executive.chi_def: （尤指商業機構中的）行政主管，經理
executive.eg: She is now a senior executive, having worked her way up through the company.

executive.eng_def: the part of a government that is responsible for making certain that laws and decisions are put into action
a group of people who run a business or an organization
executive.chi_def: （公司或組織的）執行委員會，領導階層
executive.eg: The executive of the health workers' union accepted the proposed pay increase on behalf of their members.

executive.eng_def: relating to making decisions and managing businesses, or suitable for people with important jobs in business
executive.chi_def: 決策的，管理的；給重要人物使用的
executive.eg: His executive skills will be very useful to the company.

exercise.eng_def: physical activity that you do to make your body strong and healthy
exercise.eg: Swimming is my favourite form of exercise.

exercise.eng_def: an action or actions intended to improve something or make something happen
exercise.eg: Ships from eight navies will be taking part in an exercise in the Pacific to improve their efficiency in combat.

exercise.eng_def: a short piece of written work that you do to practise something you are learning
exercise.eg: The book has exercises at the end of every chapter.
The exercise of restraint may well be difficult.

exercise.eng_def: a ceremony that includes speeches and usually traditional music or activities
to do physical activities to make your body strong and healthy
exercise.eg: She exercises most evenings usually by running.

exercise.eng_def: If you exercise an animal, you make it walk or run so that it stays strong and healthy.
exercise.eg: Now he's retired he spends most afternoons exercising his dogs.
I exercised my democratic right by not voting in the election.

exert.eng_def: to use something such as authority, power, influence, etc. in order to make something happen
exert.chi_def: 運用；行使（權威、權力等）；施加（影響等）
exert.eg: If you were to exert your influence they might change their decision.

exert.eng_def: to make a mental or physical effort
exert.eg: I was too tired to exert myself.

exhaust.chi_def: 使筋疲力竭；使疲憊不堪
exhaust.eg: The long journey exhausted the children.
How long will it be before the world's fuel supplies are exhausted?

exhaust.eng_def: the waste gas from an engine, especially a car's, or the pipe the gas flows through
exhaust.chi_def: （引擎排出的）廢氣；（尤指汽車的）尾氣；排氣管
exhaust.eg: Car exhaust is the main reason for the city's pollution.

exhibit.eg: He frequently exhibits at the art gallery.

exhibit.eng_def: an object that is shown to the public in a museum, etc.
exhibit.eg: The museum has a fascinating collection of exhibits ranging from Iron Age pottery to Inuit clothing.

exhibit.eng_def: a collection of objects that is shown to the public in a museum, etc.
exhibit.eg: Let's go see the new dinosaur exhibit.

exhibit.eng_def: a thing used as evidence (= proof that something is true) in a trial
exhibit.eg: Is exhibit C the weapon that you say was used?

exhibition.eng_def: an event at which objects such as paintings are shown to the public, a situation in which someone shows a particular skill or quality to the public, or the act of showing these things
exhibition.eg: The photographs will be on exhibition until the end of the month.

exile.eng_def: the condition of someone being sent or kept away from their own country, village, etc., especially for political reasons
exile.chi_def: （尤指出於政治原因的）流放，放逐，流亡
exile.eg: The king went into exile because of the political situation in his country.

exile.eng_def: a person who is sent or kept away from their own country, etc.
to send someone away from their own country, village, etc., especially for political reasons
exile.chi_def: （尤指出於政治原因的）流放，放逐，流亡
exile.eg: The monarch was exiled because of the coup.

exist.eng_def: to be, or to be real
to live, or to live in difficult conditions
exist.eg: Some species exist in this small area of forest and nowhere else on earth.

existence.eng_def: the fact of something or someone existing
existence.eg: Many people question the existence of God.
She has a miserable existence living with him.

exit.eng_def: the door through which you might leave a building or large vehicle, or the act of leaving something, especially a theatre stage
exit.chi_def: （建築物或大型交通工具的）出口，安全門；（尤指演員）退場
exit.eg: a fire exit (= a door you can escape through if there is a fire)

exit.eng_def: a smaller road used to leave a main road
exit.eg: Come off the motorway at the Duxford exit.

exit.eng_def: to leave a building or large vehicle
exit.chi_def: 離開（建築物或大型交通工具）
exit.eg: I exited quickly before anyone could see me.

exit.eng_def: to end a computer program that you are using
exit.eg: You have to exit the program before starting another.

exotic.eng_def: unusual and exciting because of coming (or seeming to come) from far away, especially a tropical country
exotic.chi_def: 異國風情的，外國情調的；奇異的

expand.eng_def: to increase in size, number, or importance, or to make something increase in this way
expand.chi_def: （使）（尺寸、數量或重要性）擴大，增加；（使）膨脹
expand.eg: The air in the balloon expands when heated.

expansion.eng_def: the increase of something in size, number, or importance
expansion.chi_def: （尺寸、數量或重要性的）擴大，增加，擴展
expansion.eg: the rapid expansion of the software industry

expect.eng_def: to think or believe something will happen, or someone will arrive
expect.eg: We are expecting a lot of applicants for the job.
All parents of small children get tired. It's to be expected.

expect.eng_def: to think that someone should behave in a particular way or do a particular thing
expect.eg: I expect punctuality from my students.
She shouldn't be lifting those boxes if she's expecting.

expectation.eng_def: the feeling that good things are going to happen in the future
expectation.eg: The holiday lived up to all our expectations (= was as good as we were expecting).

expectation.eng_def: the feeling of expecting something to happen
expectation.eg: Considering the injuries he's had there can be little expectation of him winning the race.

expectation.chi_def: 出乎所有人的預料；意想不到的是
expectation.eg: Contrary to all expectations, she was accepted by the academy.

expedition.eng_def: an organized journey for a particular purpose
expedition.eg: We're going on a shopping expedition on Saturday.

expedition.eng_def: the people, vehicles, animals, etc. taking part in an expedition
expedition.chi_def: 踏上征途的一批人（或車、動物等）；考察隊；探險隊
expedition.eg: The British expedition to Mount Everest is leaving next month.
We will deal with your order with the greatest possible expedition.

expel.eng_def: to force someone to leave a school, organization, or country
expel.eg: The new government has expelled all foreign diplomats.

expel.eng_def: to force air or liquid out of something
expel.eg: She took a deep breath, then expelled the air in short blasts.

expense.eng_def: the use of money, time, or effort
expense.eg: Buying a bigger car has proved to be well worth the expense.

expense.eng_def: something that makes you spend money
expense.chi_def: 花錢的東西（或緣由）；開銷
expense.eg: Our biggest expense this year was our summer holiday.

expense.eng_def: money that you spend when you are doing your job, that your employer will pay back to you
expense.chi_def: （向僱主報銷的）業務費用，開支，花銷
expense.eg: I need to get my expenses approved.

expensive.chi_def: 昂貴的；用錢多的；價格高的

experience.eng_def: (the process of getting) knowledge or skill from doing, seeing, or feeling things
experience.eg: Do you have any experience of working with kids? (= Have you ever worked with them?)

experience.eng_def: something that happens to you that affects how you feel
experience.eg: I had a pretty unpleasant experience at the dentist's.

experience.eng_def: If you experience something, it happens to you, or you feel it.
experience.eg: We experienced a lot of difficulty in selling our house.

experiment.eng_def: a test done in order to learn something or to discover if something works or is true
experiment.eg: Some people believe that experiments on animals should be banned.

experiment.eng_def: to try something in order to discover what it is like or find out more about it
experiment.eg: Things would never change if people weren't prepared to experiment.

experimental.eng_def: relating to tests, especially scientific ones
experimental.chi_def: （尤指科學方面）實驗（性）的，試驗（性）的，根據實驗（試驗）的
experimental.eg: The drug is still at the experimental stage (= is still being tested).

expert.eng_def: a person with a high level of knowledge or skill relating to a particular subject or activity
having or showing a lot of knowledge or skill
expert.eg: The centre provides expert advice for people with financial problems.

expertise.eng_def: a high level of knowledge or skill
expertise.eg: We admired the expertise with which he prepared the meal.

expiration.eng_def: the situation in which something which lasts for a fixed length of time comes to an end or stops being in use

expire.eng_def: If something that lasts for a fixed length of time expires, it comes to an end or stops being in use.

explain.eng_def: to make something clear or easy to understand by describing or giving information about it
explain.eg: If there's anything you don't understand, I'll be happy to explain.

explain.eng_def: to give reasons for your behaviour
explain.chi_def: 為自己的行為作出說明（或解釋）
explain.eg: He hadn't been home for three days so I asked him to explain himself.

explanation.eng_def: the details or reasons that someone gives to make something clear or easy to understand
explanation.eg: Could you give me a quick explanation of how it works?

explicit.chi_def: 清楚明白的；明確的；不含糊的
explicit.eg: I gave her very explicit directions how to get here.

explicit.eng_def: showing or talking about sex or violence in a very detailed way
explicit.chi_def: （描繪性或暴力）赤裸裸的，露骨的

explode.eng_def: to break up into pieces violently, or to cause something to do this
explode.eg: A bomb exploded at one of the capital's busiest railway stations this morning.

explode.eng_def: to react suddenly with a strong expression of emotion
explode.chi_def: （情感）突然迸發，爆發，突然發作
explode.eg: "What on earth do you think you're doing?" she exploded (= said angrily).
The population has exploded in the last ten years.

explode.eng_def: to show something to be wrong
explode.eg: This book finally explodes some of the myths about the origin of the universe.

exploit.eng_def: to use something in a way that helps you
exploit.eg: We need to make sure that we exploit our resources as fully as possible.

exploit.eng_def: to use someone or something unfairly for your own advantage
exploit.eg: Laws exist to stop companies exploiting their employees.

exploit.eng_def: something unusual, brave, or funny that someone has done
exploit.chi_def: 不尋常的行為；英勇的行為；奇遇
exploit.eg: She was telling me about her exploits while travelling around Africa.

exploration.eng_def: the activity of searching and finding out about something
exploration.eg: Livingstone was the first European to make an exploration of the Zambezi river (= to travel to it in order to discover more about it).

explore.eng_def: to think or talk about something in order to find out more about it
explore.eg: Let's explore this issue/idea more fully.

explosion.eng_def: the fact of something such as a bomb exploding
explosion.eg: The fire was thought to have been caused by a gas explosion.

explosion.eng_def: a sudden strong expression of emotion
explosion.chi_def: （情感的）突然迸發，爆發，突然發作
explosion.eg: There was an explosion of applause from the audience at the end of the performance.

explosion.eng_def: a large increase in the number of something that happens very quickly
explosion.eg: The government has had to take measures to halt the population explosion.

explosion.eng_def: the act of proving that something is wrong
explosion.eg: the explosion of the conspiracy theories surrounding the death of the star

explosive.eng_def: exploding or able to explode easily
explosive.chi_def: 易爆炸的；會爆炸的；可能引起爆炸的

explosive.eng_def: very loud and sudden, like an explosion
explosive.chi_def: 如爆炸般的；震耳欲聾的
explosive.eg: There was an explosive clap of thunder overhead.

explosive.eng_def: An explosive situation or emotion is one in which strong feelings are loudly or violently expressed.
explosive.chi_def: （局勢）一觸即發的，爆炸性的；（情感）突然迸發的
explosive.eg: The situation in some of America's cities has become explosive.

explosive.eng_def: An explosive increase is very large and quick.
explosive.eg: The last few years have seen an explosive increase in the number of homeless people on our streets.

explosive.eng_def: a substance or piece of equipment that can cause explosions

export.eng_def: to send goods to another country for sale
export.eg: French cheeses are exported to many different countries.

export.eng_def: to put something from one country into use in other countries
export.chi_def: 把…帶到另一國家；傳播；輸出
export.eg: American culture has been exported all over the world.

export.eng_def: If you export information from a computer, you copy a large amount of it to a different part of the computer's memory or to another device.
a product that you sell in another country, or the business of sending goods to another country in order to sell them there
export.chi_def: 出口；出口商品；出口業務
export.eg: Coffee is one of Brazil's main exports.

expose.eng_def: to remove what is covering something so that it can be seen
expose.eg: The plaster on the walls has been removed to expose the original bricks underneath.

expose.eng_def: If a man exposes himself, he shows his sexual organs in a public place to people he does not know.
expose.chi_def: （男性由於病態心理在公共場合）裸露性器官，露陰

expose.eng_def: to make public something bad or dishonest
expose.chi_def: 揭露，揭發，揭穿壞事（或不誠實之事）
expose.eg: The review exposed widespread corruption in the police force.

expose.eng_def: a public report of the facts about a situation, especially one that is shocking or has been kept secret
expose.chi_def: （尤指對令人震驚或保密之事的）曝光報道
expose.eg: Today's newspaper contains a searing exposé of police corruption.

exposure.eng_def: the fact of experiencing something or being affected by it because of being in a particular situation or place
exposure.eg: You should always limit your exposure to the sun.

exposure.eng_def: the fact of something bad that someone has done being made public]
exposure.eg: The exposure of the politician's love affair forced him to resign.

exposure.eng_def: the fact of an event or information being often discussed in newspapers and on the television, etc.
exposure.chi_def: （在報紙或電視上的）報導，宣傳，曝光
exposure.eg: His last movie got so much exposure in the press.

exposure.eng_def: a serious medical condition that is caused by being outside in very cold weather
exposure.chi_def: （暴露於嚴寒而導致的）凍傷（病），受寒
exposure.eg: All the members of the expedition to the South Pole died of exposure.

exposure.eng_def: a single photograph on a piece of film, or the amount of time a piece of film is open to the light when making a photograph
exposure.chi_def: （底片的）一張；曝光時間，曝光量
exposure.eg: There are 24 exposures on this film.

exposure.eng_def: the direction in which something faces
exposure.eg: Our dining room has a northern exposure (= faces north), so it's rather cold.

express.eng_def: to show a feeling, opinion, or fact
to communicate what you think or feel, by speaking or writing, or in some other way
express.chi_def: 表達自己（的想法或感受）
express.eg: I'm afraid I'm not expressing myself very clearly.

express.eng_def: to send something somewhere very quickly
express.eg: Your order will be expressed to you within 24 hours.
Please send this letter by express delivery.

express.chi_def: 明確的；明白表示的；特別指出的
express.eg: It is my express wish that after my death, my books be given to my old college library.

express.eng_def: using a service that does something faster than usual
a train or bus that takes less time to do a journey than other trains or buses
express.eg: The quickest way to get here is to take the uptown express.

express.eng_def: a service that does something faster than usual
express.eg: This parcel needs to be sent by express.

expression.eng_def: the act of saying what you think or showing how you feel using words or actions
expression.eg: He wrote her a poem as an expression of his love.

expression.eng_def: the look on someone's face, showing what they feel or think
expression.eg: I could tell from her expression that something serious had happened.

expression.eng_def: a word or group of words used in a particular situation or by particular people
expression.eg: He uses a lot of unusual expressions.

expression.eng_def: in mathematics, a symbol or group of symbols that represent an amount

expressive.eng_def: showing what someone thinks or feels
expressive.chi_def: 富於表情的；有表現力的

expressive.eg: The final movement of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony is expressive of joy.

exquisite.eng_def: used to describe feelings such as pleasure or pain that are extremely strong, or qualities that are extremely good; great
exquisite.chi_def: （感覺）劇烈的，強烈的；（品質）完美的，卓越的

extend.eng_def: to add to something in order to make it bigger or longer
extend.eg: We have plans to extend our house (= to make it bigger).
The bar has recently extended its opening hours (= made them longer).
We've extended a clothesline (= made it reach) between two trees in the garden.
The Sahara Desert extends for miles.

extend.eng_def: to offer or give something to someone
extend.eg: I should like to extend my thanks to you for your kindness.

extend.eng_def: to include or affect someone or something
extend.eg: Parking restrictions do not extend to disabled people.

extend.eng_def: to cause someone to use all their ability
extend.chi_def: 使發揮才幹；使盡用其才；使竭盡全力
extend.eg: She feels that her job doesn't extend her enough.

extension.eng_def: the fact of reaching, stretching, or continuing; the act of adding to something in order to make it bigger or longer
extension.eg: Martin Luther King, Jr, campaigned for the extension of civil rights to (= for them to include) black people.

extension.eng_def: any of two or more phones in the same house that share the same number, or any of a number of phones connected to a switchboard in a large building such as an office
extension.chi_def: （共用一個號碼的）電話分機；（號碼不同的）電話分機
extension.eg: We have an extension in our bedroom.

extension.eng_def: the last part of the name of a computer file, which comes after a (.) and shows what type of file it is
extension.chi_def: 副檔名（電腦檔案名稱的最後一部分，用於區分檔案種類）

extension.eng_def: a long piece of hair that is added to a person's own hair in order to make the hair longer
extension.chi_def: （為創造長髮效果而織入頭髮的）一段假髮

extension.eng_def: a new part added to a house or other building
extension.eg: We're building an extension to/on our house.

extension.eng_def: intended to support students' learning by making them try different or more difficult things in addition to their basic work
extension.chi_def: （學生作業）延展性的，難度更高的，範圍更廣的
extension.eg: The book includes lesson plans and extension activities.

extension.eng_def: offered by a university to people who are not studying for a degree there
extension.chi_def: （尤指學院或大學）對校外學生提供課程的；為非在校生而設的

extensive.eng_def: covering a large area; having a great range
extensive.chi_def: 廣闊的，大面積的；覆蓋範圍廣的

extent.eg: From the top of the Empire State Building, you can see the full extent of Manhattan (= the area it covers).

extent.eng_def: the degree to which something happens or is likely to happen
extent.eg: She had not realized the extent to which the children had been affected.
Some people hold their beliefs very strongly, even to the extent of being prepared to go to prison for them.

extent.eng_def: to a particular degree or stage, often causing particular results
extent.eg: Sales have fallen badly this year, to the extent that we will have to close some of our shops.

extent.eng_def: to the same degree as; as much as
extent.chi_def: 在同樣的程度上；同樣，一樣
extent.eg: The rich will not benefit from the proposed changes to the tax system to the same extent as the lower paid.
To some extent, she was responsible for the accident.
The car was damaged to such an extent that it couldn't be repaired.
To what extent will the budget have to be modified?

exterior.eg: In some of the villages the exterior walls of the houses are painted pink.

exterior.eng_def: the outside part of something or someone
exterior.eg: The Palace of Fontainebleau has a very grand exterior.

external.eng_def: of, on, for, or coming from the outside
external.chi_def: 外面的；外表的；來自外部的
external.eg: the external walls of the house

extinct.eg: There is concern that the giant panda will soon become extinct.

extinct.eng_def: An extinct volcano is one that is not now active (= will not explode again).

extra.eg: If you need any extra help, just call me.
They pay her extra to work nights.

extra.eng_def: something that you can get with something else if you pay a little more money
extra.chi_def: 另外付費就可額外得到的東西
extra.eg: A sunroof is an optional extra on this model of the car.

extra.eng_def: a person in a film who does not have a speaking part and who is usually part of the scene, for example, in a crowd
extra.chi_def: （電影中的）臨時演員，群眾演員

extra.eng_def: a point given to one cricket team if the other team makes an illegal mistake when bowling
extra.chi_def: 額外得分（板球中一隊在敵隊發球犯規時所得的分數）

extra.eg: extraterrestrial beings (= imaginary creatures which come from outside the planet Earth)

extract.eng_def: to remove or take out something
extract.eg: They used to extract iron ore from this site.

extract.eng_def: to make someone give you something when they do not want to
extract.eg: After much persuasion they managed to extract the information from him.

extract.eng_def: a substance taken from a plant, flower, etc. and used especially in food or medicine
extract.chi_def: （尤指食物或藥物的）提出物，精華，汁

extract.eng_def: a particular part of a book, poem, etc. that is chosen so that it can be used in a discussion, article, etc.
extract.eg: They published an extract from his autobiography.

extracurricular.eng_def: An extracurricular activity or subject is not part of the usual school or college course.
used to refer to something a person does secretly or unofficially and not within their normal work or relationship, especially a sexual relationship
extracurricular.chi_def: 業餘的，分外的；（尤指性關係）婚外的
extracurricular.eg: He detailed the future president's extracurricular activities while governor.

extraordinary.eng_def: very unusual, special, unexpected, or strange
extraordinary.chi_def: 非凡的；特別的；意想不到的；令人驚奇的
extraordinary.eg: He told the extraordinary story of his escape.

extraordinary.eng_def: a special meeting that happens between regular meetings

extreme.eng_def: very large in amount or degree

extreme.chi_def: 極嚴厲的；嚴重的；極差的

extreme.eng_def: Extreme beliefs and political parties are considered by most people to be unreasonable and unacceptable.
extreme.chi_def: （信仰或政黨）偏激的，過激的，極端的

extreme.eng_def: at the furthest point, especially from the centre
extreme.chi_def: 末端的，盡頭的；（尤指）離中心最遠的
extreme.eg: They live in the extreme south of the island.

extreme.eng_def: the largest possible amount or degree of something
extreme.eg: I've never witnessed such extremes of wealth and poverty.
Some of the scenes were unpleasant in the extreme.

extreme.eng_def: a situation, feeling, etc. that is the opposite or very different from another one
extreme.eg: My moods seem to go from one extreme to another (= my moods often change from very bad to very good).

eye.eng_def: one of the two organs in your face that are used for seeing
eye.eg: He has no sight in his left eye.

eye.eng_def: a dark spot on a potato or similar plant part, from which a new stem and leaves will grow
eye.chi_def: （馬鈴薯或者類似植物的）芽眼

eye.eng_def: the hole in a needle through which you put the thread
to look at someone or something with interest
eye.eg: I could see her eyeing my lunch.

eyebrow.eng_def: the line of short hairs above each eye in humans
eyebrow.eg: Do you pluck your eyebrows (= remove some of the hairs to change their shape)?

eyelash.eng_def: any of the short hairs that grow along the edges of the eye

eyelid.eng_def: either of the two pieces of skin that can close over each eye

fable.eng_def: a short story that tells a general truth or is only partly based on fact, or literature of this type
fable.eg: the fable of the tortoise and the hare

fabric.eng_def: cloth or material for making clothes, covering furniture, etc.
the structure or parts of something
fabric.chi_def: （尤指社會或建築物的）結構，構造

fabulous.eg: She looked absolutely fabulous in her dress.

fabulous.eng_def: imaginary, not existing in real life
fabulous.eg: The unicorn is a fabulous creature.

face.eng_def: the front of the head, where the eyes, nose, and mouth are
face.eg: She has a long, thin face.
I was greeted by smiling faces.
