face.eng_def: to make a strange expression with your face, for example to show that you do not like someone or something
face.eg: I was making silly faces to get the baby to laugh.

face.eng_def: the front or surface of an object
face.eg: the north face of a mountain

face.eng_def: the front of a clock or watch that has the numbers or marks that show what time it is
face.eg: a watch face with Roman numerals

face.eng_def: the respect and honour of others
face.eg: He thinks he would lose face if he admitted the mistake.

face.eng_def: If you face a problem, or a problem faces you, you have to deal with it.
face.chi_def: 面對，面臨，必須對付（難題）
face.eg: This is one of the many problems faced by working mothers.

face.eng_def: to accept that something unpleasant is true and start to deal with the situation
face.eg: I think Phil has to face the fact that she no longer loves him.

face.eng_def: to not want to do or deal with something unpleasant
face.eg: I can't face walking up all those steps again.

face.eng_def: to deal with someone when the situation between you is difficult
face.chi_def: 面對，應對（不想見到的人）
face.eg: She half hoped he would not find her, though she knew she would have to face him sooner or later.

face.eng_def: to turn or be turned towards something physically; to be opposite something
face.eg: The balcony faced towards the sea.

face.eng_def: If you face a building, you put an extra layer in front of what is already there.
face.chi_def: （在建築物表面）覆蓋，抹蓋，貼上
face.eg: The house was built of wood but faced in/with brick.

facial.eng_def: a beauty treatment that cleans and improves the skin of the face with creams and gentle rubbing
facial.eg: Beauty treatments range from an eyelash tint at £8 to a deep cleansing facial costing £80.

facilitate.eng_def: to make something possible or easier
facilitate.eg: The new ramp will facilitate the entry of wheelchairs.

facility.eng_def: a place, especially including buildings, where a particular activity happens
facility.chi_def: （尤指包含多個建築物，有特定用途的）場所

facility.eng_def: the buildings, equipment, and services provided for a particular purpose
an ability to do something easily or well
facility.eg: His facility for languages is astonishing.

facility.eng_def: a feature of a product that allows you to do something
facility.eg: a computer with a speech recognition facility

fact.eng_def: something that is known to have happened or to exist, especially something for which proof exists, or about which there is information
fact.chi_def: 現實，實際情況；（尤指）事實，真相
fact.eg: No decision will be made until we know all the facts.

fact.eng_def: used to add emphasis to what you are saying, or to show that it is the opposite of or different from what went before
fact.eg: I don't work. In fact, I've never had a job.

fact.eng_def: something unpleasant that cannot be avoided
fact.eg: Going bald is just a fact of life.

fact.chi_def: 翔實的資料；準確的資料
fact.eg: We are getting some facts and figures together and we will then have a full board meeting.

fact.eng_def: details about sexual activity and the way that babies are born

faction.eng_def: a group within a larger group, especially one with slightly different ideas from the main group
faction.chi_def: （大團體中的）派別，派系，小集團
faction.eg: the left-wing faction of the party

factor.eng_def: a fact or situation that influences the result of something
factor.eg: People's voting habits are influenced by political, social and economic factors.

factor.eng_def: in mathematics, any whole number that is produced when you divide a larger number by another whole number
factor.eg: Two, three, four and six are all factors of twelve.

factor.eng_def: a particular level on some systems of measurement
If an amount becomes larger or smaller by a factor of a particular number, it becomes that number of times larger or smaller.
factor.eg: Cases of leukaemia in the area near the nuclear reactor have risen by a factor of four.

factory.eng_def: a building or set of buildings where large amounts of goods are made using machines

faculty.eng_def: a natural ability to hear, see, think, move, etc.
faculty.eg: Even at the age of 100, she still had all her faculties.

faculty.eng_def: a special ability to do a particular thing
faculty.eg: She has a faculty for inspiring confidence in people.

faculty.eng_def: a group of departments in a college that specialize in a particular subject or group of subjects
the people who teach in a department in a college
faculty.chi_def: （高等院校中院系的）全體教師
faculty.eg: He has been a faculty member at the college for 20 years.

fad.eng_def: a style, activity, or interest that is very popular for a short period of time
fad.chi_def: 一時的風尚；短暫的狂熱

fade.eng_def: to (cause to) lose colour, brightness, or strength gradually
fade.eg: If you hang your clothes out in the bright sun, they will fade.

fail.eng_def: to not succeed in what you are trying to achieve or are expected to do
fail.eg: She moved to London in the hope of finding work as a model, but failed.

fail.eng_def: if none of our plans succeed
fail.eg: If all else fails, we can always stay in and watch TV.

fail.eng_def: to be unsuccessful, or to judge that someone has been unsuccessful, in a test or exam
fail.eg: I passed in history but failed in chemistry.

fail.eng_def: to not do something that you should do
fail.eg: He failed to arrive on time.

fail.eng_def: used when you do not accept something
fail.eg: I fail to see why you can't work on a Saturday.

fail.eng_def: to become weaker or stop working completely
fail.eg: If my eyesight fails, I'll have to stop doing this job.

fail.eng_def: If a business fails, it is unable to continue because of money problems.
to not help someone when you are expected to do so
fail.eg: He failed her in her moment of need.

fail.eng_def: an unsuccessful result in a course, test, or exam
fail.eg: John got three passes and four fails in his exams.

fail.eng_def: something that has been done very badly or gone completely wrong; a failure
fail.eg: My pancakes were an epic fail (= completely unsuccessful).

fail.eng_def: If you do something without fail, you always do it.
fail.eg: I go to the gym every Monday and Wednesday, without fail.

fail.eng_def: used to tell someone that they must do something
fail.eg: Be there at nine o'clock, without fail.

failure.eng_def: the fact of someone or something not succeeding
failure.eg: The meeting was a complete/total failure.

failure.eng_def: the fact of not doing something that you must do or are expected to do
failure.eg: His failure to return her phone call made her realize that something was wrong.

failure.eng_def: the fact of something not working, or stopping working as well as it should

faint.chi_def: 微弱的；不清晰的；微小的

faint.eng_def: used to emphasize that you do not know something
faint.eg: "Is she going to stay?" "I haven't the faintest idea."

faint.eng_def: to feel weak, as if you are about to become unconscious
faint.chi_def: 虛弱無力；感到暈眩；快要暈倒似的

faint.eng_def: to suddenly become unconscious for a short time, usually falling down
faint.eg: He faints at the sight of blood.

faint.eng_def: the act of suddenly becoming unconscious
faint.eg: On receiving the news, she fell into a dead faint.

fair.eng_def: treating someone in a way that is right or reasonable, or treating a group of people equally and not allowing personal opinions to influence your judgment
fair.chi_def: 合理的；公平的；公正的；平等待人的
fair.eg: a fair trial

fair.eng_def: If something is fair, it is reasonable and is what you expect or deserve.
fair.eg: I thought it was a fair price that she was offering.

fair.eng_def: If a game or competition is fair, it is done according to the rules.
fair.eg: It was a fair fight.

fair.eng_def: it is the right way to treat someone and what they deserve
fair.chi_def: 只有…才合理；只有…才正確
fair.eg: I think it's only fair to tell you that we have had over 300 applications for this job.

fair.eng_def: it is true to say
fair.eg: I think it's fair to say (that) you've done less of the work than I have.

fair.eng_def: considering everything that has an effect on a situation, so that a fair judgment can be made
fair.eg: He's done the job badly but, to be fair, I gave him very little time to do it.

fair.eng_def: something you say to show that you understand why someone has done or said something
fair.eg: "I'm just annoyed with him because he's behaved so badly." "Fair enough."

fair.eng_def: something that you say when you want someone to behave reasonably or treat you the same as other people
fair.eg: Come on, it's my turn. Fair's fair!

fair.eng_def: an opportunity to explain something or give your opinions, without other people trying to influence the situation
fair.eg: He didn't think that he got a fair hearing in court.

fair.eng_def: in an honest way and without any doubt
fair.eg: We won the match fair and square.

fair.eng_def: If you hit someone fair and square on a particular part of their body, you hit that person hard, exactly on that part.
fair.eg: He hit me fair and square on the nose.

fair.eng_def: (of skin) pale, or (of hair) pale yellow or gold
fair.chi_def: （皮膚）白皙的；（頭髮）淺黃的，金色的
fair.eg: She's got fair hair and blue eyes.

fair.eng_def: quite large
fair.eg: We've had a fair amount of rain this week.

fair.eng_def: neither very good nor very bad
fair.eg: Films are rated on a scale of poor, fair, good and excellent.

fair.eng_def: (of an idea, guess, or chance) good, but not excellent
fair.chi_def: （想法、猜測或機會）相當好的，不錯的
fair.eg: I think I've got a fair idea of (= I understand reasonably well) what you want.

fair.eng_def: (of weather) pleasant and dry
fair.eg: Fair weather was forecast for the following day.

fair.eng_def: (of a woman) beautiful
fair.eg: a fair maiden

fair.eng_def: a large public event where goods are bought and sold, usually from tables that have been specially arranged for the event, and where there is often entertainment
fair.eg: I bought a wooden salad bowl at the local craft fair.

fair.eng_def: an outside event where you can ride on large machines for pleasure and play games to win prizes
a large show at which people who work in a particular industry meet, and sell and advertise their products
fair.chi_def: 商品展銷會，商品交易會
fair.eg: a book/antiques/toy fair

fair.eng_def: a public event in the countryside where farm animals and farm products are sold
fair.eg: a county/state fair

fair.eng_def: a public event, often held outside, where you can take part in competitions and buy small things and food, often organized to collect money for a particular purpose
fair.eg: the school fair

fairly.eng_def: more than average, but less than very
used to emphasize figurative expressions that describe what people or objects are doing
fairly.eg: The answer fairly jumps off the page at you!

fairly.eng_def: If you do something fairly, you do it in a way that is right and reasonable and treats people equally.
fairly.eg: He claimed that he hadn't been treated fairly by his employers.
She lays the blame for the recession fairly and squarely on the government.

fairy.eng_def: an imaginary creature with magic powers, usually represented as a very small person with wings
to behave in a way that is slightly strange
fairy.eg: It's no good asking her to take care of the children - she's away with the fairies most of the time.

faith.eng_def: great trust or confidence in something or someone
faith.eg: She has no faith in modern medicine.

faith.eng_def: strong belief in God or a particular religion
faith.eg: Even in the bad times she never lost her faith.

faithful.eng_def: firm and not changing in your friendship with or support for a person or an organization, or in your belief in your principles
If your husband, wife, or partner is faithful, he or she does not have a sexual relationship with anyone else.
faithful.chi_def: （配偶或性伴侶）忠誠的，忠貞的
faithful.eg: Was your wife faithful during your marriage?

faithful.eng_def: to continue to support or follow something
faithful.eg: He remained faithful to the regime when so many others spoke out against it.

faithful.eng_def: true or not changing any of the details, facts, style, etc. of the original
faithful.chi_def: 如實的，絲毫不作改動的
faithful.eg: She gave a faithful account of what had happened on that night.

faithful.eng_def: someone who continues to support someone or something
faithful.eg: He gave a rousing speech to a room full of party faithfuls (= faithful supporters of a political party).

faithful.eng_def: people who are always loyal to a particular group or organization, especially a political party
faithful.chi_def: 忠實信徒；（尤指政黨的）忠誠支持者
faithful.eg: They asked for donations from the party faithful.

faithful.eng_def: the people who believe in a particular religion
faithful.eg: We heard bells calling the faithful to prayer.

fake.eng_def: an object that is made to look real or valuable in order to deceive people
fake.eg: Experts revealed that the painting was a fake.

fake.eng_def: someone who is not what or who they claim to be
fake.eg: After working for ten years as a doctor, he was exposed as a fake.

fake.eng_def: not real, but made to look or seem real
fake.eg: He was charged with possessing a fake passport.

fake.eng_def: showing or pretending to feel emotions that are not sincere
to pretend that you have a feeling or illness
fake.chi_def: 裝出（某種感情）；假裝（有病）

fake.eng_def: to make an object look real or valuable in order to deceive people

fall.eng_def: to suddenly go down onto the ground or towards the ground without intending to or by accident
fall.eg: The path's very steep, so be careful you don't fall.

fall.eng_def: to fall and land with your face down
fall.eg: Poor Kathy fell flat on her face in the mud.

fall.eng_def: to become lower in size, amount, or strength
fall.eg: Demand for new cars has fallen due to the recession.

fall.eng_def: to come down onto the ground or from a high position to a lower position
fall.eg: The snow had been falling steadily all day.

fall.eng_def: to go down on your knees to show respect
fall.eg: The people all fell to their knees and began to pray.

fall.eng_def: When the curtain falls in the theatre, it comes down because the play or performance has ended.
fall.eg: The audience was still laughing as the curtain fell.

fall.eng_def: to belong to a particular group, subject, or area
fall.chi_def: 屬於（某一群體、學科或領域）
fall.eg: The material falls into three categories.

fall.eng_def: to change to a particular condition from a different one
fall.eg: He always falls asleep after drinking red wine.

fall.eng_def: to be beaten or defeated
fall.eg: The president fell from power during the military coup.

fall.eng_def: If a place falls in a war or an election, an enemy army or a different political party gets control of it.
fall.eg: Rome fell to the Vandals in AD 455.

fall.eng_def: If soldiers fall while fighting, they are killed.
fall.eg: Many brave men fell in the fight to save the city.

fall.eng_def: In cricket, when a wicket falls, the turn of the player who is hitting the ball ends.
fall.eg: Ten wickets fell in 22 overs.

fall.eng_def: to come at a particular time or happen in a particular place
fall.eg: Easter falls late this year.

fall.eng_def: to hang down loosely
fall.eg: The boy's hair fell around his shoulders in golden curls.

fall.eng_def: If your face falls, you suddenly look unhappy or disappointed, and if your spirits fall, you suddenly feel unhappy or disappointed.
fall.chi_def: 臉色變陰沉／情緒變低落
fall.eg: His spirits fell when he saw the distance he still had to go.

fall.eng_def: the fact of the size, amount, or strength of something getting lower
fall.chi_def: （規模、數量或力量的）減少，降低
fall.eg: a fall in the price of petrol/the unemployment rate

fall.eng_def: the season after summer and before winter, when fruits and crops become ready to eat and the leaves fall off the trees
fall.eg: I'm starting college in the fall.

fall.eng_def: the act of falling down to the ground, usually without intending to or by accident
fall.eg: He had/took a nasty fall and hurt his back.

fall.eng_def: an amount of something that moves down onto the ground or from a higher position to a lower position
fall.eg: a heavy fall of snow

fall.eng_def: often used in place names to mean a very wide waterfall, often made of many separate waterfalls
fall.eg: Niagara Falls

fall.eng_def: the fact of being defeated or losing your power
fall.eg: the fall of Rome

falter.eng_def: to lose strength or purpose and stop, or almost stop
falter.eg: The dinner party conversation faltered for a moment.

falter.eng_def: to move awkwardly as if you might fall
falter.eg: The nurse saw him falter and made him lean on her.

fame.eng_def: the state of being known or recognized by many people because of your achievements, skills, etc.
fame.eg: She first rose to fame as a singer at the age of 16.

familiar.eng_def: easy to recognize because of being seen, met, heard, etc. before
familiar.eg: There were one or two familiar faces (= people I knew).

familiar.eng_def: to know something or someone well
familiar.eg: I'm sorry, I'm not familiar with your poetry.

familiar.eng_def: informal and friendly, sometimes in a way that does not show respect to someone who is not a family member or close friend
familiar.eg: He patted her back in an overly familiar way.

familiar.eng_def: a close friend, or a spirit in the shape of a cat, bird, or other animal that is the close companion of a witch
familiar.chi_def: 知交；（以貓、鳥等形象出現，與女巫為伴的）妖精

familiarity.eng_def: a good knowledge of something, or the fact that you know it so well
familiarity.eg: Ellen's familiarity with pop music is astonishing.

family.eng_def: a group of people who are related to each other, such as a mother, a father, and their children
family.eg: A new family has/have moved in next door.
Women shouldn't have to choose between career and family (= having children).

family.eng_def: a pair of adult animals and their babies
family.eg: We've got a family of squirrels living in our garden.

family.eng_def: a large group of related types of animal or plant
family.eg: The lion is a member of the cat family.

famine.eng_def: a situation in which there is not enough food for a great number of people, causing illness and death, or a particular period when this happens
famine.eg: Another crop failure could result in widespread famine.

famous.eng_def: known and recognized by many people

fan.eng_def: someone who admires and supports a person, sport, sports team, etc.
fan.eg: More than 15,000 Liverpool fans attended Saturday's game.

fan.eng_def: an electric device with blades that turn quickly, used to move the air around
fan.eg: There was no air conditioning, just a ceiling fan turning slowly.

fan.eng_def: an object made of folded paper or other material that you wave with your hand in order to move the air around
fan.eg: Fans are still used by many Spanish women during their hot summer as a means of keeping cool.

fan.eng_def: to wave a fan, or something that acts as a fan, in front of your face
fan.eg: It was so hot in the car that I tried to fan myself with the road map.

fan.eng_def: to blow air at a fire to make it burn more strongly
to encourage bad emotions or behaviour to get worse

fanatic.eng_def: a person who is extremely interested in something, to a degree that some people find unreasonable
a person who has very extreme beliefs that may lead them to behave in unreasonable or violent ways

fancy.eng_def: to want to have or do something
fancy.eg: Do you fancy a drink this evening?

fancy.eng_def: to be sexually attracted to someone
fancy.eg: He could tell she fancied him.

fancy.eng_def: to think you are very attractive or important
fancy.eg: That Dave really fancies himself, doesn't he?

fancy.eng_def: to imagine or think that something is so
fancy.eg: He fancies himself as a bit of a singer.
I wanted a simple black dress, nothing fancy.
We stayed in a fancy hotel near the Champs-Élysées.

fancy.eng_def: something that you like very much for a short period
fancy.eg: But for me, parachuting was no passing fancy.

fancy.eng_def: to start liking something or someone very much
fancy.eg: Laura's taken a fancy to Japanese food.

fancy.eng_def: If something takes/tickles your fancy, you like it and want to have or do it.
fancy.eg: I looked in a lot of clothes shops but nothing really tickled my fancy.

fantastic.eg: You look fantastic in that dress.

fantastic.eng_def: strange and imaginary, or not reasonable
fantastic.chi_def: 幻想的；怪誕的，荒誕不經的
fantastic.eg: He drew fantastic animals with two heads and large wings.

fantastic.chi_def: 非同尋常的；奇怪的；難以置信的
fantastic.eg: It seemed fantastic that they still remembered her 50 years later.

fantastic.eng_def: A fantastic amount is very large.
fantastic.eg: She must be earning a fantastic amount of money.

fantasy.eng_def: a pleasant situation that you enjoy thinking about but is unlikely to happen, or the activity of imagining things like this
fantasy.eg: Steve's favourite fantasy was to own a big house and a flashy car.

fantasy.eng_def: a story or type of literature that describes situations that are very different from real life, usually involving magic
fantasy.eg: His preferred reading was horror stories and fantasy.

far.eng_def: at, to, or from a great distance in space or time
far.eg: How far is it from Australia to New Zealand?

far.eng_def: used to say what you think is true, although you do not know all the facts
far.eg: He isn't coming today, as far as I know.

far.eng_def: used to say what your personal opinion is about something
far.eg: She can come whenever she likes, as far as I'm concerned.

far.eng_def: used to say what you have noticed or understood
far.eg: There's been no change, as far as I can tell.

far.chi_def: 我絕不想（絕不會、絕不敢等）
far.eg: Far be it from me to tell you how to run your life.
The situation is far from clear.

far.eng_def: used to describe something that is almost the opposite of something else
far.eg: She insisted that, far from being easy, it would be a difficult period for all concerned.
He's not handsome - far from it.

far.eng_def: from a large number of places
far.eg: People came from far and wide to see the house.

far.eng_def: to be willing to do something that is extreme
far.eg: It's good, but I wouldn't go so far as to say that it's great.

far.eng_def: used to say that an activity has gone well until now
far.chi_def: 到目前為止，一切還算順利
far.eg: I've found a tin of beans. So far so good, but where is the tin opener?
This car is far better than our old one.
They are by far the best students in the class.

far.eng_def: used to refer to something that is not near, or the part of something that is most distant from the centre or from you
far.eg: The station isn't far - we could easily walk there.

far.eng_def: used to refer to political groups whose opinions are very extreme

fare.eng_def: the money that you pay for a journey in a vehicle such as a bus or train
fare.eg: Train fares are going up again.

fare.eng_def: someone who pays to be driven somewhere in a taxi
the type of food that is served in a restaurant
to succeed or be treated in the stated way
fare.eg: How did you fare in your exams?

farewell.eng_def: an occasion when someone says goodbye
farewell.eg: We said our sad farewells and got on the bus.

farm.eng_def: an area of land, together with a house and buildings, used for growing crops and/or keeping animals as a business
a place where a particular type of animal is kept in large numbers in order to be sold
to use land for growing crops and/or keeping animals as a business
farm.eg: The Stamfords have farmed this land for over a hundred years.

farmer.eng_def: someone who owns or takes care of a farm

farther.eng_def: comparative of far : to a greater distance
farther.eg: How much farther is it to the airport?
It was farther to the shop than I expected.

fascination.eng_def: the fact of finding someone or something fascinating
fascination.eg: Miller's fascination with medieval art dates from her childhood.

fashion.eng_def: a style that is popular at a particular time, especially in clothes, hair, make-up, etc.
fashion.chi_def: （尤指服裝、髮型、妝容的）流行款式，時興式樣
fashion.eg: Long hair is back in fashion for men.

fashion.eng_def: to do what is popular at the time
If you use something like it's going out of fashion, you use large amounts of it very quickly.
fashion.eg: Emma spends money like it's going out of fashion.
The rebel army behaved in a brutal fashion.

fashion.eng_def: If you can do something after a fashion, you can do it, but not well.
fashion.eg: I can cook, after a fashion.

fashion.eng_def: to make something using your hands
fashion.eg: He fashioned a hat for himself from/out of newspaper.

fashionable.eng_def: wearing clothes, doing things, and going to places that are in fashion
fashionable.eg: A fashionable couple posed elegantly at the next table.

fast.eng_def: moving or happening quickly, or able to move or happen quickly
If your watch or clock is fast, it shows a time that is later than the correct time.
used to refer to photographic film that allows you to take pictures when there is not much light or when things are moving quickly
used to describe something that is full of speed and excitement
fast.chi_def: 快速激烈的，充滿速度與激情的
fast.eg: It's not a relaxing movie - it's pretty fast and furious.

fast.eng_def: If the colour of a piece of clothing is fast, the colour does not come out of the cloth when it is washed.

fast.eg: The accident was caused by people driving too fast in bad conditions.
The glue had set and my hand was stuck fast.

fast.eng_def: a period of time when you eat no food
fast.eg: Hundreds of prisoners began a fast in protest about prison conditions.

fast.eng_def: to eat no food for a period of time
fast.eg: One day a week he fasts for health reasons.

fasten.eng_def: to (cause something to) become firmly fixed together, or in position, or closed
fasten.eg: Make sure your seat belt is securely fastened.

fasten.eng_def: to fix one thing to another
fasten.chi_def: 把…固定在（…上）／在一起（等等）
fasten.eg: I fastened the sticker to the windscreen.

fat.eng_def: having a lot of flesh on the body
fat.eg: Like most women, she thinks she's fat.
He passed me a fat envelope full of money.

fat.eng_def: used in some phrases to mean very little or none
fat.eg: A fat lot of use you are! (= You are not useful in any way.)

fat.eng_def: the substance under the skin of humans and animals that stores energy and keeps them warm
a solid or liquid substance from animals or plants and used especially in cooking
fat.chi_def: （尤指用於烹飪的）動物油，植物油
fat.eg: This product contains no animal fat.

fatal.eng_def: A fatal illness, accident, etc. causes death.
fatal.eg: This illness is fatal in almost all cases.

fatal.eng_def: very serious and having an important bad effect in the future
fatal.eg: He made the fatal mistake/error of believing what they told him.

father.eg: My father took me to watch the football every Saturday.

father.eng_def: (the title of) a Christian priest, especially a Roman Catholic or Orthodox priest
father.chi_def: （尤指天主教或東正教的）神父

father.eng_def: a name for the Christian God
to become the father of a child by making a woman pregnant

fatigue.eng_def: weakness in something, such as a metal part or structure, often caused by repeated bending
fatigue.eg: The crash was caused by metal fatigue in one of the propeller blades.

fatigue.eng_def: a loose, brownish-green uniform worn by soldiers
fatigue.chi_def: （士兵穿的）迷彩服，工作服，勞動服

fatigue.eng_def: work such as cleaning or cooking, done by soldiers, often as punishment
fatigue.chi_def: （打掃、幫廚等）士兵雜役（常作為懲罰）
fatigue.eg: Get dressed right now or you'll find yourself on fatigues.

faucet.eng_def: a device that controls the flow of liquid, especially water, from a pipe

fault.eng_def: a mistake, especially something for which you are to blame
fault.eg: It's not my fault she didn't come!

fault.eng_def: a weakness in a person's character
fault.eg: He has many faults, but dishonesty isn't one of them.

fault.eng_def: a broken part or weakness in a machine or system
fault.chi_def: （機器或系統的）毛病，故障，缺陷
fault.eg: The car has a serious design fault.

fault.eng_def: (in tennis and some other games) a mistake made by a player who is beginning a game by hitting the ball

fault.eg: Her doctor was at fault for/in not sending her straight to a specialist.

fault.eng_def: to criticize someone or something, especially without good reasons
fault.eg: He's always finding fault with my work.

fault.eng_def: a crack in the earth's surface where the rock has divided into two parts that move against each other
fault.eg: Surveyors say the fault line is capable of generating a major earthquake once in a hundred years.

fault.eng_def: to find a reason to criticize someone or something
fault.eg: I can't fault the way they dealt with the complaint.

fault.eng_def: to hit a fault in tennis and other similar games
fault.eg: That's the fourth serve he's faulted on today.

fax.eng_def: (a copy of) a document that travels in electronic form along a phone line and is then printed on paper
fax.chi_def: 傳真件，傳真電文，傳真信件
fax.eg: I'll send you a fax with the details of the proposal.

fax.eng_def: a device or system used to send and receive documents in electronic form along a phone line
fax.eg: I'll send you the agenda by fax.

fax.eng_def: to send a document using a fax machine

fear.eng_def: an unpleasant emotion or thought that you have when you are frightened or worried by something dangerous, painful, or bad that is happening or might happen
fear.eg: Trembling with fear, she handed over the money to the gunman.

fear.eng_def: to be frightened that you might be killed
fear.eg: Lakisha sat inside, in fear of her life, until the police came.

fear.eng_def: to be no possibility that a particular thing will happen
fear.eg: Greta knows the city well, so there's no fear of us getting lost (= we will not get lost).

fear.eng_def: because you are worried that a particular thing might happen
fear.eg: They wouldn't let their cat outside for fear (that) it would get run over.

fear.eng_def: to be frightened of something or someone unpleasant
to be worried or frightened that something bad might happen or might have happened
fear.eg: Police fear (that) the couple may have drowned.

fear.eng_def: used to give someone news of something bad that has happened or might happen

fearful.eg: He hesitated before calling her, fearful of what she might say.

feasible.eng_def: able to be made, done, or achieved
feasible.chi_def: 可行的；行得通的；做得到的
feasible.eg: With the extra resources, the project now seems feasible.

feast.eng_def: a special meal with very good food or a large meal for many people
feast.eg: "What a feast!" she said, surveying all the dishes on the table.

feast.eng_def: something that is very enjoyable to see, hear, experience, etc.
a collection of something to be enjoyed
feast.eg: The team contains a veritable feast of international talent.

feast.eng_def: a day on which a religious event or person is remembered and celebrated
feast.eg: the Feast of St James/the Passover

feather.eng_def: one of the many soft, light things that cover a bird's body, consisting of a long, thin, central part with material like hairs along each side
to turn oars (= poles with flat ends used to move a boat) so that the flat parts are horizontal above the water while you prepare for the next pull

feature.eng_def: a typical quality or an important part of something
feature.eg: The town's main features are its beautiful mosque and ancient marketplace.

feature.eng_def: a part of a building or of an area of land
one of the parts of someone's face that you notice when you look at them
a special article in a newspaper or magazine, or a part of a television or radio broadcast, that deals with a particular subject
feature.chi_def: （報紙或雜誌的）特寫；（電視或廣播的）專題節目
feature.eg: a double-page feature on global warming

feature.eng_def: a film that is usually 90 or more minutes long
to include someone or something as an important part
feature.chi_def: 以…為特色；給…以顯著的地位
feature.eg: The movie features James Dean as a disaffected teenager.

federal.eng_def: relating to the central government, and not to the government of a region, of some countries such as the US
A federal system of government consists of a group of regions that are controlled by a central government.

federation.eng_def: a group of organizations, countries, regions, etc. that have joined together to form a larger organization or government
the act of forming a federation
federation.eg: The federation of the six original Australian states took place in 1901.

fee.eng_def: an amount of money paid for a particular piece of work or for a particular right or service

feeble.eng_def: weak and without energy, strength, or power
feeble.eg: He was a feeble, helpless old man.

feed.eng_def: to give food to a person, group, or animal
feed.chi_def: 給（人、團體或動物）提供食物；餵養
feed.eg: I usually feed the neighbour's cat while she's away.

feed.eng_def: If a baby or animal feeds, it eats or drinks milk.
feed.eg: The baby only feeds once a night at the moment, thank goodness.

feed.eng_def: to be enough food for a group of people or animals
feed.eg: This amount of pasta won't feed ten people.

feed.eng_def: to produce or supply enough food for someone or something
feed.eg: If agriculture was more of a priority, the country would easily be able to feed itself.

feed.eng_def: to give a plant substances that will help it grow
feed.eg: Don't forget to feed the tomatoes.

feed.eng_def: to supply something to a person or thing, or put something into a machine or system, especially in a regular or continuous way
feed.chi_def: 供給；供應；（尤指規律地或連續地）把…放進（機器或系統）
feed.eg: The vegetables are fed into the machine at this end.

feed.eng_def: to put fuel on or inside something that burns, to keep it burning
feed.eg: Remember to feed the fire while I'm out.

feed.eng_def: an occasion when a baby has something to eat or drink
feed.eg: The baby had a feed an hour ago, so she can't be hungry.

feed.eng_def: food eaten by animals that are not kept as pets
the part of a machine through which it is supplied with fuel or with something else that it needs

feedback.eng_def: information or statements of opinion about something, such as a new product, that can tell you if it is successful or liked
feedback.eg: Have you had any feedback from customers about the new soap?

feedback.eng_def: the sudden, high, unpleasant noise sometimes produced by an amplifier when sound it produces is put back into it
feedback.eg: Jimi Hendrix loved to fling his guitar around to get weird and wonderful sounds from the feedback.

feedback.eng_def: the return back into a machine or system of part of what it produces, especially to improve what is produced
feedback.chi_def: 回饋（到機器或產出系統，以改良產品）
feedback.eg: Feedback from the sensors ensures that the car engine runs smoothly.

feel.eng_def: to experience something physical or emotional
feel.eg: "How are you feeling?" "Not too bad, but I've still got a slight headache."

feel.eng_def: to have a wish for something, or to want to do something, at a particular moment
feel.eg: I feel like (going for) a swim.

feel.eng_def: to want to do something that you do not do
feel.eg: He was so rude I felt like slapping his face.

feel.eng_def: to get cold quicker and more often than most people
feel.eg: As you get older, you tend to feel the cold more.
"Did it hurt?" "Not at all - I didn't feel a thing."

feel.eng_def: to have a particular opinion about or attitude towards something
feel.eg: I feel (that) I should be doing more to help her.

feel.eng_def: to touch something in order to discover something about it
feel.eg: Just feel how cold my hands are!
She loved the feel of silk against her skin.
Is that shirt silk? Ooh, let me have a feel!

feel.eng_def: the character of a place or situation
feel.chi_def: （場所或情況給人的）感受，氣氛；特質
feel.eg: I like the decoration - it's got a Spanish feel to it.

feel.eng_def: a natural understanding or ability, especially in a subject or activity
feel.chi_def: （尤指在某學科或活動方面的）理解力，領悟力
feel.eg: She has a real feel for language.

feel.eng_def: to learn how to do something, usually a new activity
feel.eg: Once you get the feel of it, using a mouse is easy.

feeling.eng_def: the fact of feeling something physical
feeling.eg: I had a tingling feeling in my fingers.
The feeling of loneliness suddenly overwhelmed him.

feeling.eng_def: emotions, especially those influenced by other people
feeling.chi_def: （尤指受他人影響而產生的）情感，感情
feeling.eg: Some people say that dogs have feelings.
My feeling is that we had better act quickly or it will be too late.

feelings.eng_def: the fact of feeling something physical
feelings.eg: I had a tingling feeling in my fingers.
The feeling of loneliness suddenly overwhelmed him.

feelings.eng_def: emotions, especially those influenced by other people
feelings.chi_def: （尤指受他人影響而產生的）情感，感情
feelings.eg: Some people say that dogs have feelings.
My feeling is that we had better act quickly or it will be too late.

fellow.eng_def: used to refer to someone who has the same job or interests as you, or is in the same situation as you
fellow.chi_def: 同事的；同伴的；同情況的
fellow.eg: She introduced me to some of her fellow students.

fellow.eng_def: a man, used especially in the past by people in a higher social class
fellow.chi_def: 人，男人，傢夥（尤為舊時社會階層較高的人使用）
fellow.eg: He seemed like a decent fellow.

fellow.eng_def: a member of a group of teachers of high rank at a particular college or university or of particular academic societies
fellow.chi_def: （學院或大學的）研究員；（學術協會的）會員
fellow.eg: Georgia's a fellow of Clare College, Cambridge.

fellow.eng_def: a member of an official organization for a particular subject or job
fellow.eg: He's a fellow of the Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors.

fellow.eng_def: a graduate student who has a fellowship at a university

female.eng_def: belonging or relating to women, or the sex that can give birth to young or produce eggs
female.chi_def: 女性的；婦女的；雌的；母的
female.eg: She was voted the best female vocalist.

female.eng_def: Female plants produce flowers that will later develop into fruit.
used to refer to a piece of equipment that has a hole or space into which another part can be fitted

female.eg: The kitten was actually a female, not a male.

female.eng_def: used to refer to a woman in a way that shows no respect
female.eg: I suspect the doctor thought I was just another hysterical female.

feminine.eng_def: having characteristics that are traditionally thought to be typical of or suitable for a woman
feminine.chi_def: （舉止或氣質）女性特有的，女性的
feminine.eg: With his long dark eyelashes, he looked almost feminine.

feminine.eng_def: belonging to the group of nouns that, in some languages, are not masculine or neuter
used to refer to a particular form of a noun in English, such as "actress", that refers only to a female person. These feminine forms are now being used less often.
feminine.chi_def: （英語中表示女性的詞）陰性的

fence.eng_def: a structure that divides two areas of land, similar to a wall but made of wood or wire and supported with posts
a person who buys and sells stolen goods
to fight as a sport with a long, thin sword

ferry.eng_def: a boat or ship for taking passengers and often vehicles across an area of water, especially as a regular service
to transport people or goods in a vehicle, especially regularly and often
ferry.eg: I spend most of my time ferrying the children around.

fertile.eng_def: Fertile land can produce a large number of good quality crops.
Fertile animals or plants are able to produce (a lot of) young or fruit.
fertile.chi_def: （動物或植物）可繁殖的，能生育的，能結果的
fertile.eg: People get less fertile as they get older.

fertile.eng_def: A fertile seed or egg is able to develop into a new plant or animal.
A fertile mind or imagination is active and produces a lot of interesting and unusual ideas.
fertile.chi_def: 想像力豐富的；點子多的

fertility.eng_def: (of animals and plants) the quality of being able to produce young or fruit
(of land) the quality of producing a large number of good quality crops
(of the mind or imagination) the quality of producing a lot of unusual and interesting ideas

fertilizer.eng_def: a natural or chemical substance that is spread on the land or given to plants, to make plants grow well

festival.eng_def: a special day or period, usually in memory of a religious event, with its own social activities, food, or ceremonies
an organized set of special events, such as musical performances

fetch.eng_def: to go to another place to get something or someone and bring it, him, or her back
fetch.eg: Could you fetch me my glasses/fetch my glasses for me from the other room, please?

fetch.eng_def: to be sold for a particular amount of money
fetch.eg: The paintings fetched over a million dollars.

fetch.eng_def: to hit someone with the hand
fetch.eg: I fetched him a smart blow on the ear!

fetch.eng_def: to play a game with a dog that involves throwing something for it to run after and bring back to you

fever.eng_def: a medical condition in which the body temperature is higher than usual and the heart beats very fast
fever.eg: He's got a headache and a slight fever.
The whole country seems to be in the grip of football fever.

few.eng_def: some, or a small number of something
few.eg: I need to get a few things in town.

few.eng_def: used in expressions such as "quite a few" to mean "quite a large number"
few.chi_def: （用於 quite a few, a good few 等表達方式中）許多，很多，大量
few.eg: I know quite a few people who have had the same problem.

few.eng_def: a small number or not many
few.eg: It was embarrassing how few people attended the party.
Fewer people smoke these days than used to.

few.eng_def: not happening or existing very often
few.eg: Apartments that are both comfortable and reasonably priced are few and far between.

fiancé.eng_def: the man who someone is engaged to be married to

fiancée.eng_def: the woman who someone is engaged to be married to

fiction.eng_def: the type of book or story that is written about imaginary characters and events and not based on real people and facts
fiction.eg: The book is a work of fiction and not intended as a historical account.

fiction.eng_def: a false report or statement that you pretend is true
fiction.eg: At work she kept up the fiction that she had a university degree.

fiddle.eng_def: to act dishonestly in order to get something for yourself, or to change something dishonestly, especially to your advantage
fiddle.chi_def: （尤指為個人利益而）用詭計獲得；篡改，偽造
fiddle.eg: She managed to fiddle a free trip to America.

fiddle.eng_def: to move things about or touch things with no particular purpose
fiddle.eg: Put your papers down and stop fiddling with them!

fiddle.eng_def: something difficult to do, especially because the things involved are small or need careful use of the fingers
fiddle.eg: I find threading a needle a terrible fiddle.

fiddle.eng_def: something dishonest that someone does in order to get money or other advantages
fiddle.chi_def: （為獲得金錢或其他利益而做的）不誠實行為

fidelity.eng_def: honest or lasting support, or loyalty, especially to a sexual partner
fidelity.chi_def: （尤指對性伴侶的）忠誠，忠實，忠貞
fidelity.eg: Somerset Maugham's comedy of marital fidelity, "The Constant Wife"

fidelity.eng_def: the degree to which the detail and quality of an original, such as a picture, sound, or story, is copied exactly
fidelity.eg: The best ink-jet printers can reproduce photographs with amazing fidelity.

field.eng_def: an area of land, used for growing crops or keeping animals, usually surrounded by a fence
field.eg: We drove past fields of ripening wheat.

field.eng_def: a place where you are working or studying in real situations, rather than from an office, laboratory, etc.
field.eg: I spoke to an aid worker who had recently returned from the field.

field.eng_def: an area, usually covered with grass, used for playing sports
to go onto the field at the start of a game
field.eg: There were loud cheers as the Irish team took the field.

field.eng_def: an area of activity or interest
to be something you do not know much about
field.eg: Programming really isn't my field - you'd better ask Phil.

field.eng_def: all the competitors taking part in a race or activity
field.chi_def: （參加比賽或活動的）全體運動員，全體人員
field.eg: The race started with a field of eleven, but two horses fell.

field.eng_def: a division of a database (= a collection of similar information on a computer) that contains a particular type of information, such as names or numbers
to catch or pick up the ball after it has been hit in a game such as cricket or baseball, and to try to prevent the other team from scoring
field.chi_def: （板球或棒球運動中）接（球），截（球）；守（球），作守方

field.eng_def: to avoid answering a question directly
field.eg: He fielded some awkward questions very skilfully.

field.eng_def: to have or produce a team of people to take part in an activity or event
field.chi_def: 使參加活動（或比賽）；組織參加
field.eg: The company fielded a group of experts to take part in the conference.

field.eng_def: an area of land containing a particular natural substance
field.chi_def: （有某種天然物質的）大片地方，…田

fierce.eg: Fierce winds prevented the race from taking place.

fierce.eng_def: showing strong feeling or energetic activity
fierce.eg: The expansion plans will face fierce opposition/resistance from environmentalists.

fifteen.eg: They live about fifteen miles away.

fight.eng_def: to use physical force to try to defeat another person or group of people
fight.eg: There were children fighting in the playground.

fight.eng_def: to use a lot of effort to defeat or achieve something, or to stop something happening
fight.chi_def: 努力擊敗（或爭取）；（與…）作鬥爭
fight.eg: He fought the disease bravely for three years.
I wish they wouldn't fight in front of the kids.

fight.eng_def: an argument or an occasion when someone uses physical force to try to defeat someone
a situation in which you use a lot of effort to defeat someone or achieve something, or to stop something happening
fight.eg: We must continue the fight against homelessness.

fight.eng_def: the wish or ability to fight or act energetically
fight.eg: The team came out on the field full of fight.

fighter.eg: She's a fighter (= she tries hard and will not easily give up).

fighter.eng_def: a small, fast military aircraft used for chasing and destroying enemy aircraft

figure.eng_def: the symbol for a number or an amount expressed in numbers
figure.eg: Can you read this figure? Is it a three or an eight?
The unemployment rate is now in double figures.

figure.eng_def: the shape of the human body, or a person
figure.eg: I could see two tall figures in the distance.

figure.eng_def: a painting, drawing, or model of a person
figure.eg: There are several reclining figures in the painting.

figure.eng_def: a picture or drawing, often with a number, in a book or other document
figure.chi_def: （書或文件中常帶有編號的）圖，表

figure.eng_def: to expect or think that something will happen
figure.eg: We figured (that) you'd want to rest after your trip.

figure.eng_def: to be, appear, take part, or be included in something
figure.eg: Their names did not figure in the list of finalists.

file.eng_def: any of several different types of container used to store papers, letters, and other documents in an ordered way, especially in an office
file.chi_def: （尤指辦公室的）文件箱，文件夾，卷宗

file.eng_def: written records that are kept about a particular person or subject
file.eg: The police have opened a file on local burglaries.

file.eng_def: information stored on a computer as one unit with one name
a long line of people or animals, one behind another
file.eg: They were horrified to see files of ants marching through the kitchen.

file.eng_def: a thin, flat or rounded metal tool with rough surfaces for rubbing wooden or metal objects to make them smooth or to change their shape
to store information in a careful and particular way
file.eg: We file these reports (= put them in a file) under country of origin.

file.eng_def: to officially record something, especially in a law court
file.eg: The police filed charges against the two suspects.

file.eng_def: News reporters file a story by sending it to their office, usually by phone, email, or other electronic method.
file.eg: Our foreign correspondent filed this report earlier today.

file.eng_def: to walk in a line, one behind another
file.eg: The visitors filed through the entrance to the ticket offices.

file.eng_def: to use a file in order to make an object smooth or to change its shape

fill.eng_def: to make or become full; to use empty space
fill.chi_def: （使）充滿，（使）裝滿，（使）注滿；佔據；布滿
fill.eg: I filled the bucket with water.

fill.eng_def: to put a substance into an empty space
fill.eg: Before painting, fill (in) all the cracks in the plaster.

fill.eng_def: to make someone have a particular feeling
fill.eg: The thought of it fills me with (= makes me feel) dread.

fill.eng_def: to put a substance into a hole in a tooth to repair it
fill.eg: You should get that cavity filled.

fill.eng_def: to give a job or position to someone
fill.eg: I'm sorry, the job/post/vacancy has already been filled.

fill.eng_def: someone's fill is as much as they want or can deal with
fill.eg: He took only a few minutes to eat/drink his fill.

film.eng_def: a series of moving pictures, usually shown in a cinema or on television and often telling a story
(a length of) dark plastic-like material that can record images as photographs or as a moving picture
a thin layer of something on a surface
to record moving pictures with a camera, usually to make a film for television or the cinema
film.eg: Most of the scenes were filmed in a studio.

filter.eng_def: any of several types of equipment or devices for removing solids from liquids or gases, or for removing particular types of light
a green, arrow-shaped light that is part of a set of traffic lights and tells drivers when they can turn left or right
filter.chi_def: （表示可左轉或右轉的）交通分流指示燈

filter.eng_def: to appear or happen gradually or to a limited degree
filter.eg: News filtered down to us during the day.

filter.eng_def: to remove solids from liquids or gases, or to remove particular types of light, using special equipment
filter.eg: The water is filtered to remove any impurities.

fin.eng_def: a thin vertical part sticking out of the body of especially a fish or an aircraft that helps balance and movement
fin.eg: We could see the fin of a shark as it slowly circled our boat.

fin.eng_def: a hairstyle, usually worn by men, where the hair is combed from the sides towards the centre so that it sticks up like a fin on top of the head
fin.chi_def: 魚鰭頭（男性的一種髮型，頭髮從兩邊往中間梳，在頭頂如魚鰭般高高凸起）

final.eng_def: used when you are talking about what is most important or true in a situation
final.eg: In the final analysis, it is the drug companies that are going to profit from this policy.

final.eng_def: used to show that you are certain you will not change your decision about something
final.chi_def: （表示決定不會更改）就這麼決定了
final.eg: I'm not coming and that's final.

final.eng_def: the last in a series of games, races, or competitions, usually the one in which the winner is chosen
final.eg: Last year we got through to the final.

final.eng_def: the last set of games in a competition
final.eg: Do you think she will make it to the finals this year in the US Open?

final.eng_def: the exams taken at the end of a university or college course
final.chi_def: （大學或學院的）畢業考試；結業試
final.eg: I'm taking my finals in June.

final.eng_def: a test taken on a subject at the end of a school year or college course
final.chi_def: （中小學或大學的）期終考試；課程結業考試
final.eg: The final exam for this class will be on 21 May.

finance.eng_def: (the management of) a supply of money
finance.chi_def: 資金；財務管理；財政；金融

finance.eng_def: the money that a person or company has
finance.eg: We keep a tight control on the organization's finances.

finance.eng_def: to provide the money needed for something to happen
finance.eg: The city council has refused to finance the project.

financial.eng_def: relating to money or how money is managed

find.eng_def: to discover, especially where a thing or person is, either unexpectedly or by searching, or to discover where to get or how to achieve something
find.chi_def: （偶然）發現，碰上；找到，尋得；找出，查明
find.eg: I've just found a ten-pound note in my pocket.

find.eng_def: to realize that something exists or has happened
find.eg: We came home to find (that) the cat had had kittens.

find.eng_def: to exist or be present somewhere
find.eg: Many plant and animal species are found only in the rainforests.

find.eng_def: to get somewhere you are trying to reach
find.eg: I had a map but I still couldn't find my way back to the hotel.
She's always finding fault with the way he works.

find.eng_def: to realize that you are in a particular situation or place, or doing a particular thing, when you did not intend to
find.chi_def: （不知不覺地）發現自己處於…中（或在…處，做…事）
find.eg: He'll find himself with no friends at all if he carries on behaving this way.

find.eng_def: If you go somewhere or do something to find yourself, you go there or do it to discover your true character.
find.eg: Simon spent a year in an ashram in India to find himself.

find.eng_def: to think or feel a particular way about someone or something
find.eg: Do you find John difficult to talk to?

find.eng_def: to make a judgment in a law court
find.eg: In a unanimous verdict, the jury found him guilty/not guilty of the murder.

find.eng_def: a good or valuable thing or a special person that has been discovered but was not known about before
find.chi_def: 發現物；被發現的人（尤指有價值或有用者）
find.eg: This café's quite a find - I had no idea there was anywhere like it around here.

fine.eng_def: good or good enough; healthy and well
fine.chi_def: 好的；夠好的；健康的，身體好的
fine.eg: I felt terrible last night but I feel fine this morning.

fine.eng_def: excellent or much better than average
fine.eg: purveyors of fine wines and gourmet food

fine.eng_def: very thin or in very small pieces or drops
fine.eg: The baby's head was covered in fine blond hair.

fine.eng_def: very exact and delicate, or needing to be done, treated, or considered very carefully
fine.eg: I understood in general what she was talking about, but some of the finer details/points were beyond me.
The forecast said it would be fine and dry today.
That's a fine (= very unpleasant) thing to say about your father after all he's done for you!

fine.eng_def: an amount of money that has to be paid as a punishment for not obeying a rule or law
fine.eg: The maximum penalty for the offence is a $1,000 fine.

fine.eng_def: to charge someone an amount of money as a punishment for not obeying a rule or law
fine.eg: Drivers who exceed the speed limit can expect to be fined heavily.
"Will a loan of $500 be sufficient?" "That will suit me fine."

finger.eng_def: any of the long, thin, separate parts of the hand, especially those that are not thumbs
finger.eg: He noticed her long delicate fingers.

finger.eng_def: a part of a glove (= hand covering) that covers a finger
to touch or feel something with your fingers
finger.eg: She fingered her necklace absent-mindedly as she talked.

finger.eng_def: If you finger someone, you tell the police that they are guilty of a crime.

finish.eng_def: to complete something or come to the end of an activity
finish.eg: I'll call you when I've finished my homework.
The meeting should finish around four o'clock.

finish.eng_def: to eat, drink, or use something completely so that none remains
finish.eg: Make sure she finishes her dinner.

finish.eng_def: If you finish something made of wood, you give it a last covering of paint, polish, or varnish so that it is ready to be used.
finish.chi_def: 給（木製器具）上最後一道漆；給…最後拋光

finish.eng_def: the end of a race, or the last part of something
finish.chi_def: （比賽的）結果，結束；（某事的）最後階段（或部分）

finish.eng_def: the condition of the surface of a material such as wood
finish.eg: Look at the beautiful shiny finish on that piano.

finish.eng_def: the last covering of varnish, polish, or paint, that is put onto something
finish.eg: Even a clear finish will alter the colour of wood slightly.

finite.chi_def: 有限的；有限制的；有盡的
finite.eg: The funds available for the health service are finite and we cannot afford to waste money.

finite.eng_def: in a form that shows the tense and subject of a verb, rather than the infinitive form or a participle
finite.eg: In the following sentence "go" is finite: "I often go to the cinema."

fire.eng_def: (material that is in) the state of burning that produces flames that send out heat and light, and might produce smoke
fire.eg: Animals are usually afraid of fire.

fire.eng_def: a small controlled fire that is used for heating or cooking
fire.eg: It's very cold in here - should I light a fire?

fire.eng_def: If something is on fire, it is burning when it should not be.
fire.eg: If your home was on fire and you could save only one thing, what would it be?

fire.eng_def: a gas or electric heater that is used to warm up a room
the shooting of guns or other weapons
fire.eg: The police opened fire on (= started shooting at) the protesters.

fire.chi_def: 極度興奮；極為激動；狂熱
fire.eg: The fire in her speech inspired everyone.

fire.eng_def: to cause a weapon to shoot bullets, arrows, or missiles
fire.chi_def: 開火，開（槍）；放（箭）；發射（導彈）
fire.eg: He fired his gun into the air.

fire.eng_def: to direct a series of questions or criticisms at someone
fire.chi_def: 連珠炮似地提出（問題）；猛烈地作出（抨擊）
fire.eg: The journalists were firing questions at me for two whole hours.

fire.eng_def: to remove someone from their job, either because they have done something wrong or badly, or as a way of saving the cost of employing them
fire.eg: She was fired after she was caught stealing from her employer.

fire.eng_def: to cause a strong emotion in someone
fire.eg: I had a brilliant English teacher who fired me with enthusiasm for literature at an early age.

fire.eng_def: to heat objects made of clay in a kiln (= a special oven) so that they become hard

firecracker.eng_def: a firework that makes a loud noise when it explodes

fireman.eng_def: a man whose job is to stop unwanted fires from burning

fireplace.eng_def: a space in the wall of a room for a fire to burn in, or the decorated part that surrounds this space
fireplace.eg: She swept the ashes from the fireplace.

fireproof.eng_def: unable to be damaged by fire
fireproof.eg: She keeps all her important papers in a fireproof safe.

firework.eng_def: a small container filled with explosive chemicals that produce bright coloured patterns or loud noises when they explode

firework.eg: He suggested he lose some weight and that's when the fireworks started!

firm.eng_def: not soft but not completely hard
firm.eg: I'd rather sleep on a firm mattress than a soft one.

firm.eng_def: well fixed in place or position
firm.eg: The bridge provided a firm platform for the bungee jumpers.

firm.eng_def: fixed at the same level or opinion and not changing
firm.eg: The government remains firm in its opposition to tax reform.

firm.chi_def: 強而有力的；緊緊的，牢牢的

firm.eng_def: certain and not likely to change
firm.eg: He is a firm believer in traditional family values.

firm.eng_def: forceful and making people do what you want
firm.eg: I was always very firm with my children - they knew the rules and I made sure they followed them.
He works for a law firm called Neil and Vigliano.

firm.eng_def: to make soil harder by pressing on it
firm.eg: Firm the soil around the cuttings and water them in.

firm.eng_def: to stop changing or to remain at the same level, amount, etc.
firm.eg: After a turbulent week on the markets, share prices firmed today.

first.eng_def: (a person or thing) coming before all others in order, time, amount, quality, or importance
first.chi_def: 第一（的）；首先；最初；首要（的）
first.eg: This is my first visit to New York.

first.eng_def: in or at the beginning (of a series of events)
first.eg: The trousers shrank when I washed them, but they weren't really big enough in the first place.

first.eng_def: as the first attempt or effort
first.eg: Enquiries about the post should be addressed in the first instance to the personnel manager.

first.eng_def: at the earliest time in the day
first.eg: He said he'd call back first thing tomorrow.

first.eng_def: before all others in order, time, amount, quality, or importance
first.eg: Tom came first in the race.
When did you first meet each other?

first.eng_def: used at the beginning of a list of things you want to say or write
first.chi_def: 首先（用於想說或想寫的一連串事物的開頭）
first.eg: First, I want to thank my parents.

first.eng_def: the first person or thing to do or be something, or the first person or thing mentioned
first.chi_def: 第一個（做某事的）人；頭一件（發生或提及的）事
first.eg: She was one of the first to arrive.
I've opposed the proposal from the very first.

first.eng_def: something that has never happened or been done before
first.chi_def: 從未發生過的事，開創先例的事
first.eg: This new surgical technique is a first for (= has never been done before in) the hospital.

first.eng_def: the best possible undergraduate university degree you can get in the UK and some other countries
first.chi_def: （英國大學學位）最高成績，優等成績
first.eg: She has a first in English from Newcastle University.

first.eng_def: (in a vehicle) the gear used when starting to drive forward or when driving up a steep hill

fish.eng_def: an animal that lives in water, is covered with scales, and breathes by taking water in through its mouth, or the flesh of these animals eaten as food
fish.eg: Several large fish live in the pond.

fish.eng_def: to try to find something, using your fingers to look for it
fish.eg: She fished in her tool box for the right screwdriver.

fish.eng_def: to try to get something, without asking directly
fish.chi_def: 拐彎抹角地引出；間接探聽
fish.eg: The director was fishing for information about our strategy.

fish.eng_def: to catch fish from a river, sea, lake, etc., or to try to do this
If an area of water has been fished out, all or most of the fish in it have been caught.

fisherman.eng_def: someone who catches fish, especially as a job
fisherman.chi_def: 抓魚（或釣魚）的人；（尤指）漁民

fishery.eng_def: an area of water where fish are caught so they can be sold

fist.eng_def: a hand with the fingers and thumb held tightly in

fit.eng_def: to be the right size or shape for someone or something

fit.eg: With her qualifications, she should fit the job perfectly.

fit.eng_def: to provide something and put it in the correct position
fit.eg: All the carpets we sell are fitted free.

fit.eng_def: to have a fit (= sudden attack of uncontrolled movements)
fit.chi_def: 發作（指突然發生的、不能控制的動作）

fit.eng_def: healthy and strong, especially as a result of exercise
suitable for a particular purpose or activity
fit.eg: She's not fit for the level of responsibility she's been given.

fit.eng_def: to not be able to do something because you are upset, ill, drunk, etc.
fit.eg: He's very upset and is in no fit state to drive.

fit.eng_def: Something that is fit for purpose does what it is meant to do.
fit.chi_def: 十分適合用來做某事的；專門用於做某事的

fit.eng_def: to consider an action or decision to be correct for the situation
fit.chi_def: 認為（行動或決定）恰當（或合適）
fit.eg: Just do whatever you think fit - I'm sure you'll make the right decision.
I met this really fit bloke in a club last night.

fit.eng_def: a sudden attack of illness when someone cannot control their movements and becomes unconscious
a sudden, uncontrolled period of doing something or feeling something

fit.eg: These shoes are a perfect fit.

five.eg: Five, four, three, two, one, blast-off!

fix.eg: They couldn't fix my old computer, so I bought a new one.

fix.eng_def: to arrange or agree a time, place, price, etc.
fix.chi_def: 安排，確定（時間、地點、價格等）
fix.eg: Shall we fix a time for our next meeting?

fix.eng_def: to fasten something in position so that it cannot move
fix.eg: We fixed the bookcase to the wall.

fix.eng_def: to keep something or someone in sight
fix.eg: His eyes were fixed on the distant yacht.

fix.eng_def: to continue to think about or remember something
fix.chi_def: 不斷想（某事）；仍然記得（某事）
fix.eg: It is somehow fixed in my mind that my fate and that woman's are intertwined.

fix.eng_def: to do something dishonest to make certain that a competition, race, or election is won by a particular person
fix.chi_def: 操縱；在（比賽或選舉）中作弊
fix.eg: Several jockeys were arrested on suspicion of fixing the race.

fix.eng_def: to make your hair, make-up, clothes, etc. look tidy
fix.chi_def: 梳洗，整理（頭髮、容妝、衣服等）
fix.eg: Give me a couple of minutes while I fix my hair.

fix.eng_def: to cook or prepare food or drink
fix.eg: Whose turn is it to fix dinner?

fix.eng_def: to punish especially someone who has been unfair
fix.chi_def: 懲罰，收拾（尤指待人不公者）
fix.eg: I'm gonna fix her if she doesn't stop telling lies about me!

fix.eng_def: to treat something, especially photographic material, with chemicals to prevent its colours becoming pale
to remove the reproductive organs of an animal so that it is unable to produce young animals
to inject (= put into the body through a needle) an illegal drug
fix.eg: We saw kids as young as twelve fixing in doorways.

fix.eng_def: a situation in which someone does something dishonest to make certain that a competition, race, or election is won by a particular person
fix.chi_def: 操縱；在（比賽或選舉）中作弊

fix.eg: I'm in a bit of a fix with the arrangements.

fix.eng_def: an amount of an illegal drug, or of another substance that has an effect on someone
fix.eg: He was shaking badly and needed a fix.

fix.eng_def: (the calculation of) the position of a vehicle, usually in relation to the earth
fix.eg: Do we still have a fix on that jet?

flag.eng_def: a piece of cloth, usually rectangular and attached to a pole at one edge, that has a pattern that shows it represents a country or a group, or has a particular meaning
flag.eg: Flags of all the participating countries are flying outside the stadium.

flag.eng_def: a flower that is a type of large iris
to put a mark on something so it can be found easily among other similar things
flag.eg: Flag any files that might be useful later.

flag.eng_def: to mark computer information with one of two possible values so that you can deal with it later
flag.chi_def: 標記（電腦裡某些資料，以便之後處理）
flag.eg: We'll flag the records of interest in the database and then we can give you a print-out.

flag.eng_def: to become tired, weaker, or less effective
flag.eg: I was starting to flag after the ninth mile.

flake.eng_def: a small, thin piece of something, especially if it has come from a surface covered with a layer of something
a person you cannot trust to remember things or to do what they promise, or someone who behaves in a strange way
flake.chi_def: 健忘的人；離譜的的人；古怪的人

flake.eng_def: to come off a surface in small, thin pieces
flake.eg: Patches of skin are starting to flake off.

flame.eng_def: a stream of hot, burning gas from something on fire
flame.eg: The flames grew larger as the fire spread.
Flames of passion swept through both of them.

flame.chi_def: 憤怒（或無禮）的電子郵件

flame.eg: The fire flamed cosily in the hearth.

flame.eng_def: If an emotion flames, you feel it suddenly and strongly.
flame.eg: Seeing the damage made hatred flame within her.

flame.eng_def: to suddenly become hot and red with emotion
to send an angry or insulting email
flame.chi_def: 寄送憤怒（或無禮）的電子郵件
flame.eg: Please don't flame me if you disagree with this message.

flap.eng_def: to wave something, especially wings when or as if flying
flap.chi_def: 振（翅）；撲打翅膀；拍打，擺動
flap.eg: A small bird flapped its wings furiously and flew off.

flap.eng_def: to behave in a nervous and excited way
flap.eg: Don't flap - there's plenty of time to cook before they arrive.

flap.eng_def: a piece of cloth or other material fixed along one edge, especially used for covering or closing something

flap.eg: She's in a flap because her parents are coming to visit.

flap.eng_def: a lot of public anger, excitement, or discussion
flap.chi_def: 公眾的憤怒；大眾的激動情緒；民眾的意見
flap.eg: She claimed to have had an affair with the candidate, which produced a huge media flap.

flap.eng_def: part of the back of an aircraft wing that can be moved up or down to help the aircraft go up or down
the action of a bird waving its wings when flying, or of something else moving in this way
flap.chi_def: 振（翅）；撲打翅膀；拍打，擺動
flap.eg: A few flaps of its long wings and the bird was gone.

flap.eng_def: a consonant sound made when the tongue moves forward and down, and quickly touches the alveolar ridge

flare.eng_def: to burn brightly either for a short time or not regularly
flare.eg: The flame above the oil well flared (up) into the dark sky.

flare.eng_def: When something bad such as violence, pain, or anger flares (up), it suddenly starts or gets much worse.
flare.chi_def: （暴力、疼痛或憤怒）爆發，突發，加劇
flare.eg: Violence flared up again last night.

flare.eng_def: a sudden increase in the brightness of a fire
flare.eg: There was a sudden flare when she threw the petrol onto the fire.

flare.eng_def: a very bright light or coloured smoke that can be used as a signal, or a device that produces this
flare.chi_def: 閃光信號燈；彩色煙霧信號；閃光裝置；照明彈
flare.eg: We set off a flare to help guide our rescuers.

flare.eng_def: trousers that get wider below the knee
the fact of something, especially clothing, becoming wider at one end
flare.chi_def: （衣服）逐漸張開，呈喇叭形展開
flare.eg: This skirt has a definite flare.

flash.eng_def: to shine brightly and suddenly, or to make something shine in this way
flash.eg: Stop flashing that light in my eyes!

flash.eng_def: If someone's eyes flash, they look bright because of the anger or excitement the person is feeling.
flash.chi_def: （眼睛因憤怒或激動而）發亮，閃耀

flash.eg: They flashed past/by on a motorcycle.

flash.eng_def: to show something for a short time
flash.eg: He flashed a smile and offered to buy me a drink.

flash.eng_def: If a man flashes, he shows his sexual organs in public.
flash.eg: He came out of the bushes and flashed me.

flash.eng_def: to communicate something quickly, especially using radio or light waves
flash.chi_def: （尤指用無線電或光波）通信，聯絡
flash.eg: Within moments of an event happening, the news can be flashed around the world.

flash.eng_def: If something flashes through/across your mind, you suddenly or quickly think of it.
flash.eg: The thought suddenly flashed through my mind that she didn't want to be here.

flash.eng_def: a sudden bright light that quickly disappears
a sudden, powerful emotional or mental experience
flash.eg: The idea came to her in a flash of inspiration/genius.

flash.eng_def: the device or system used to produce a bright light for a short time when taking a photograph
flash.eg: Where's the flash for the camera?

flash.eng_def: a small object or piece of material worn on a military uniform as a sign of rank, or (on clothing) a strip or mark of colour different from the main colour
flash.chi_def: （佩於軍服上的）徽章，肩章，臂章；（衣服上的）色條，色塊

flash.eg: She leaned over and I caught a flash of pink underwear.

flash.eng_def: looking expensive in a way that attracts attention
flash.eg: That's a very flash suit he's wearing.

flashlight.eng_def: a small light that is held in the hand and usually gets its power from batteries
flashlight.eg: She shone the flashlight into the dark room.

flat.eng_def: level and smooth, with no curved, high, or hollow parts
flat.eg: An ice rink needs to be completely flat.

flat.eng_def: level but having little or no height
flat.eg: flat shoes (= ones without a raised heel)

flat.eng_def: Flat bread is made without yeast, and therefore does not rise.
flat.eg: Pitta and nan are two types of flat bread.

flat.eng_def: a hat that is not rounded on top and has little height
not interesting, or without emotion or excitement
flat.chi_def: 不積極的；不感興趣的；缺乏熱情的
flat.eg: After the excitement of the party, life seems somewhat flat now.

flat.eng_def: with no electrical power left in it
flat.eg: I left my car lights on and now the battery is flat.

flat.eng_def: If a drink is flat, it has stopped being fizzy (= with bubbles).
flat.eg: If you don't put the top back on that bottle of beer, it will go flat.

flat.eng_def: complete or certain, and not likely to change
flat.eg: His request for time off work was met with a flat refusal.

flat.eng_def: If something such as a tyre or ball is flat, it does not contain enough air.
flat.chi_def: （輪胎或球）洩了氣的，撒了氣的
flat.eg: I got a flat tyre (= the air went out of it) after driving over a nail.

flat.eng_def: (especially of an amount of money) fixed and not likely to change
flat.eg: We charge a flat fee/rate of $25 per hour.

flat.eng_def: If profits, sales, etc. are flat, they are not growing or increasing.
flat.eg: Demand for our machinery abroad is increasing, while growth is flat at home.

flat.eng_def: a set of rooms for living in that are part of a larger building and are usually all on one floor
flat.eg: a furnished/unfurnished flat

flat.eng_def: an area of low, level ground, often near water
flat.eg: The salt flats are used for motor racing.

flat.eng_def: the palm and fingers when they are held straight and level
flat.eg: He hit me with the flat of his hand.

flat.eng_def: to be on a level surface, not on a slope or hill
flat.eg: Most of the path is on the flat.

flat.eng_def: a tyre that does not have any or enough air in it
flat.eg: We were late because we had to stop and fix a flat.

flat.eng_def: women's shoes without high heels
flat.eg: I feel more comfortable in flats.

flat.eng_def: (a symbol for) a note that is a semitone lower than a stated note
(in music) lower than a particular note or the correct note
flat.chi_def: （音樂）低於標準音高的，偏低的
flat.eg: The top string on your violin is flat.

flat.eng_def: in a level position, often against another surface
flat.chi_def: （常指貼著另一表面）水平地，平直地
flat.eg: Lay the cloth flat across the table.

flat.eng_def: into a flat shape without height
flat.eg: These patio chairs will fold flat for storage.

flat.eng_def: completely or to the greatest degree possible
flat.eg: She told him flat that she would not go to the show.

flat.eng_def: exactly three minutes, half an hour, etc.
flat.chi_def: 剛好三分鐘／半小時（等等）
flat.eg: We managed to get to the station in five minutes flat.

flat.eng_def: as fast or as hard as possible
flat.eg: My car only does about 60 mph, even when it's going flat out.

flatter.eng_def: to praise someone in order to make them feel attractive or important, sometimes in a way that is not sincere
flatter.eg: I knew he was only flattering me because he wanted to borrow some money.

flatter.eng_def: to believe something good about yourself although it might not be true
flatter.eg: Steve flatters himself that he's an excellent speaker.

flatter.eng_def: to give the appearance of being better than the true situation
flatter.eg: I suspect these statistics flatter to deceive.

flatter.eng_def: to feel very pleased and proud because someone has said good things about you or has made you feel important
flatter.chi_def: 被奉承得高興；感到榮幸
flatter.eg: She was flattered by his attention.

flatter.eng_def: to make someone look more attractive than usual
flatter.eg: That new hairstyle really flatters her.

flaw.eng_def: a fault, mistake, or weakness, especially one that happens while something is being planned or made, or that causes something not to be perfect
flaw.eg: I returned the material because it had a flaw in it.

flaw.eng_def: to cause something to be not perfect
flaw.eg: A tiny mark flawed the otherwise perfect silk shirt.

flea.eng_def: a very small jumping insect that feeds on the blood of animals and humans

flee.eng_def: to escape by running away, especially because of danger or fear
flee.eg: She fled (from) the room in tears.

flee.eng_def: to quickly go to another country in order to escape from something or someone
flee.eg: It is likely that the suspects have fled the country by now.

fleet.eng_def: a group of ships, or all of the ships in a country's navy
fleet.chi_def: 船隊；（一國的）全部艦隊，海軍

fleet.eng_def: a number of buses, aircraft, etc. under the control of one person or organization
fleet.chi_def: （由某人或某機構調度的）車隊，機群
fleet.eg: He owns a fleet of taxis.
She was slight and fleet of foot/fleet-footed.

flesh.eng_def: the soft part of the body of a person or animal that is between the skin and the bones, or the soft inside part of a fruit or vegetable
flesh.chi_def: （人或動物的）肉；果肉；蔬菜的可食部分
flesh.eg: The thorn went deep into the flesh of my hand.

flesh.eng_def: the physical body and not the mind or the soul
flesh.eg: This left him plenty of time to indulge in the pleasures of the flesh (= physical pleasures, such as sex or eating).

flexible.eng_def: able to change or be changed easily according to the situation
flexible.chi_def: 可變動的；靈活的；可變通的
flexible.eg: My schedule is flexible - I could arrange to meet with you any day next week.

flexible.eng_def: able to bend or to be bent easily without breaking
flexible.chi_def: 可彎曲的；柔韌的；有彈性的

flick.eng_def: to move or hit something with a short sudden movement
flick.eg: He carefully flicked the loose hairs from the shoulders of his jacket.
With a flick of its tail, the cat was gone.

flick.eng_def: to quickly look at the pages of a book, magazine, etc.
flick.eg: I've had a flick through their brochure and it looks quite interesting.
What's on at the flicks this week?

flicker.eng_def: to shine with a light that is sometimes bright and sometimes weak
flicker.eg: I felt a cold draft and the candle started to flicker.

flicker.eng_def: to appear for a short time or to make a sudden movement
flicker.chi_def: 閃現，一閃而過；使…突然動一下
flicker.eg: A smile flickered across her face.

flicker.eng_def: a situation in which a light is sometimes bright and sometimes weak
a feeling or expression of an emotion or quality that does not last very long
flicker.chi_def: （感覺或情緒的）閃現，一閃而過
flicker.eg: There was a flicker of hope in his eyes.

flight.eg: I'll never forget my first flight.

flight.eng_def: an aircraft that is making a particular journey
flight.eg: Flight 474 to Buenos Aires is now boarding at Gate 9.

flight.eng_def: an occasion when something flies or moves through the air
a group of birds, aircraft, etc. flying together
(an act or example of) escape, running away, or avoiding something
flight.eg: They lost all their possessions during their flight from the invading army.

flight.eng_def: to defeat someone and force them to run away

flight.eg: The burglars took flight when the alarm sounded.

flight.eng_def: a set of steps or stairs, usually between two floors of a building
flight.chi_def: （通常指兩個樓層間的）一段樓梯，一段臺階
flight.eg: We live up three flights of stairs.

fling.eng_def: to throw something or someone suddenly and with a lot of force
fling.eg: He crumpled up the letter and flung it into the fire.

fling.eng_def: to move or do something quickly and energetically
fling.eg: She flung her arms around his neck.
They were flinging bitter accusations at each other.
The girls are going to the beach for one last fling before the end of summer.

flip.eng_def: If you flip something, you turn it over quickly one or more times, and if something flips, it turns over quickly.
flip.eg: I flipped the book (over) to look at the back cover.

flip.eng_def: to cook something by turning it over several times over heat
flip.eg: I don't want to spend the rest of my life flipping burgers.

flip.eng_def: to buy a house, improve it a little, then sell it quickly for more money
flip.chi_def: 迅速轉售（稍作裝修後的房子）以獲取利潤
flip.eg: I am going to take three weeks' vacation and flip this house.

flip.eng_def: an occasion when something turns over quickly or repeatedly
used when you are slightly annoyed
flip.eg: Oh, flip, I've missed the bus.

float.eng_def: to stay on the surface of a liquid and not sink
to (cause to) move easily through, or along the surface of a liquid, or to (cause to) move easily through air
float.chi_def: （使）漂流；（使）浮動；（使）飄動；（使）飄移
float.eg: We spent a lazy afternoon floating down/along the river.
