ham.eng_def: a person who operates a radio station as a hobby rather than as a job

hamburger.eng_def: a round, flat piece of minced beef, fried and usually eaten between two halves of a bread roll
beef that is cut into very small pieces, used to make hamburgers
hamburger.chi_def: （用於做漢堡包的）碎牛肉，牛肉糜

hammer.eng_def: a tool consisting of a piece of metal with a flat end that is fixed onto the end of a long, thin, usually wooden handle, used for hitting things
a heavy metal ball attached to a chain that is thrown as part of a sports event
the event or sport in which a hammer is thrown as far as possible
hammer.eg: She qualified for the women's hammer final.

hammer.eng_def: the part of a gun that hits another part when you pull the trigger to send out the bullet
one of the parts of a piano that hits the strings to make a sound
to hit something with a hammer
hammer.eg: Can you hold this nail in position while I hammer it into the door?

hammer.eng_def: to hit or kick something with a lot of force
hammer.eg: I was woken up suddenly by the sound of someone hammering on/at the front door.

hammer.eng_def: to defeat someone completely in a game or a fight
hammer.chi_def: （在比賽或戰鬥中）徹底擊敗，擊垮
hammer.eg: We were hammered in both games.

hammer.eng_def: to criticize someone or something strongly
hammer.eg: Her latest film has been hammered by the critics.

hand.eng_def: the part of the body at the end of the arm that is used for holding, moving, touching, and feeling things
hand.eg: All their toys are made by hand.

hand.eng_def: one of the long, thin pieces that point to the numbers on a clock or watch
hand.eg: Does anyone have a watch with a second hand?

hand.eng_def: a (single part of a) game of cards, or the set of cards that a player has in a game
hand.eg: Who wants to play a hand of poker?

hand.eng_def: help with doing something that needs a lot of effort
hand.eg: Would you like a hand carrying those bags?

hand.eng_def: a person who does physical work or is skilled or experienced in something
hand.eg: How many extra hands will we need to help with the harvest?

hand.eng_def: involvement in or influence over an event
hand.eg: It is not thought that terrorists had a hand in the explosion.
So please give a big hand to (= welcome with clapping) your host for the evening, Bill Cronshaw!

hand.eng_def: a unit for measuring the height of a horse up to its shoulder
hand.chi_def: 一手之寬（用來測量馬匹的高度）
hand.eg: One hand equals four inches (= 10.16 centimetres).

hand.eng_def: to put something into someone's hand from your own hand
hand.eg: The waiter smiled politely as he handed me my bill/handed my bill to me.

handful.eng_def: an amount of something that can be held in one hand
handful.eg: He pulled out a handful of coins from his pocket.

handful.eng_def: a small number of people or things
handful.eg: She invited all her friends to her party, but only a handful of them turned up.

handful.eng_def: a person, often a child, who is difficult to control
handful.eg: Her older son is fine but the little one is a bit of a handful.

handicap.eng_def: a condition in which part of your body or mind has been permanently damaged or does not work normally. This word is now considered offensive by many people, who prefer the word disability.
something that makes it difficult for you to do something
handicap.eg: I found that not having a car was quite a handicap while on holiday.

handicap.eng_def: a disadvantage given to a person taking part in a game or competition in order to reduce their chances of winning, or a sports event in which such disadvantages are given
handicap.chi_def: （讓步賽中對強者施加的）不利條件；讓步賽，讓分比賽
handicap.eg: Handicaps give people with different abilities an equal chance of winning.

handicap.eng_def: to make something more difficult to do
handicap.eg: Rescue efforts have been handicapped by rough seas and hurricane-force winds.

handicraft.eng_def: a skilled activity in which something is made in a traditional way with the hands rather than being produced by machines in a factory, or an object made by such an activity

handkerchief.eng_def: a square piece of cloth or paper used for cleaning the nose or drying the eyes when they are wet with tears
handkerchief.eg: She took out her handkerchief and blew her nose loudly.

handle.eng_def: a part of an object designed for holding, moving, or carrying the object easily
a name of a person or place, especially a strange one
handle.eg: That's some handle to go through life with!

handle.eng_def: to deal with, have responsibility for, or be in charge of
handle.eg: I thought he handled the situation very well.

handle.eng_def: to pick something up and touch, hold, or move it with your hands
handle.eg: Always wash your hands before handling food.

handle.eng_def: to operate or control something that could be difficult or dangerous
handle.chi_def: 操作，控制（困難或危險的事物）
handle.eg: Have you ever handled a gun before?

handle.eng_def: If a car handles well, it is easy and pleasant to drive.

handle.eg: We only handle cosmetics that have not been tested on animals.

handsome.eng_def: A handsome man is physically attractive in a traditional, male way.
handsome.eg: Her dream is to be whisked off her feet by a tall, dark, handsome stranger.

handsome.eng_def: A handsome woman is attractive in a strong way.
handsome.eg: a handsome woman in her fifties
They made a handsome profit on their house.

handwriting.eng_def: writing with a pen or pencil
handwriting.eg: We need to ensure that handwriting is properly taught in our primary schools.

handwriting.eng_def: the particular way in which someone forms letters with a pen or pencil

handy.eg: Jonathan's good at putting up wallpaper, but he's not so handy with a paintbrush.

hang.eng_def: to fasten or support something at the top leaving the other parts free to move, or to be held in this way
hang.eg: A heavy gold necklace hung around her neck.

hang.eng_def: If you hang wallpaper, you fix it to the wall.
to kill someone, especially as punishment for a serious crime, by dropping them with a rope tied around their neck, or to die in this way
hang.eg: He was found guilty and hanged later that year.
The falcon seemed to hang in the air for a moment before diving onto its prey.
The branches hung heavy with snow.

hang.eng_def: to learn how to do something, especially if it is not obvious or simple
hang.chi_def: 學會做（尤指不那麽簡單明瞭的事）
hang.eg: "I've never used this program before." "Don't worry - you'll soon get the hang of it."

hang.eng_def: the way something made of cloth looks when it is hanging
hang.eg: That coat fits you so well - the hang is perfect.

hanger.eng_def: a curved piece of wire, wood, or plastic on which clothes are hung while they are being stored

happen.eng_def: (of a situation or an event) to have existence or come into existence
happen.eg: No one knows exactly what happened but several people have been hurt.

happen.eng_def: If something happens to someone or something, it has an effect on him, her, or it.
happen.chi_def: 發生在（某人）身上；作用於…
happen.eg: I don't know what I'd do if anything happened to him (= if he was hurt, became ill, or died).

happen.eng_def: to do or be by chance
happen.eg: They happened to look (= looked by chance) in the right place almost immediately.

happy.eng_def: feeling, showing, or causing pleasure or satisfaction
(used in greetings for special occasions) full of enjoyment and pleasure

happy.eg: We hadn't planned to be in France at the same time as Ann and Charles - it was just a happy coincidence.
It wasn't a happy choice of phrase given the circumstances.

harass.eng_def: to continue to annoy or upset someone over a period of time

harassment.eng_def: behaviour that annoys or upsets someone

harbor.eng_def: an area of water next to the coast, often protected from the sea by a thick wall, where ships and boats can shelter
harbor.eg: Our hotel room overlooked a pretty little fishing harbour.

harbor.eng_def: to think about or feel something, usually over a long period
harbor.eg: He's been harbouring a grudge against her ever since his promotion was refused.

harbor.eng_def: to protect someone or something bad, especially by hiding that person or thing when the police are looking for him, her, or it
harbor.chi_def: 庇護，窩藏，藏匿（罪犯或贓物）

harbor.eng_def: to contain the bacteria, etc. that can cause a disease to spread
harbor.chi_def: 攜帶（細菌等，可導致疾病的傳播）
harbor.eg: Bathroom door handles can harbour germs.

hard.eng_def: not easy to bend, cut, or break
difficult to understand, do, experience, or deal with
hard.eg: There were some really hard questions in the exam.

hard.eng_def: needing or using a lot of physical or mental effort
hard.chi_def: 耗費體力（或腦力）的；辛苦的
hard.eg: Go on - give it a good hard push!
You have to be quite hard to succeed in the property business.

hard.eng_def: to criticize someone severely, or to treat someone unfairly
hard.chi_def: 對（某人）嚴厲批評；對（某人）不公平
hard.eg: Don't be too hard on him - he's new to the job.

hard.eng_def: A hard drink contains a high level of alcohol.
Hard water contains a high level of minerals that prevent soap from cleaning.
used to describe a time when there is bad weather
hard.eg: We had a very hard winter last year.

hard.eng_def: with a lot of physical or mental effort
hard.eg: Work hard and play hard, that's my motto.

hard.eng_def: If it rains or snows hard, it rains or snows a lot.
hard.eg: It had been raining hard most of the afternoon.

harden.eg: The mixture hardens as it cools.

harden.eng_def: to become more severe, determined, or unpleasant
harden.chi_def: （使）變嚴厲，（使）變堅強，（使）變冷酷
harden.eg: Living in the desert hardened the recruits (= made them more strong and determined).

hardly.eg: I could hardly hear her at the back.
You can hardly expect a pay rise when you've only been working for the company for two weeks!

hardship.eng_def: (something that causes) difficult or unpleasant conditions of life, or an example of this

hardware.eng_def: the physical and electronic parts of a computer, rather than the instructions it follows
metal tools, materials, and equipment used in a house or a garden, such as hammers, nails, and screws
equipment, especially if it is for military use or if it is heavy

hardy.eng_def: strong enough to bear extreme conditions or difficult situations
hardy.eg: A few hardy souls continue to swim in the sea even in the middle of winter.

hardy.eng_def: Hardy plants can live through the winter without protection from the weather.

harm.eng_def: physical or other injury or damage
harm.eg: Both deny conspiring to cause actual bodily harm.

harm.eng_def: to hurt someone or damage something
harm.eg: Thankfully no one was harmed in the accident.

harmful.eg: This group of chemicals is known to be harmful to people with asthma.

harmonica.eng_def: a small, rectangular musical instrument, played by blowing and sucking air through it

harmony.eng_def: a pleasant musical sound made by different notes being played or sung at the same time
a situation in which people are peaceful and agree with each other, or when things seem right or suitable together
harmony.eg: racial harmony (= good feelings between different races)

harness.eng_def: a piece of equipment with straps and belts, used to control or hold in place a person, animal, or object
to put a harness on a horse, or to connect a horse to a vehicle using a harness
to control something, usually in order to use its power
harness.eg: There is a great deal of interest in harnessing wind and waves as new sources of power.

harsh.eng_def: unpleasant, unkind, cruel, or more severe than is necessary
harsh.chi_def: 令人不快的；嚴酷的；（無端地）嚴厲的
刺眼的；刺耳的；過於強烈的

harvest.eng_def: the time of year when crops are cut and collected from the fields, or the activity of cutting and collecting them, or the crops that are cut and collected
harvest.chi_def: 收穫時節；收割，收穫；收成

harvest.eng_def: to pick and collect crops, or to collect plants, animals, or fish to eat
harvest.eg: In the US, winter wheat is harvested in the early summer.

harvest.eng_def: to take cells or other body parts from someone for medical use
harvest.chi_def: 採集（細胞或器官以作醫學用途）
harvest.eg: The donor organ is harvested at the accident scene and rushed to a hospital.

haste.eg: Unfortunately the report was prepared in haste and contained several inaccuracies.

hasten.eng_def: to make something happen sooner or more quickly
hasten.eg: There is little doubt that poor medical treatment hastened her death.

hasten.eng_def: If you hasten to do something, you quickly do it.
hasten.eg: The president hastened to reassure his people that he was in perfect health.

hasten.eng_def: If you hasten to say something, you want to make it clear.
hasten.eg: It was an unfortunate decision and I hasten to say it had nothing to do with me.

hasty.eng_def: Hasty actions are done in a hurry, sometimes without the necessary care or thought.
hasty.eg: He warned against making hasty decisions.

hat.eng_def: a covering for the head that is not part of a piece of clothing
used to refer to one of the various jobs or responsibilities that someone has
hat.eg: For this movie, she is wearing the hats of director and actress.

hatch.eng_def: to (cause an egg to) break in order to allow a young animal to come out
to make a plan, especially a secret plan
hatch.eg: He hatched a plot to forge documents that would embarrass the company.

hatch.eng_def: an opening through a wall, floor, etc., or the cover for it
hatch.chi_def: （牆、地板等上的）開口；活板門；蓋子

hate.eng_def: to dislike someone or something very much

hate.eg: She gave him a look of pure hate.

hateful.chi_def: 令人非常討厭的，可惡的
hateful.eg: I never wear grey because it reminds me of my hateful school uniform.

hatred.eng_def: an extremely strong feeling of dislike
hatred.eg: What is very clear in these letters is Clark's passionate hatred of his father.

haul.eng_def: to pull something heavy slowly and with difficulty
haul.eg: They hauled the boat out of the water.

haul.eng_def: to take something or someone somewhere, especially by force
haul.eg: FBI agents hauled away boxes of records.

haul.eng_def: a usually large amount of something that has been stolen or is illegal
haul.chi_def: （贓物或非法物品的）一大批，大量

haul.eg: Fishermen have been complaining of poor hauls all year.

haul.eng_def: a journey, often a difficult one
haul.eg: From there it was a long haul/only a short haul back to our camp.

haunt.eng_def: to cause repeated suffering or anxiety
haunt.eg: Fighting in Vietnam was an experience that would haunt him for the rest of his life.

haunt.eng_def: (of a ghost) to appear in a place repeatedly
haunt.eg: A ghostly lady is said to haunt the stairway looking for her children.
This bar used to be one of your old haunts, didn't it, Jake?

have.eng_def: used with the past participle of other verbs to form the present perfect and past perfect
have.chi_def: （與動詞的過去分詞連用，構成現在完成式和過去完成式）

have.eng_def: to do one good thing, although you do other bad or silly things
have.eg: At least he had the good sense to turn the gas off.

have.eng_def: If you have a particular illness, you suffer from it.

have.eg: I had prawns and rice for lunch.

have.eng_def: to receive, accept, or allow something to happen
to cause something to happen or someone to do something
have.eg: We're having the house painted next month.

have.eng_def: to suffer something that someone does to you
have.eg: She had her car stolen (= it was stolen) last week.
We're having a wonderful time here in Venice.

have.eng_def: to give birth to a baby
have.eg: Elaine had a baby girl yesterday.
I hear his wife's having a baby.
He asked me how many men I'd had.

have.eng_def: to need to or be forced
have.eg: I have to go to San Francisco tomorrow on business.

have.eng_def: used to say that something must be true
have.eg: That total has to be right - I've checked it twice.

hawk.eng_def: a type of large bird that catches small birds and animals for food
a person who strongly supports the use of force in political relationships rather than discussion or other more peaceful solutions
hawk.chi_def: （主張採取強硬政治路線的）鷹派人物

hawk.eng_def: to sell goods informally in public places
hawk.eg: On every street corner there were traders hawking their wares.

hay.eng_def: grass that is cut and dried and used as animal food

hazard.eng_def: something that is dangerous and likely to cause damage
to risk doing something, especially making a guess, suggestion, etc.
hazard.eg: I wouldn't like to hazard a guess.

hazard.eng_def: to risk doing something that might cause harm to someone or something else
hazard.eg: The policy hazarded the islands and put the lives of the inhabitants at risk.

head.eng_def: the part of the body above the neck where the eyes, nose, mouth, ears, and brain are
head.eg: Put this hat on to keep your head warm.

head.eng_def: a person or animal when considered as a unit
head.eg: Dinner will cost £20 a/per head (= for each person).

head.eng_def: a measure of length or height equal to the size of a head
head.eg: Her horse won by a head.

head.eng_def: the mind and mental abilities
head.eg: You need a clear head to be able to drive safely.

head.eng_def: someone in charge of or leading an organization, group, etc.
head.eg: the head of the History department

head.eng_def: a  headteacher UK
a boy or girl who often represents his or her school on formal occasions
the top part or beginning of something
the larger end of a nail, hammer, etc.
the top part of a plant where a flower or leaves grow
the layer of white bubbles on top of beer after it has been poured
the upper part of a river, where it begins
the top part of a spot when it contains pus (= yellow liquid)
the side of a coin that has a picture of someone's head on it
head.chi_def: 硬幣有人頭像的一面，硬幣正面

head.eng_def: the part of a tape or video recorder (= machine for recording sound or pictures) that touches the tape to record and play music, speech, etc.
the main part of the phrase, to which the other parts are related
to go in a particular direction
head.eg: I was heading out of the room when she called me back.

head.eng_def: to be in charge of a group or organization
head.eg: She heads one of Britain's leading travel firms.

head.eng_def: to be at the front or top of something
head.eg: The royal carriage headed the procession.

head.eng_def: to hit a ball with your head
head.eg: Rooney headed the ball into the back of the net.

head.eng_def: a person with a particular strong interest or addiction
head.eg: a crack-head (= someone who depends on the drug crack)

headline.eng_def: a line of words printed in large letters as the title of a story in a newspaper, or the main points of the news that are broadcast on television or radio
headline.chi_def: （報紙的）標題；（電視或廣播的）內容提要
headline.eg: The news of his death was splashed in headlines across all the newspapers.

headline.eng_def: to have something as a headline or as the main story
headline.chi_def: 以…為標題；以…為主要故事
headline.eg: The story was headlined "Killer dogs on the loose".

headline.eng_def: to be the main performer at an entertainment event
headline.chi_def: （在娛樂活動中）扮演主角，充當主角
headline.eg: The band's headlining appearance at the festival could be their last.

headline.eng_def: a headline amount, number, or rate is the most important one or the one that people notice most
headline.chi_def: （最重要的或人們最關注的）頭條數字
headline.eg: The credit card company will cut its headline rate of interest to 19.9 percent.

headquarters.eng_def: the main offices of an organization such as the army, the police, or a business company
headquarters.eg: The company's headquarters is/are in Amsterdam.

heal.eng_def: to make or become well again, especially after a cut or other injury
If a bad situation or painful emotion heals, it ends or improves, and if something heals it, it makes it end or improve.
heal.chi_def: （使）（壞的情況）好轉；（使）（情感上的傷口）癒合
heal.eg: Peace talks were held to try to heal the growing rift between the two sides.

health.eng_def: the condition of the body and the degree to which it is free from illness, or the state of being well
the condition of something that changes or develops, such as an organization or system
health.chi_def: （組織或系統的）運行狀況，運作狀況
health.eg: the financial health of the business

healthful.eg: A healthful diet includes lots of green vegetables.

healthy.eng_def: showing that you are strong and well
healthy.eg: The walk had given her a healthy glow.

heap.eng_def: an untidy pile or mass of things
to put things into a large, untidy pile
heap.eg: He heaped more food onto his plate.

hear.eng_def: to receive or become conscious of a sound using your ears
to be told information about something
to listen to someone or something with great attention or officially in court
hear.eg: I heard a really interesting programme on the radio this morning.

heart.eng_def: the organ in your chest that sends the blood around your body
heart.eg: He's got a weak/bad heart (= his heart is not healthy).

heart.eng_def: used to refer to a person's character, or the place within a person where feelings or emotions are considered to come from
heart.eg: She has a good heart (= she is a kind person).

heart.eng_def: the central or most important part
heart.eg: The demonstrators will march through the heart of the capital.

heart.eng_def: the firm central part of a vegetable, especially one with a lot of leaves

heart.eg: You're doing really well - don't lose heart now.

heart.eng_def: a shape, consisting of two half circles next to each other at the top and a V shape at the bottom, often coloured pink or red and used to represent love
one of the four suits in playing cards, represented by a red heart shape
a playing card from the suit of hearts
heart.eg: In this game, a heart beats a club.

heart.eng_def: used to say that you like someone or something very much

hearty.eng_def: enthusiastic, energetic, and often loudly expressed
large or (especially of food) in large amounts
hearty.eg: We ate a hearty breakfast before we set off.
She has a hearty dislike of any sort of office work.

heat.eng_def: the quality of being hot or warm, or the temperature of something
the system that keeps a building warm
a less important race or competition in which it is decided who will compete in the final event
An animal that is in heat is in a state of sexual excitement and ready to breed.
to make something hot or warm, or to become hot or warm
heat.eg: A large house like this must be expensive to heat.

heaven.eng_def: in some religions, the place, sometimes imagined to be in the sky, where God or the gods live and where good people are believed to go after they die, so that they can enjoy perfect happiness
a situation that gives you great pleasure
heaven.eg: I just lay in the sun for a week and did nothing - it was heaven.
We stared up at the heavens trying to see the comet.

heavenly.eg: It was a good party and the food was heavenly.

heavy.eng_def: weighing a lot, and needing effort to move or lift
(especially of something unpleasant) of very or especially great force, amount, or degree
heavy.chi_def: （尤指不愉快的事物）劇烈的，大量的
heavy.eg: a heavy blow to the head

heavy.eng_def: sea that is rough with large waves
thick, strong, solid, or strongly made
Heavy soil is thick and difficult to dig or walk through.

heavy.eg: The sun disappeared behind heavy clouds.

heavy.eng_def: Heavy machines or vehicles that are very large and powerful.
used to describe something such as a situation that is dangerous or unpleasant
heavy.eg: Then the police arrived and things got really heavy.

heavy.eng_def: a large strong man employed to protect someone else or to frighten other people
heavy.chi_def: （受僱保護或恐嚇他人的）彪形大漢，身強體壯的打手
heavy.eg: Frank always took a couple of heavies along with him when he went collecting his debts.

hedge.eng_def: a line of bushes or small trees planted very close together, especially along the edge of a garden, field, or road
hedge.chi_def: （尤指花園、田地或馬路邊緣的）樹籬

hedge.eng_def: a way of protecting, controlling, or limiting something
hedge.eg: She'd made some overseas investments as a hedge against rising inflation in this country.

hedge.eng_def: a word or phrase that makes what you say less strong
hedge.chi_def: 讓表述內容的嚴重程度降低的單詞（或片語）

hedge.eg: We've got permission, but it's hedged about/around with strict conditions.

hedge.eng_def: to try to avoid giving an answer or taking any action
hedge.chi_def: 避免答覆，拐彎抹角，迴避
hedge.eg: Stop hedging and tell me what you really think.

heed.eng_def: to pay attention to something, especially advice or a warning
heed.chi_def: 注意，聽從（尤指建議或警告）
heed.eg: The airline has been criticized for failing to heed advice/warnings about lack of safety routines.
The company took no heed of (= did not consider) public opposition to the plans.

heel.eng_def: the rounded back part of the foot
the part of a sock or shoe that covers the heel of the foot
the raised part at the back of a shoe, under your heel
a person who treats other people badly and unfairly
heel.eg: I felt like a real heel when I saw how I'd upset her.

heel.eng_def: the raised part of the palm of your hand nearest the wrist
the end part of something, especially of a loaf of bread, that is usually left after the rest has been eaten or used
heel.chi_def: （某物的）剩餘部分；（尤指）麵包頭

heel.eng_def: to repair the heel of a shoe
In rugby, to heel the ball is to kick it backwards with the heel.
heel.chi_def: （橄欖球運動中）用腳跟往回傳球

heel.eng_def: said to a dog to order it to come and stand close to you or to walk close to your side as you walk

height.eng_def: the distance from the top to the bottom of something, or the quality of being tall
height.eg: The sheer height of New York's skyscrapers is so impressive.

height.eng_def: the particular distance that something is above a surface
height.eg: The bullet entered the body at chest height.

height.eng_def: high places, or the top of hills
height.eg: Don't go up the tower if you're afraid of heights.
He reached the heights of his profession at the age of 35.

height.eng_def: the time when a situation or event is strongest or most full of activity
height.eg: August is the height of the tourist season.

height.eng_def: the time when you are most successful in what you do
height.eg: She was at the height of her career when he first met her.

heighten.eng_def: to increase or make something increase, especially an emotion or effect
heighten.chi_def: （使）（尤指某種情緒或效果）增強，加強
heighten.eg: The strong police presence only heightened the tension among the crowd.

heir.eng_def: a person who will legally receive money, property, or a title from another person, especially an older member of the same family, when that other person dies
heir.eg: The guest of honour was the Romanov heir to the throne of all Russia.

heir.eng_def: someone who now has responsibility for dealing with a problem or situation that existed or was created earlier
heir.chi_def: （負責繼續處理某一問題或局面的）繼承者
heir.eg: The French finance minister is heir to a tradition of central control that goes back to Louis XIV.

heir.eng_def: someone who continues to do the work of someone important who has died, or someone who has the same position as the previous person who held that position
heir.chi_def: （接替某重要位置的）接班人，繼任者

helicopter.eng_def: a type of aircraft without wings, that has one or two sets of large blades that go round very fast on top. It can land and take off vertically and can stay in one place in the air
helicopter.eg: The injured were ferried to hospital by helicopter.

hell.eng_def: an extremely unpleasant or difficult place, situation, or experience
hell.chi_def: 悲慘的境況；苦難的經歷
hell.eg: Work is sheer hell at the moment.

hell.eng_def: in some religions, the place where some people are believed to go after death to be punished for ever for the bad things they have done during their lives
hell.eg: I'll go to Hell for this.

hell.eng_def: to cause a lot of problems for someone and make them very unhappy
hell.chi_def: 給（某人）惹很多麻煩，令（某人）日子不好過
hell.eg: I worked for her for two years and she made my life hell.

hell.eng_def: used to express anger or to add emphasis
hell.eg: Oh hell, I've forgotten my key!

hello.eng_def: used when meeting or greeting someone
hello.chi_def: 喂，你好（用於問候或打招呼）
hello.eg: Hello, Paul. I haven't seen you for ages.

hello.eng_def: something that is said at the beginning of a phone conversation
hello.eg: "Hello, I'd like some information about flights to the US, please."

hello.eng_def: something that is said to attract someone's attention
hello.eg: The front door was open so she walked inside and called out, "Hello! Is there anybody in?"

hello.eng_def: said to someone who has just said or done something stupid, especially something that shows they are not noticing what is happening
hello.chi_def: （表示認為某人言行愚蠢可笑，尤指對正在發生的事不注意）
hello.eg: She asked me if I'd just arrived and I was like "Hello, I've been here for an hour."
Hello, this is very strange - I know that man.

helmet.eng_def: a strong, hard hat that covers and protects the head

help.eng_def: to make it possible or easier for someone to do something, by doing part of the work yourself or by providing advice, money, support, etc.
If something helps a difficult or painful situation, it improves it or makes it easier or less painful.
help.eg: The morphine didn't seem to help (the pain).

help.eng_def: If something or someone helps to do something, that thing or person is one of several reasons for it happening.
help.eg: The drought has helped (to) make this a disastrous year for Somalia.

help.eng_def: If you can't/couldn't help something, such as acting in a particular way or making a particular remark, you are/were not able to control or stop it.
help.eg: It was awful, but I couldn't help laughing.
Can I help you to some more soup?
"Might I have some more bread?" "Please, help yourself!"

help.eng_def: the act of helping another person
help.eg: Do you need any help with those boxes?
Having a satnav would be a help.

help.eng_def: someone who is employed to clean and do other small jobs
a person or the people employed to work in someone's home doing cleaning, cooking, caring for children, etc.
shouted by a person who is asking for someone to come and save them from a dangerous situation

helpful.chi_def: 願意幫忙的；有幫助的，有用的
helpful.eg: She's such a pleasant, helpful child!

hemisphere.eng_def: one of two halves of the earth, especially above or below the equator
one of the two halves of the brain
half of a sphere (= ball shape)
hemisphere.eg: The bush had been pruned into a perfect hemisphere.

hen.eng_def: an adult female chicken, often kept for its eggs
used as a way of talking to a woman or girl, especially a friend
hen.chi_def: （尤用來稱呼自己喜歡的）姑娘
hen.eg: Are you not feeling too good, hen?

hence.eng_def: that is the reason or explanation for
hence.eg: His mother was Italian, hence his name - Luca.
The project will be completed at the end of the decade, two years hence.

herald.eng_def: to be a sign that something important, and often good, is starting to happen, or to make something publicly known, especially by celebrating or praising it
herald.chi_def: 預示…的開始；（尤指透過慶祝或讚揚）宣佈（常指好事）
herald.eg: The president's speech heralds a new era in foreign policy.

herald.eng_def: a sign that something will happen, change, etc.
herald.eg: If this first opera of the season is a herald (= sign) of what is to come, we can expect great things.

herald.eng_def: in the past, a person who carried important messages and made announcements

herb.eng_def: a type of plant whose leaves are used in cooking to give flavour to particular dishes or in making medicine
herb.chi_def: （用作調味品或藥材的）香草，藥草

herd.eng_def: a large group of animals of the same type that live and feed together
a large group of people that is considered together as a group and not separately
herd.eg: Poor Janine - she just follows the herd (= does what all the other people are doing).

herd.eng_def: to make animals move together as a group
herd.eg: An old woman was herding the goats.

herd.eng_def: to make people move somewhere as a group, often against their wishes or with difficulty
herd.chi_def: （常指強迫性地）使集中在一起

here.eng_def: in, at, or to this place
here.eg: I've lived here for about two years.

here.eng_def: used at the beginning of a statement to introduce someone or something
here.chi_def: （用於句首以介紹某人或某物）這
here.eg: Here's Fiona - let me introduce you to her.

here.eng_def: used to show that someone has arrived or that something has started
here.eg: Here they are! We thought you'd never come!

here.eng_def: used to say that someone or something that is near you
here.chi_def: （表示在說話人近旁的人或物）這裡
here.eg: I don't know anything about this, but I'm sure my colleague here can help you.
Shall we break here and have a coffee?

here.eng_def: used when giving something to someone
here.eg: "Could you pass the sugar, please?" "Here you are."

hereafter.eng_def: starting from this time; in the future
hereafter.eg: Elizabeth Gaskell's novel "Ruth" will hereafter be cited within the text as EG.
She had a firm conviction that they would meet again in the hereafter.

heritage.eng_def: features belonging to the culture of a particular society, such as traditions, languages, or buildings, that were created in the past and still have historical importance
heritage.chi_def: 遺產（指流傳下來的具有歷史意義的傳統、語言、建築等）
heritage.eg: These monuments are a vital part of the cultural heritage of South America.

hermit.eng_def: a person who lives alone and apart from the rest of society, especially for religious reasons

hero.eng_def: a person who is admired for having done something very brave or having achieved something great
the main male character in a book or film who is usually good
hero.eg: the hero of her latest novel

hero.eng_def: someone who you admire very much
hero.eg: Humphrey Bogart's my hero - I've seen every one of his movies.

hero.eng_def: a long sandwich filled with cold meat, cheese, salad, etc.
hero.chi_def: （夾有冷切肉、乳酪、沙拉等的）長捲三明治

heroic.eng_def: If you make a heroic attempt or effort to do something, you try very hard to do it.
heroic.eg: Despite Roz's heroic efforts to liven it up, the party was a disaster.

heroin.eg: Heroin is obtained from morphine and is extremely addictive.

heroine.eng_def: a woman who is admired for having done something very brave or having achieved something great
the main female character in a book or film who is usually good
heroine.eg: the heroine of her latest novel

heroine.eng_def: a woman who you admire very much

hesitate.eng_def: to pause before you do or say something, often because you are uncertain or nervous about it
hesitate.eg: She hesitated slightly before answering the detective's question.

hesitation.eng_def: the act of pausing before doing something, especially because you are nervous or not certain
hesitation.chi_def: （由指因緊張或不確定而產生的）猶豫，躊躇
hesitation.eg: After a slight hesitation, she began to speak.

heterosexual.eng_def: a person who is sexually attracted to people of the opposite sex

hi-fi.eng_def: electronic equipment used to play recorded sound, especially music
hi-fi.eg: I've just bought a new hi-fi.

hide.eng_def: to put something or someone in a place where that thing or person cannot be seen or found, or to put yourself somewhere where you cannot be seen or found
hide.eg: She used to hide her diary under her pillow.

hide.eng_def: to prevent something from being seen
hide.eg: He tries to hide his bald spot by sweeping his hair over to one side.
She tried to hide her disappointment at not getting the promotion.

hide.eng_def: If you hide information from someone, you do not allow that person to know it.
hide.eg: I feel sure there's something about her past that she's trying to hide from me.

hide.eng_def: the strong, thick skin of an animal, used for making leather
a place where people can watch wild animals or birds without being noticed by them
hide.chi_def: （可以觀察野獸或鳥類的）隱藏處，躲藏處

high.eng_def: (especially of things that are not living) being a large distance from top to bottom or a long way above the ground, or having the stated distance from top to bottom
high.chi_def: （尤指無生命的東西）高的，有…高的

high.eng_def: greater than the usual level or amount
high.eg: The job demands a high level of concentration.

high.eng_def: containing a large quantity of something
high.eg: I avoid foods that are high in fat.

high.eng_def: very good or very moral standards
high.chi_def: 高標準／高度的道德標準
high.eg: She was a woman of high principles.
High winds caused delays on the ferries.

high.eng_def: having power, an important position, or great influence
near or at the top of the range of sounds
high.eg: I can't reach the high notes.

high.eng_def: (of food) smelling bad and no longer good to eat
high.eg: This meat is rather high - I'm going to throw it out.

high.eng_def: not thinking or behaving normally because of taking drugs
high.eg: He was high on heroin at the time.

high.eng_def: a higher level than has ever been reached previously
high.eg: Interest rates have reached an all-time/record high.

high.eng_def: a period of extreme excitement or happiness when you feel full of energy, often caused by a feeling of success, or by drugs or alcohol or a religious experience
high.chi_def: （因獲得成功帶來的）極度興奮；（毒品、酒精或宗教體驗引起的）快感，極樂

high.eng_def: informal for high school  (when used in the name of a school)
high.chi_def: （用於中學名稱中，high school的非正式說法）
high.eg: I go to Santa Ana High.

high.eng_def: at or to a large distance from the ground
high.eg: You'll have to hit the ball quite high to get it over that net.

highlight.eng_def: to attract attention to or emphasize something important
highlight.eg: The report highlights the need for improved safety.

highlight.eng_def: the best or most exciting, entertaining, or interesting part of something
highlight.eg: Highlights of the match will be shown after the news.

highlight.eng_def: a narrow strip of hair on a person's head that has been made a lighter colour than the surrounding hair

highly.eng_def: very, to a large degree, or at a high level
to admire or say admiring things about someone
highly.chi_def: 對（某人）評價很高／對（某人）高度讚揚
highly.eg: He's very highly thought of within the company.

highly.eng_def: in an important or influential (= having a lot of influence) position
highly.eg: According to one highly placed source, the prime minister had threatened to resign over this issue.

highway.eng_def: a public road, especially an important road that joins cities or towns together
highway.chi_def: 公路（尤指連接城鎮的重要公路）

hijack.eng_def: to take control of an aircraft or other vehicle during a journey, especially using violence
hijack.eg: Two men hijacked a jet travelling to Paris and demanded $125,000.

hijack.eng_def: to take control of or use something that does not belong to you for your own advantage
hijack.chi_def: 把持，控制，使用（本不屬於自己的東西）
hijack.eg: He resents the way his ideas have been hijacked by others in the department.

hijack.eng_def: an occasion when someone uses force to take control of an aircraft or other vehicle
hijack.eg: The hijack ended with the release of all the plane's passengers unharmed.

hike.eng_def: a long walk, especially in the countryside
an increase in the cost of something, especially a large or unwanted increase
hike.chi_def: （價格或費用的大幅）提高，增加
hike.eg: The recent hike in train fares came as a shock to commuters.

hike.eng_def: to go for a long walk in the countryside
to increase the cost of something
hike.chi_def: （價格或費用的大幅）提高，增加

hill.eng_def: an area of land that is higher than the surrounding land
hill.eg: Hills are not as high as mountains.
That hill's far too steep to cycle up.

hill.eng_def: Capitol Hill (= the US legislature or the place where it meets)

hint.eng_def: something that you say or do that shows what you think or want, usually in a way that is not direct
hint.eg: He's dropped (= given) several hints to the boss that he'll quit if he doesn't get a promotion.

hint.eng_def: a piece of advice that helps you to do something
hint.eg: Could you give us a hint about how to do this exercise, please?

hint.eng_def: a very small amount of something
hint.eg: There's just a hint of brandy in the sauce.

hint.eng_def: to say or do something that shows what you think or want, usually in a way that is not direct
hint.eg: Mum's hinted (that) she might pay for my trip to Mexico.

hip.eng_def: the area below the waist and above the legs at either side of the body, or the joint that connects the leg to the upper part of the body
hip.eg: This exercise is designed to trim your hips and stomach.
The bars in the old part of the town are frequented by hip young students.

hip.eng_def: an expression that is called out, often by a group of people at the same time, to express approval of someone
hip.eg: Three cheers for the bride and groom! Hip, hip, hooray!

hippo.eng_def: a very large animal with short legs and thick, dark grey skin that lives near water in Africa

hippopotamus.eng_def: a very large animal with short legs and thick, dark grey skin that lives near water in Africa

hire.eng_def: to pay to use something for a short period
hire.eg: How much would it cost to hire a car for the weekend?

hire.eng_def: to employ someone or pay someone to do a particular job
hire.eg: I was hired by the first company I applied to.

hire.eng_def: an arrangement to use something by paying for it
hire.eg: The price includes flights and car hire.

hire.eng_def: a person to whom a company has recently given a job

hiss.eng_def: to make a noise like a long s sound
to say something in a quiet angry way
a sound like the letter s
hiss.eg: I heard a hiss and a pop as the cork came out of the bottle.

historian.eng_def: someone who writes about or studies history

historic.eng_def: important or likely to be important in history
historic.chi_def: 歷史上著名（或重要）的，有歷史意義的

historic.eng_def: A historic offence is one that was committed by someone in the past but that they were not charged with at the time.
historic.chi_def: 過去的，歷史上的（當時未被指控的犯罪活動）
historic.eg: He pleaded guilty to a charge of rape, as well as five historic sexual offences.

historical.eng_def: connected with studying or representing things from the past
historical.eg: Many important historical documents were destroyed when the library was bombed.

historical.eng_def: used to describe prices, values, etc. in the past
historical.eg: The table compares historical exchange rates for five different currencies.

history.eng_def: (the study of or a record of) past events considered together, especially events of a particular period, country, or subject
history.eg: I studied modern European history at college.

history.eng_def: something that happened or ended a long time ago and is not important now, or a person who is not important now, although they were in the past
history.chi_def: 過去的事，過去的人（現已不再重要）
history.eg: Last year's report is ancient history and totally irrelevant to the current situation.

history.eng_def: something that has been done or experienced by a particular person or thing repeatedly over a long period
history.eg: Her family has a history of heart problems.

hit.eng_def: to move your hand or an object onto the surface of something so that it touches it, usually with force
hit.eg: Teachers are not allowed to hit their pupils.

hit.eng_def: to touch something with sudden force
hit.eg: They were going about 60 kilometres an hour when their car hit the tree.

hit.eng_def: to have an unpleasant or negative effect on a person or thing
hit.eg: Production has been badly hit by the strike.

hit.eng_def: If an idea or thought hits you, you suddenly think of it.
hit.eg: That's when it hit me that my life would never be the same again.

hit.eng_def: to shoot at or bomb a place or person, causing damage or injury
hit.eg: Two schools were hit during the air raid.

hit.eng_def: to arrive at a place or position
hit.eg: If we turn left at the next junction, we should hit the main road after five miles or so.

hit.eng_def: to succeed in reaching or achieving something
hit.eg: Our profits hit an all-time high of $20 million last year.

hit.eng_def: to like someone and become friendly immediately
hit.eg: I didn't really hit it off with his friends.
Three drug dealers were hit in the city over the weekend.

hit.eng_def: a thing or person that is very popular or successful
hit.chi_def: 非常受歡迎的人（或事）；非常成功的人（或事）
hit.eg: The Beatles had a string of number-one hits in the 1960s.

hit.eng_def: a request to use a web page on the internet that is then counted to calculate the number of people looking at the page
hit.chi_def: （對網際網路網頁的）訪問量，點擊數
hit.eg: Our page had 243 hits this week.

hit.eng_def: the act of hitting something or someone, or an occasion when something or someone hits you
hit.eg: She gave him a hit on the head which knocked him flying.

hit.eng_def: in baseball, when the batter (= person trying to hit the ball) safely reaches first base after hitting the ball
an occasion when something that has been thrown, dropped, shot, etc. at a place or object reaches that place or object
hit.eg: The rebel headquarters took a direct hit from a bomb during the attack.
He was the victim of a mafia hit.

hive.eng_def: a structure where bees live, especially a beehive (= container like a box) or the group of bees living there
a condition in which a person's skin develops red raised areas
hive.eg: She broke out in hives after eating strawberries.

hoarse.eng_def: (of a voice or a person) having a rough voice, often because of a sore throat or a cold

hobby.eng_def: an activity that someone does for pleasure when they are not working
hobby.eg: Angela's hobby is restoring vintage motorcycles.

hockey.eng_def: a game played on a sports field between two teams of eleven players who each have a curved stick with which they try to put a small, hard ball into the other team's goal

hold.eng_def: to take and keep something in your hand or arms
hold.eg: Can you hold the bag while I open the door?

hold.eng_def: to support something
hold.eg: Will the rope be strong enough to hold my weight?

hold.eng_def: to press your nose tightly between thumb and finger in order to close it
hold.eg: I have to hold my nose when I jump into water.

hold.eng_def: When two people hold hands, one person holds the other person's hand, especially to show that they love each other.
hold.chi_def: （尤指為了表示兩人相愛）手拉著手
hold.eg: They walked along holding hands.

hold.eng_def: to contain or be able to contain something
hold.eg: This jug holds exactly one pint.

hold.eng_def: If you say that the future holds something, you mean that that thing will happen
hold.eg: Who can tell what the future holds?

hold.eng_def: to have a particular quality
hold.eg: She's very religious, so death holds no fear for her.

hold.eng_def: to have something, especially a position or money, or to control something
hold.eg: He currently holds the position of technical manager.

hold.eng_def: to have a particular position in a competition
hold.chi_def: 在競賽中保持（某個）位置
hold.eg: She holds the world record.

hold.eng_def: to keep something, especially when it might have been lost
hold.eg: I asked the shop to hold the dress for me until this afternoon.

hold.eng_def: to keep someone in a place so that they cannot leave
hold.eg: The police are holding several people in custody (= at the police station) for questioning.

hold.eng_def: to have something such as a meeting or an election
hold.chi_def: 使發生；舉行（尤指會議或選舉）
hold.eg: Could we hold a meeting to discuss this tomorrow afternoon?

hold.eng_def: to cause to stay or continue in the same way as before
hold.eg: Let's hope our good luck holds.

hold.eng_def: to believe an idea or opinion
hold.eg: You sold it to me, so if it breaks I'll hold you responsible (= consider you to blame).

hold.eng_def: to wait, or to stop something temporarily
hold.eg: They've decided to hold all future deliveries until the invoice has been paid.

hold.eng_def: If you ask someone to hold something, you do not want them to include it.
hold.eg: I'd like a ham sandwich on rye, hold the lettuce.

hold.eng_def: the act of holding something or someone, or the way you do this
hold.eg: Keep a tight hold on your tickets.

hold.eng_def: to start holding something or someone
hold.eg: He took hold of one end of the carpet and tugged.

hold.eng_def: in fighting sports, a position in which one person holds another person so that they cannot move
a place to put the hands and feet, especially when climbing
hold.chi_def: （攀爬時的）支撐點，手攀（或腳踩）的地方

hold.eng_def: power or control over something or someone
hold.eg: Their company has a strong hold on/over the computer market.

hold.eng_def: If you are on hold when using the phone, you are waiting to speak to someone.
hold.eg: Mr Briggs is on hold.

hold.eng_def: If an activity is on hold, it has been intentionally delayed.
hold.eg: Everything's on hold again because of the bad weather.

hold.eng_def: the space in a ship or aircraft in which goods are carried

holder.eng_def: a device for putting objects in or for keeping them in place

hole.eng_def: an empty space in an object, usually with an opening to the object's surface, or an opening that goes completely through an object
hole.eg: We dug a hole and planted the tree.

hole.eng_def: in golf, one of the small circular spaces in the ground into which the ball is hit
in golf, one of the usually 18 areas of play
hole.chi_def: （高爾夫球運動中）從球座到球洞的區域

hole.eng_def: a place in the ground where a small animal lives
a small unpleasant place where someone lives
hole.eg: What a hole that house was - I'm so pleased we moved.

hole.eng_def: a mistake or problem in an argument, discussion, plan, etc.
hole.eg: The new proposal has several holes in it.

hole.eng_def: to make a hole in something, especially a ship or boat
hole.eg: A torpedo holed the ship below the water and it quickly sank.

holiday.eng_def: a time when someone does not go to work or school but is free to do what they want, such as travel or relax
an official day when you do not have to go to work or school
the time at the end of December and beginning of January each year that includes Christmas, Hanukkah, and New Year
holiday.chi_def: （十二月底一月初聖誕節、猶太光明節、新年期間的）假期
holiday.eg: We were at home for the holidays.
My parents are holidaying in Spain this year.

hollow.eng_def: having a hole or empty space inside
If you have hollow cheeks or eyes, your cheeks curve in or your eyes look deep in your head because you are old, tired, or ill.
(of situations, feelings, or words) without value, or not true or sincere
hollow.chi_def: （局面、情感或言語）無價值的，空洞的，虛偽的
hollow.eg: It was something of a hollow victory - she won the case but lost all her savings in legal fees.

hollow.eng_def: (of sound) as if made by hitting an empty container
a hole or empty space in something, or a low area in a surface
hollow.eg: The dog found a hollow in the ground to hide in from the wind.
We used to go for long walks in the hollow.

holy.eng_def: related to a religion or a god
used to show that you think something is surprising, shocking, or impressive
holy.eg: Holy cow! How did you get that black eye?

home.eng_def: the house, apartment, etc. where you live, especially with your family
home.eg: The senator has two homes - an apartment in Washington and a house in Colorado.

home.eng_def: a house, apartment, etc. when it is considered as property that you can buy or sell
the type of family you come from
a place where people or animals live and are cared for by people who are not their relations or owners
home.eg: a children's home/an old people's home/a dogs' home

home.eng_def: someone's or something's place of origin, or the place where a person feels they belong
home.eg: I live in London, but my home (= where I was born) is in Greece.

home.eng_def: your own country or your own area
home.eg: She loves France, but she misses home.

home.eng_def: If a sports team are/play at home, they play on their own sports field.
at or to your house or the place where you live
home.eg: Don't worry, I'll be home soon.

home.eng_def: in or to the country or area where you come from
home.eg: We pray all our troops will come home safely.

home.eng_def: relating to the house, flat, etc. where someone lives
done at home, or intended to be used at home
relating to your family or your life at home
home.eg: His home life is affecting his work.

home.eng_def: connected with or done in your own country
home.eg: His books were a success in his home country/market, but failed to find an audience abroad.

home.eng_def: relating to the place where a team is based and plays a lot of its games

homeland.eng_def: the country you were born in
(in the past) one of the areas in South Africa in which black people were separated from whites under the political system of apartheid
homeland.chi_def: （過去南非實行種族隔離制度時劃定的）黑人居住地

homesick.eng_def: unhappy because of being away from home for a long period
homesick.eg: As I read my mother's letter, I began to feel more and more homesick.

hometown.eng_def: the town or city that a person is from, especially the one in which they were born and lived while they were young
hometown.eg: He was born in Miami, but he considers New York his hometown since he's lived there most of his life.

homework.eng_def: work that teachers give their students to do at home
homework.eg: You can't watch TV until you've done your homework.

homosexual.eng_def: a person who is sexually attracted to people of the same sex and not to people of the opposite sex

honest.eng_def: telling the truth or able to be trusted and not likely to steal, cheat, or lie

honey.eng_def: a sweet, sticky, yellow substance made by bees and used as food
a name that you call someone you love or like very much

honeymoon.eng_def: a holiday taken by a couple immediately after their marriage
honeymoon.eg: Where are you going on your honeymoon?

honeymoon.eng_def: a short period at the beginning of a new job, government, etc. when there is no criticism from anyone

honeymoon.eg: They are honeymooning in the Bahamas.

honeymoon.eng_def: people who are on their honeymoon
honeymoon.eg: The hotel is a favourite with honeymooners.

honk.eng_def: If a goose or a car horn honks, it makes a short, loud sound.

honk.eg: He honked (up) all over the floor.

honk.eng_def: a short, loud sound made by a car horn or a goose
honk.chi_def: （短促大聲的）汽車喇叭聲；鵝叫聲
honk.eg: He gave us a honk on his horn as he drove off.

honorary.eng_def: (especially of a degree) given as an honour to someone who has not done a course of study
honorary.eg: She received an honorary doctorate from Exeter University in recognition of her work for the homeless.

honorary.eng_def: An honorary position in an organization is one for which no payment is made.
honorary.eg: Charities often have a well-known person as their honorary treasurer.

hood.eng_def: part of a piece of clothing that can be pulled up to cover the top and back of the head
hood.eg: The coat has a detachable hood.

hood.eng_def: a bag that is put over someone's head so that they cannot see or be recognized
hood.chi_def: （為了擋住視線或不讓人認出而戴的）頭套，頭罩
hood.eg: The prisoners had been tortured and made to wear hoods.

hood.eng_def: a part that covers or shelters a piece of equipment
hood.eg: The hood over the air vent is loose.

hood.eng_def: the metal cover over the part of a car where the engine is
hood.eg: I looked under the hood and clouds of smoke poured out.
When he started he was just a poor boy from the hood - now he's a multimillionaire.

hood.eng_def: used to form nouns describing the state of being a particular thing
hood.chi_def: （用於構成名詞，描述作為某種事物的狀態）

hoof.eng_def: the hard part on the bottom of the feet of animals such as horses, sheep, and deer

hoof.eg: The defender hoofed the ball up the field.

hook.eng_def: a curved device used for catching or holding things, especially one attached to a surface for hanging things on
a way of hitting in boxing, cricket, or golf
hook.chi_def: （拳擊的）勾拳；（板球或高爾夫球的）曲球

hook.eng_def: to fasten something with a hook, hang something on a hook, or catch something with a hook
hook.eg: He hooked the trailer (= joined it with a hook) to his car.

hop.eng_def: to jump on one foot or to move about in this way
hop.eg: I tried to hop on my good foot while holding onto Jim.

hop.eng_def: to go somewhere quickly or to get into or out of a vehicle quickly
hop.chi_def: 快速去（某地）；快速跳上（或跳下）（車輛）
hop.eg: We hopped over to Bruges for the weekend.

hop.eng_def: If a small animal, bird, or insect hops, it moves by jumping on all or two of its feet at the same time.
hop.eg: The rabbit/bird hopped across the grass.

hop.eng_def: a short jump by a person on one foot, or by a small animal, bird, or insect on all or two of its feet at the same time
hop.chi_def: 單足短距離跳躍；（小動物、鳥或昆蟲的）齊足（或雙足）短距離跳躍
hop.eg: With his feet tied together he could only move in little hops.

hop.eng_def: to be a short distance, especially by plane
hop.eg: Rio to São Paulo is just a short hop by plane.

hop.eng_def: the dried fruits of a climbing plant, used to give a bitter flavour to beer

hope.eng_def: to want something to happen or to be true, and usually have a good reason to think that it might
hope.eg: I'm hoping for an interview next week.

hope.eng_def: something good that you want to happen in the future, or a confident feeling about what will happen in the future
hope.eg: What are your hopes and dreams for the future?

hopeful.chi_def: 抱有希望的，充滿希望的
hopeful.eg: He was hopeful about the outcome of the meeting.
The green shoots were hopeful signs of spring.

hopeful.eng_def: a person who is trying to get a part in a film, play for a famous sports team, etc.
hopeful.chi_def: 希望成名的人（設法參與電影拍攝，戲劇演出，著名足球俱樂部等等）
hopeful.eg: Over a thousand young hopefuls went to the Theatre Royal today to audition for a part in the new musical.

horizon.eng_def: the line at the farthest place that you can see, where the sky seems to touch the land or sea
horizon.eg: The moon rose slowly above the horizon.

horizontal.eng_def: parallel to the ground or to the bottom or top edge of something
horizontal.chi_def: 水平的；與地面（或底邊、頂邊）平行的；橫的
horizontal.eg: Draw a horizontal line across the bottom of the page.

horizontal.eng_def: a horizontal line, surface, or position
horizontal.chi_def: 水平線；水平面；水平位置
horizontal.eg: Rotate it slowly from the horizontal into a vertical position.

hormone.eng_def: any of various chemicals made by living cells that influence the development, growth, sex, etc. of an animal and are carried around the body in the blood

horn.eng_def: a hard, pointed, often curved part that grows from the top of the head of some animals, or the hard substance of which a horn is made
a device on a vehicle that is used to make a loud noise as a warning or signal to other people
horn.eg: The driver blew/sounded (informal honked) her horn.

horn.eng_def: a curved metal musical instrument that is narrow at the end you blow into and much wider at the other end

horrify.eg: This news will horrify my parents.

horror.eng_def: an extremely strong feeling of fear and shock, or the frightening and shocking character of something
horror.chi_def: 恐懼；震驚；（…的）震驚性，恐怖性
horror.eg: The crowd cried out in horror as the car burst into flames.

horror.eng_def: things that are very shocking or frightening
horror.eg: The population now faces the horrors of starvation.

horror.eng_def: a child who behaves very badly
horror.eg: Her youngest boy is a little horror.

horse.eng_def: a large animal with four legs that people ride on or use for carrying things or pulling vehicles
horse races where you try to win money by correctly guessing which horse will win
horse.eg: He spends all his money on the horses.

horse.eng_def: a tall piece of equipment that people jump over in gymnastics

hose.eng_def: a long plastic or rubber pipe, used to direct water onto fires, gardens, etc.
hose.chi_def: （滅火、澆灌花園等用的）軟管，水龍帶

hose.eng_def: to direct water onto something using a hose
hose.eg: He was covered in mud so we hosed him down.

hospitable.eng_def: friendly and welcoming to guests and visitors
hospitable.eg: The villagers were very hospitable to/towards anyone who passed through.

hospitable.eng_def: providing good conditions for living or growing
hospitable.chi_def: （條件）適宜生活的，適合成長的
hospitable.eg: It's difficult to think of a less hospitable environment than the surface of the moon.

hospital.eng_def: a place where people who are ill or injured are treated and taken care of by doctors and nurses

hospitality.eng_def: the act of being friendly and welcoming to guests and visitors
hospitality.eg: The local people showed me great hospitality.

hospitality.eng_def: food, drink, entertainment, etc. that an organization provides for guests or business partners
hospitality.chi_def: （待客用的）食物，飲料；招待，款待
hospitality.eg: The company's guests are entertained in the corporate hospitality area.

hospitalize.eng_def: to take someone to hospital and keep them there for treatment
hospitalize.eg: His wife's been hospitalized for depression.

hostess.eng_def: a woman who entertains customers, especially men, at a nightclub

hostile.eg: I'm not hostile to (= against) the idea of change as such.

hostile.eng_def: difficult or not suitable for living or growing
connected with the enemy in a war
relating to situations in which one company wants to buy another company whose owners do not want to sell it
hostile.eg: The company convinced investors to reject a hostile bid from Enterprise Oil Plc worth £1.5 billion.

hostility.eng_def: an occasion when someone is unfriendly or shows that they do not like something
hostility.eg: They showed open (= obvious) hostility to/towards their new neighbours.

hostility.eng_def: an occasion when someone shows that they do not agree with or like something

hostility.eg: Hostilities began/broke out just after midnight.

hot.eng_def: used to describe food that causes a burning feeling in the mouth
used to describe a subject that causes a lot of disagreement or discussion
hot.eg: Global warming has become a very hot issue.

hot.chi_def: 所知甚多的；技藝精湛的
hot.eg: I'm not too hot on Russian history.

hot.eng_def: an accurate piece of advice about who will win a race
hot.chi_def: 對比賽結果的準確猜測
hot.eg: Do you have any hot tips for this afternoon's race?

hot.eng_def: the person or animal that is most likely to win a race, competition, election, etc.
hot.chi_def: 奪冠的大熱門，最可能獲勝者
hot.eg: He's the hot favourite to win the election.

hot.eng_def: to think that a particular thing is very important and to demand that it is done well or correctly
hot.eg: They're very hot on dress at work so she always looks very smart for the office.

hot.eng_def: Hot goods have been recently stolen and are therefore difficult to sell or dangerous to deal with because the police are still looking for them.
sexually attractive, or feeling sexually excited
If someone has a hot temper, they are easily made angry.

hotel.eng_def: a building where you pay to have a room to sleep in, and where you can sometimes eat meals
a building where alcoholic drinks can be bought and drunk and where food is often available

hound.eng_def: a type of dog used for hunting
to chase someone or to refuse to leave someone alone, especially because you want to get something from them
hound.eg: The reporters wouldn't stop hounding her.

hour.eg: The exam lasted an hour and a half.

hour.eng_def: the period of time when a particular activity happens or when a shop or public building is open
hour.chi_def: （用於做某事的）時間；（商店或公共場所）開放時間
hour.eg: I try to spend my lunch hour walking.

hour.eng_def: a particular time during the day or night
hour.chi_def: （白天或夜裡的）某個時間，某個時刻
hour.eg: Who could be calling us at this unearthly/ungodly hour (= so late at night)?

hour.eng_def: used to describe how many hours in the day you work or what part of the day you work
hour.chi_def: 長時間工作／工作時間規律／在其他人不上班的時間工作（等等）
hour.eg: She's a nurse so she often works unsocial hours.
I waited for him for hours.

hour.eng_def: repeatedly during the day and the night
hour.chi_def: 整天不斷地；晝夜不停地
hour.eg: They keep calling me at all hours (of the day and night).

hourly.eg: There's an hourly bus service into town.

hourly.eng_def: the amount that is charged or earned every hour

house.eng_def: a building that people, usually one family, live in
all the people living in a house
house.chi_def: 住在一間房子裡的人；全家人
house.eg: Try not to wake the whole house when you come in!

house.eng_def: a building where animals are kept
house.eg: the monkey/lion house at the zoo

house.eng_def: a building or part of a building that is used for a special purpose
a company that is involved in a particular area of business
house.chi_def: （尤指出版圖書或設計服裝的）公司，機構，商行

house.eng_def: popular dance music with a fast regular beat, usually produced on electronic equipment
house.chi_def: 電子音樂（電子樂器演奏的一種快節奏的流行音樂）
house.eg: House music first appeared in the late 1980s.

house.eng_def: any of a small number of groups that the children in a school are put in for sports and other competitions
house.chi_def: （學校裡為進行比賽而分成的）組

house.eng_def: an important family, especially a royal one
house.eg: The British Royal Family belong to the House of Windsor.

house.eng_def: an organization that makes laws, or its meeting place
the members of the organization that makes laws
house.eg: The House began debating the proposal at 3 p.m.

house.eng_def: the group of people who suggest a subject for a debate
house.eg: The motion for tonight's debate is, "This house believes that capital punishment should be abolished."

house.eng_def: the people watching a performance, especially in a theatre
house.eg: The opera played to a full/packed house.

house.eng_def: to give a person or animal a place to live, or to provide space for something
house.chi_def: 為…提供住處，收容；為…提供空間
house.eg: It will be difficult to house all the refugees.

household.eng_def: a group of people, often a family, who live together
household.eg: By the 1960s, most households had a TV.

housekeeper.eng_def: a person, especially a woman, whose job is to organize another person's house and deal with cooking, cleaning, etc.

housewife.eng_def: a woman whose work is inside the home, doing the cleaning, cooking, etc., and who usually does not have any other job

housework.eng_def: the work of keeping a house clean and tidy

housing.eng_def: buildings for people to live in
housing.eg: There's a shortage of cheap housing in the region.

hover.eng_def: to stay in one place in the air, usually by moving the wings quickly
hover.eg: A hawk hovered in the sky, waiting to swoop down on its prey.

hover.eng_def: to stand somewhere, especially near another person, eagerly or nervously waiting for their attention
hover.eg: A waiter hovered at the table, ready to take our order.

hover.eng_def: to stay at or near a particular level
hover.eg: Inflation is hovering at three percent.

hover.eng_def: to put the cursor on a computer screen in a particular place without clicking on it
hover.chi_def: 把游標放在電腦螢幕上的某個位置
hover.eg: The link changes to green when the mouse hovers over it.

how.eng_def: in what way, or by what methods
how.eg: How do we get to the town from here?

how.eng_def: used to ask about someone's physical or emotional state
how.chi_def: （尤指身體或精神狀況）怎麼樣

how.eng_def: used in questions that ask what an experience or event was like
how.chi_def: （用於詢問經歷或事情）怎麼樣

how.eg: I can't tell you how pleased I am (= I am very pleased) that you came.

how.eng_def: used to emphasize that something is strange, stupid, etc.
how.chi_def: （用於強調）那可真奇怪／愚蠢／古怪（等等）

how.eng_def: used to ask someone if they are well and happy
how.eg: "Hi, Lucy, how are you?" "Fine, thanks, how are you?"

how.eng_def: used when you want someone to explain what they have just said
how.chi_def: （要求某人解釋剛說的話）你是甚麼意思?
how.eg: "I think we need to reconsider our position." "How do you mean?"

how.eng_def: used when asking if something you have done for someone is satisfactory
how.chi_def: （用於為某人做某事之後詢問效果）滿意嗎？怎麼樣？
how.eg: Let me put a cushion behind your back. How's that?

how.eng_def: used to show that you feel the same way as someone
how.eg: "I'll be so glad when this project is finished." "And how!"

however.eg: However hungry I am, I never seem to be able to finish off a whole pizza.

however.chi_def: （用於表示驚訝）究竟怎樣，到底如何
however.eg: However did you manage to get him to agree to that?
However you look at it, it's still a mess.
This is one possible solution to the problem. However, there are others.

howl.eng_def: If a dog or wolf howls, it makes a long, sad sound.
howl.eg: In the silence of the night, a lone wolf howled.

howl.eng_def: to make a loud sound, usually to express pain, sadness, or another strong emotion
howl.chi_def: （通常因痛苦、悲傷或其他強烈情感而）號叫，哀號
howl.eg: An injured dog lay in the middle of the road, howling with/in pain.

howl.eng_def: If the wind howls, it blows hard and makes a lot of noise.
howl.eg: Is there someone outside, or is it just the wind howling in the trees?
the howl of the wind in the trees

howl.eng_def: a strong expression of emotion, such as anger or disagreement
howl.chi_def: 感情迸發；怒吼，憤怒的表示
howl.eg: Plans to build a new supermarket have been greeted with howls of protest from local residents.

hug.eng_def: to hold someone close to your body with your arms, usually to show that you like, love, or value them
hug.chi_def: 擁抱，摟抱（以示喜歡或欣賞）
hug.eg: Have you hugged your child today?

hug.eng_def: to stay very close to something or someone
hug.eg: The road hugs the coast for several miles, then turns inland.

hug.eng_def: to keep something that makes you feel better or pleases you private or secret
hug.eg: I hugged the idea to myself all through dinner.

hug.eng_def: the act of holding someone or something close to your body with your arms
hug.eg: Come here and give me a big hug.

huge.eng_def: extremely large in size or amount
huge.eg: They live in a huge house.

hum.eng_def: to make a continuous low sound
hum.chi_def: 發出連續低沉的聲音，嗡嗡作響
hum.eg: The computers were humming in the background.

hum.eng_def: to sing without opening your mouth
hum.eg: She hummed to herself as she walked to school.

hum.eng_def: to be busy and full of activity, excitement, sounds, or voices
hum.eg: The bar was really humming last night.

hum.chi_def: 持續低沉的噪音；嗡嗡聲
hum.eg: Our house is on a main road, so we can hear the constant hum of traffic.

human.eg: The human body is composed of about 60 percent water.
The greatest damage being done to our planet today is that being done by humans.

humanitarian.eng_def: (a person who is) involved in or connected with improving people's lives and reducing suffering
humanitarian.chi_def: 人道主義的；人道主義者
humanitarian.eg: The prisoner has been released for humanitarian reasons.

humanity.eg: The massacre was a crime against humanity.

humanity.eng_def: understanding and kindness towards other people
humanity.eg: If only he would show/display a little humanity for once.
There is a sense of common humanity that unites people of all nations.

humanity.eng_def: the study of subjects such as literature, language, history, and philosophy
humanity.chi_def: 人文學科（如文學、語言、歷史、哲學等）
humanity.eg: I've always been more interested in the humanities than the sciences.

humankind.eng_def: all people, considered as a group

humble.eng_def: not proud or not believing that you are important
humble.eg: He's very humble about his success.

humble.eng_def: poor or of a low social rank
humble.eg: Even when she became rich and famous, she never forgot her humble background.

humble.eng_def: ordinary; not special or very important
humble.eg: At that time she was just a humble mechanic.

humble.eng_def: to make someone understand that they are not as important or special as they thought
humble.eg: He was humbled by the child's generosity.

humid.eng_def: (of air and weather conditions) containing extremely small drops of water in the air
humid.chi_def: （空氣和天氣狀況）潮濕的，濕潤的
humid.eg: New York is very hot and humid in the summer.

humidity.eg: I don't like the humidity of this climate.

humidity.eng_def: a measurement of how much water there is in the air
humidity.eg: The temperature is almost 80 degrees, and the humidity 35%.

humiliate.eng_def: to make someone feel ashamed or lose respect for himself or herself
humiliate.eg: How could you humiliate me by questioning my judgment in front of everyone like that?

humorous.eg: Her latest book is a humorous look at teenage life.

hunch.eng_def: an idea that is based on feeling and for which there is no proof
hunch.eg: I had a hunch that you'd be here.

hunch.eng_def: to lean forward with your shoulders raised or to bend your back and shoulders into a rounded shape
hunch.eg: We hunched round the fire to keep warm.

hundred.eg: We've driven a/one hundred miles in the last two hours.
There were hundreds of people at the pool today.
He expects the total amount to be in the low hundreds.

hundred.eng_def: the years of a particular century
hundred.chi_def: 某個世紀（18世紀，19世紀，等等）
hundred.eg: The house was built in the sixteen hundreds.

hundred.eng_def: used to say the time using the 24-hour system, especially used in the military
hundred.chi_def: 用於表達24小時制的時間（尤用於軍事）
hundred.eg: Breakfast is at seven hundred hours.

hunger.eng_def: the feeling you have when you need to eat
hunger.eg: I can't believe that that enormous meal wasn't enough to satisfy your hunger.

hunger.eng_def: a situation in which the body does not have enough food
hunger.eg: All over the world, people die of hunger every day.

hungry.eg: By four o'clock I felt/was really hungry.

hungry.eng_def: having a strong wish or desire for something
hungry.eg: She was so hungry for success that she'd do anything to achieve it.

hungry.eng_def: having a strong wish or desire for the stated thing

hunt.eng_def: to chase and try to catch and kill an animal or bird for food, sport, or profit
in Britain, to chase and kill animals, especially foxes, using dogs and riding on horses
hunt.chi_def: （英國帶著獵狗進行的）騎馬打獵；（尤指）騎馬獵狐

hunt.eng_def: to try to find something or someone
hunt.eg: I've hunted all over the place, but I can't find that book.

hunt.eng_def: a search for something or someone
hunt.eg: After a long hunt we finally found a house we liked.

hunt.eng_def: the activity of people chasing wild animals in order to kill them
hunt.eg: to go on a fox/deer hunt

hunt.eng_def: in the UK, a group of people who meet regularly in order to chase and kill animals, especially foxes
hunt.chi_def: （英國騎馬狩獵的）狩獵隊；（尤指）獵狐隊
hunt.eg: They are members of the local hunt.

hunter.eng_def: a person or an animal that hunts animals for food or for sport
hunter.eg: Animals in the cat family are hunters.

hunter.eng_def: a type of horse, especially one used in hunting animals
someone who hunts the stated animal
someone who is trying to find or get the stated thing

hurdle.eng_def: a frame or fence for jumping over in a race
hurdle.eg: He fell at the last hurdle.

hurdle.eng_def: a race in which people or horses jump over hurdles
a problem that you have to deal with before you can make progress
hurdle.eg: Getting a work permit was the first hurdle to overcome.

hurdle.eng_def: to run in a race in which there are hurdles to be jumped over, or to jump over something while running
hurdle.eg: He hurdled the gate and scrambled up the hill.

hurl.eng_def: to throw something with a lot of force, usually in an angry or violent way
hurl.eg: In a fit of temper he hurled the book across the room.

hurl.eng_def: to shout insults or rude language at someone angrily
hurl.eg: I wasn't going to stand there while he hurled abuse at me!

hurricane.eng_def: a violent wind that has a circular movement, especially in the West Atlantic Ocean
hurricane.eg: The state of Florida was hit by a hurricane that did serious damage.

hurry.eng_def: to move or do things more quickly than normal or to make someone do this
the need to move or do things more quickly than normal
hurry.eg: We left in such a hurry that we forgot our tickets.

hurt.eng_def: to feel pain in a part of your body, or to injure someone or cause them pain
to cause emotional pain to someone
hurt.eg: She criticized my writing quite severely and that hurt.
A lot of businesses are being hurt by the current high interest rates.
Let me help you up. Are you hurt?
I feel very hurt by what you said.
The hurt after a relationship breaks up can be awful.

husband.eng_def: the man that you are married to
to use something carefully so that you do not use all of it

hush.eg: There was a deathly hush after she made the announcement.

hush.eng_def: used to tell someone to be quiet

hut.eng_def: a small, simple building, usually consisting of one room

hydrogen.eng_def: a chemical element that is the lightest gas, has no colour, taste, or smell, and combines with oxygen to form water

hygiene.eng_def: the degree to which people keep themselves or their environment clean, especially to prevent disease
hygiene.eg: Poor standards of hygiene mean that the disease spreads fast.

hymn.eng_def: a song of praise that Christians sing to God

hypocrisy.eng_def: a situation in which someone pretends to believe something that they do not really believe, or that is the opposite of what they do or say at another time
hypocrisy.eg: There's one rule for her and another rule for everyone else and it's sheer hypocrisy.

hypocrite.eng_def: someone who says they have particular moral beliefs but behaves in way that shows these are not sincere
hypocrite.eg: He's a hypocrite - he's always lecturing other people on the environment but he drives around in a huge car.

hysterical.eng_def: unable to control your feelings or behaviour because you are extremely frightened, angry, excited, etc.
hysterical.chi_def: 歇斯底里的，情緒過分激動的

ice.eng_def: water that has frozen and become solid, or pieces of this
ice.eg: The pond was covered in ice all winter.

ice.eng_def: an ice cream, especially one bought in a shop
ice.eg: The shop sign said "Drinks, Cakes, Ices!"

ice.eng_def: to cover a cake with icing (= a food made mainly with sugar)
ice.eg: I've made her a chocolate cake - now I just need to ice it.

ice.eng_def: abbreviation for Immigration and Customs Enforcement: the US government department that is responsible for making sure that laws on who is allowed to enter, stay in, and work in the US and what is allowed to be brought across US borders are obeyed
ice.chi_def: （美國）移民及海關執法局（Immigration and Customs Enforcement 的縮寫）
ice.eg: The senator urged ICE not to deport the woman, who has four young children.

ice.eng_def: abbreviation for In Case of Emergency: used as a name for a number stored on a person's mobile phone that other people should call if the person is seriously ill or injured
ice.chi_def: 緊急情況連絡人（In Case of Emergency 的縮寫，用作儲存在手機上的一個號碼的名字，如果手機主人突發疾病或受傷，其他人可以撥打這個號碼）
ice.eg: The idea of ICE took off after the 7 July 2005 London bombings.

iceberg.eng_def: a very large mass of ice that floats in the sea

icy.eg: She opened the window and I was hit by an icy blast of air.

idea.eng_def: a suggestion or plan for doing something
idea.eg: I've had an idea - why don't we go to the coast?

idea.eng_def: an understanding, thought, or picture in your mind
idea.eg: Do you have any idea of what he looks like?
We have very different ideas about disciplining children.

idea.eng_def: a purpose or reason for doing something
idea.eg: The idea of the game is to get rid of all your cards as soon as you can.

ideal.eng_def: a principle or a way of behaving that is of a very high standard
ideal.chi_def: 理想，標準極高的原則（或行為準則）

ideal.eg: The ideal would be to have a house in the town and one in the country.

identical.eng_def: exactly the same, or very similar
identical.chi_def: 完全相同的；極為相似的
identical.eg: I've got three identical blue suits.

identification.eng_def: the act of recognizing and naming someone or something
identification.eg: Most of the bodies were badly burned, making identification almost impossible.

identification.eng_def: an official document that shows or proves who you are
