identification.eg: We were asked to show some identification before the security guards would let us in.

identify.eng_def: to recognize someone or something and say or prove who or what that person or thing is
identify.eg: Even the smallest baby can identify its mother by her voice.

identify.eng_def: to recognize a problem, need, fact, etc. and to show that it exists
identify.eg: The research will be used to identify training needs.

identity.eng_def: who a person is, or the qualities of a person or group that make them different from others
identity.eg: The man's identity was being kept secret while he was helping police with enquiries.

idiom.eng_def: a group of words in a fixed order that have a particular meaning that is different from the meanings of each word on its own
idiom.eg: To "have bitten off more than you can chew" is an idiom that means you have tried to do something which is too difficult for you.

idiom.eng_def: the style of expression in writing, speech, or music that is typical of a particular period, person, or group
idiom.chi_def: （某一時期、個人或群體在寫作、言語、音樂方面的）典型表達風格
idiom.eg: Both operas are very much in the modern idiom.

idiot.eng_def: a stupid person or someone who is behaving in a stupid way
idiot.eg: Some idiot left the tap running in the bathroom and there's water everywhere.

idle.eg: Half these factories now stand idle.

idle.eng_def: An idle moment or period of time is one in which there is no work or activity.
idle.eg: If you have an idle moment, call me.
Almost half of the workforce are now idle.

idle.eng_def: lazy and not willing to work
idle.eg: He's a very able student, he's just bone idle (= very lazy).

idle.eng_def: If an engine or machine idles, it runs slowly but does not move or do any work.
idle.eg: He left the engine idling and ran into the shop.

idol.eng_def: someone who is admired and respected very much
a picture or object that people pray to as part of their religion
idol.eg: The ancient people of this area worshipped a huge bronze idol in the shape of an elephant.

if.eng_def: used to say that a particular thing can or will happen only after something else happens or becomes true
if.eg: I'll pay you double if you get the work finished by Friday.
They're great kids, even if they can be demanding.
If water is heated to 100°C it turns to steam.

if.eng_def: used to mean "if it is true that"
if.eg: I'm very sorry if I've offended you.

if.eng_def: used to introduce a clause, often in indirect speech, that shows two or more possibilities
if.chi_def: （用於引出從句，常為間接引語）是否
if.eg: Mrs Kramer called half an hour ago to ask if her cake was ready.

if.eng_def: used when you want to make a polite request or remark
if.chi_def: （用於禮貌地作出請求或評論）
if.eg: If you'd like to take a seat, Mr Chang will be with you in a moment.

if.eng_def: something that is not certain or not yet decided
if.chi_def: 不確定因素；未決之事；疑問
if.eg: There's a big if hanging over the project (= it is uncertain whether the project will happen).

ignorance.eng_def: lack of knowledge, understanding, or information about something
ignorance.eg: Public ignorance about the disease is still a cause for concern.

ignorant.eng_def: not having enough knowledge, understanding, or information about something
ignorant.eg: Many teenagers are surprisingly ignorant about current politics.

ignore.eng_def: to intentionally not listen or give attention to
ignore.eg: She can be really irritating but I try to ignore her.

ill.eng_def: not feeling well, or suffering from a disease
ill.eg: I felt ill so I went home.

ill.eng_def: to say unkind things about someone
ill.eg: I realize one shouldn't speak ill of the dead.

ill.eng_def: to be a sign of bad things in the future
ill.eg: This weather bodes ill for the garden party tonight.

ill.eng_def: If you can ill afford to do something, it will cause problems for you if you do it.
ill.chi_def: 經不起（做…）；一旦…就會遇麻煩
ill.eg: We can ill afford to lose another member of staff.
There seems to be no cure for the country's economic/social ills.

ill.eng_def: in a way that is bad or not suitable
short form of I shall or I will
ill.chi_def: （I shall或 I will的縮略形式）

illuminate.eng_def: to light something and make it brighter
illuminate.eg: The streets were illuminated with strings of coloured lights.

illuminate.eng_def: to explain and show more clearly something that is difficult to understand
illuminate.eg: an article which illuminates the issues at stake

illusion.eng_def: an idea or belief that is not true
illusion.eg: He had no illusions about his talents as a singer.

illusion.eng_def: something that is not really what it seems to be
illusion.eg: A large mirror in a room can create the illusion of space.

illustrate.eng_def: to draw pictures for a book, magazine, etc.
to show the meaning or truth of something more clearly, especially by giving examples
illustrate.eg: The lecturer illustrated his point with a diagram on the blackboard.

illustration.eng_def: a picture in a book, magazine, etc. or the process of illustrating something
an example that explains or proves something
illustration.eg: This delay is a perfect illustration of why we need a new computer system.

image.eng_def: a picture in your mind or an idea of how someone or something is
image.eg: I have an image in my mind of how I want the garden to be.

image.eng_def: the way that something or someone is thought of by other people
image.eg: The aim is to improve the public image of the police.

image.eng_def: a mental picture or idea that forms in a reader's or listener's mind from the words that they read or hear
image.eg: The poem is full of images of birth and new life.

image.eng_def: any picture, especially one formed by a mirror or a lens
image.chi_def: （尤指鏡子或透鏡形成的）鏡像；影像；映射

imaginable.eg: The school offers courses in every subject imaginable.

imaginary.eng_def: Something that is imaginary is created by and exists only in the mind.
imaginary.eg: As a child I had an imaginary friend.

imagination.eng_def: the ability to form pictures in the mind
imagination.eg: My younger son has a very vivid (= active) imagination.

imagination.eng_def: something that you think exists or is true, although in fact it is not real or true
imagination.eg: Was she paying him a lot of attention or was it just my imagination?

imagination.eng_def: the ability to think of new ideas
imagination.eg: It's a job that needs someone with a bit of imagination.

imaginative.eng_def: good at thinking of new, original, and clever ideas
imaginative.chi_def: 想像力豐富的，有創意的

imagine.eng_def: to form or have a mental picture or idea of something
imagine.eg: Imagine Robert Redford when he was young - that's what John looks like.

imagine.eng_def: to believe that something is probably true
imagine.eg: I imagine (that) he's under a lot of pressure at the moment.

imagine.eng_def: to think that something exists or is true, although in fact it is not real or true
imagine.eg: "Did you hear a noise?" "No, you're imagining things/No, you must have imagined it."

imagine.eng_def: used to express shock or surprise, often at someone else's behaviour
imagine.chi_def: （常用來表示對他人行為的驚訝、震驚）難以想像
imagine.eg: She got married at 16! Imagine that!
You can't imagine what a mess the house was in after the party.

imitate.eng_def: to behave in a similar way to someone or something else, or to copy the speech or behaviour, etc. of someone or something
imitate.eg: Some of the younger pop bands try to imitate their musical heroes from the past.

imitation.eng_def: made to look like something else
an occasion when someone or something imitates another person or thing
imitation.eg: Ten-year-olds have started wearing lipstick and make-up in imitation of the older girls.
His songs are just cheap (= low quality) imitations of Beatles tunes.

immediate.eng_def: happening or done without delay or very soon after something else
immediate.eg: We must make an immediate response.

immediate.eng_def: used to refer to something or someone that is close to, or is a cause of or an effect of, something or someone else
immediate.eg: There are few facilities in the immediate area.

immediate.eng_def: in the present or as soon as possible
the period of time that is coming next
your closest relations, such as your parents, children, husband, or wife
immediate.chi_def: 直系親屬（如父母、子女、配偶等）

immense.eng_def: extremely large in size or degree

immigrant.eng_def: a person who has come to a different country in order to live there permanently

immigrate.eng_def: to come to live in a different country
immigrate.eg: He immigrated with his parents in 1895 and grew up on Long Island.

immigration.eng_def: the act of someone coming to live in a different country
immigration.eg: There are strict limits on immigration (into the country).

immigration.eng_def: the process of examining your passport and other documents to make certain that you can be allowed to enter the country, or the place where this is done
immigration.chi_def: 移民局入境檢查；移民局入境檢查處
immigration.eg: After you've been through immigration (control), you can go and get your luggage.

immune.eng_def: protected against a particular disease by particular substances in the blood
immune.eg: Most people who've had chickenpox once are immune to it for the rest of their lives.

immune.eng_def: not affected or upset by a particular type of behaviour or emotion
immune.eg: The press had criticized her so often that in the end she had become immune (to it).

immune.eng_def: not able to be punished or damaged by something
immune.eg: Journalists, he insisted, must be immune (= protected) from prosecution.

impact.eng_def: the force or action of one object hitting another
impact.eg: The impact of the crash reduced the car to a third of its original length.

impact.eng_def: a powerful effect that something, especially something new, has on a situation or person
impact.chi_def: （尤指新事物的）巨大影響，強大作用
impact.eg: The anti-smoking campaign had had/made quite an impact on young people.

impact.eng_def: to have an influence on something
impact.eg: Falling export rates have impacted (on) the country's economy quite considerably.

imperative.chi_def: 極重要的；緊急的；迫切的
imperative.eg: The president said it was imperative that the release of all hostages be secured.

imperative.eng_def: used to describe the form of a verb that is usually used for giving orders
imperative.eg: In the phrase "Leave him alone!", the verb "leave" is in the imperative form.

imperative.eng_def: the form of a verb that is usually used for giving orders
imperative.eg: In the phrase "Leave him alone!", the verb "leave" is an imperative/is in the imperative.

imperative.eng_def: something that is extremely important or urgent
imperative.eg: Getting the unemployed back to work, said the mayor, is a moral imperative.

imperial.eng_def: belonging or relating to an empire or the person or country that rules it
The imperial system of measurement uses units such as inches, miles, and pints.
imperial.eg: Imperial units have in many cases been replaced by metric ones in Britain.

implement.eng_def: to start using a plan or system
implement.eg: The changes to the national health system will be implemented next year.

implement.eng_def: a tool that works by being moved by hand or by being pulled across a surface

implication.eng_def: an occasion when you seem to suggest something without saying it directly
implication.eg: From what she said, the implication was that they were splitting up.

implication.eng_def: the effect that an action or decision will have on something else in the future
implication.chi_def: 可能的影響；可能的後果
implication.eg: The company is cutting back its spending and I wonder what the implications will be for our department.

implication.eng_def: an occasion when you suggest or show that someone is involved in a crime
implication.eg: The case depended upon his implication of his co-workers in the fraud.

implicit.eg: He interpreted her comments as an implicit criticism of the government.

imply.eng_def: to communicate an idea or feeling without saying it directly
used to show that the name, etc. of something tells you something about it
imply.eg: Variable rate loans, as the name implies, have a variable interest rate.

imply.eng_def: to involve something or make it necessary

import.eng_def: to buy or bring in products from another country
import.eg: We import a large number of cars from Japan.

import.eng_def: to introduce new goods, customs, or ideas to one country from another
import.eg: Jazz is an American modification of musical conventions imported from Europe.

import.eng_def: to copy information from one computer or computer program to another
import.eg: I need to import data from the database into this spreadsheet.

import.eng_def: goods bought by one country from another
the action of bringing goods or fashions into a country

import.eg: Whether it is to be a "working" visit or an "official" visit is of little/no import.

importance.eg: The health report stresses the importance of fresh food in a diet.

important.eg: I think his career is more important to him than I am.
He was one of the most important writers of that period.

impose.eng_def: to officially force a rule, tax, punishment, etc. to be obeyed or received
impose.eg: Very high taxes have recently been imposed on cigarettes.

impose.eng_def: to force someone to accept something, especially a belief or way of living
impose.chi_def: 把（尤指信仰或生活方式）強加於
impose.eg: I don't want them to impose their religious beliefs on my children.

impose.eng_def: to expect someone to do something for you or spend time with you when they do not want to or when it is not convenient for them
impose.eg: Are you sure it's all right for me to come tonight? I don't want to impose.

imposing.eng_def: having an appearance that looks important or causes admiration
imposing.chi_def: 壯觀的，宏偉的；氣宇不凡的

impress.eng_def: to cause someone to admire or respect you
impress.chi_def: 給…留下深刻印象；使欽佩
impress.eg: I remember when I was a child being very impressed with how many toys she had.

impression.eng_def: an idea or opinion of what something or someone is like
impression.eg: I didn't get much of an impression of the place because it was dark when we drove through it.

impression.eng_def: to think that something is true, especially when it is not
impression.eg: I was under the impression (that) you didn't get on too well.

impression.eng_def: the way that something seems, looks, or feels to a particular person
impression.eg: It makes/gives/creates a very bad impression if you're late for an interview.

impression.eng_def: an attempt at copying another person's manner and speech, etc., especially in order to make people laugh
impression.eg: She does a really good impression of the president.

impression.eng_def: a mark made on the surface of something by pressing an object onto it
impression.eg: There were impressions around her ankles made by the tops of her socks.

impression.eng_def: all the copies of a book that have been printed at the same time without any changes being made
impression.eg: This is the second impression of the encyclopedia.

impressive.eng_def: If an object or achievement is impressive, you admire or respect it, usually because it is special, important, or very large.
impressive.chi_def: （因特殊、重要或巨大而）給人留下深刻印象的
impressive.eg: That was an impressive performance from such a young tennis player.

impressive.eng_def: If someone is impressive, you admire or respect that person for their special skills or abilities.
impressive.chi_def: （因具備特殊技能）令人欽佩的
impressive.eg: She's a very impressive public speaker.

imprison.eg: He was imprisoned in 1965 for attempted murder.

imprisonment.eng_def: the limiting of someone's freedom without the authority or right to do so
imprisonment.eg: He brought civil proceedings against the police for false imprisonment.

improve.eg: He did a lot to improve conditions for factory workers.

improvement.eng_def: an occasion when something gets better or when you make it better
improvement.eg: a slight improvement in the economy

impulse.eng_def: a sudden strong wish to do something
impulse.eg: I had this sudden impulse to shout out "Nonsense!" in the middle of her speech.

impulse.eng_def: because you suddenly want to, although you haven't planned to
impulse.eg: "I didn't know you were looking for some new shoes." "Oh, I wasn't - I just bought them on impulse."

impulse.eng_def: a short electrical, radio, or light signal that carries information or instructions between the parts of a system
something that is the driving force behind or reason for something else

in.eng_def: inside a container, place, or area, or surrounded or closed off by something
in.eg: Is Mark still in bed?

in.eng_def: into something
in.eg: Come on, we're late - get in the car.

in.eng_def: forming a part of something
in.eg: He used to be the lead singer in a rock band.

in.eng_def: during part or all of a period of time
in.eg: We're going to Italy in April.

in.eng_def: between the two times mentioned
in.eg: I have breakfast at 7.30, lunch at 1.00, and sometimes a snack in between.

in.eng_def: needing or using no more time than a particular amount of time
in.eg: Can you finish the job in two weeks?

in.eng_def: before or at the end of a particular period
in.chi_def: 在…結束之前；在…結束之時
in.eg: Dinner will be ready in ten minutes.

in.eng_def: experiencing a situation or condition, or feeling an emotion
in.eg: We watched in horror as they pulled the bodies from the wreckage.

in.eng_def: expressed or written in a particular way
in.eg: Cheques should be written in ink.

in.eng_def: used when referring to something that is done as a result of something else
in.chi_def: （表示一事為另一事的結果）作為
in.eg: I'd like to do something for you in return/exchange for everything you've done for me.

in.eng_def: used to show how things or people are arranged or divided
in.chi_def: （表示組織或劃分方式）以，按照
in.eg: We all sat down in a circle.

in.eng_def: used when referring approximately to someone's age or the weather temperature
in.eg: Nowadays many women are in their late thirties when they have their first child.

in.eng_def: involved or connected with a particular subject or activity
in.eg: I never knew you were in publishing.

in.eng_def: wearing
in.eg: Do you recognize that man in the grey suit?

in.eng_def: used to compare one part of an amount of something with the total amount of it
in.eg: Apparently one in ten people/one person in ten has problems with reading.

in.eng_def: used to show which characteristic or part of a person or thing is being described
in.eg: The new version is worse in every respect - I much preferred the original.

in.eng_def: used to show when doing one thing is the cause of another thing happening
in.eg: In refusing (= because she refused) to work abroad, she missed an excellent job opportunity.

in.eng_def: because
in.eg: This research is important in that it confirms the link between aggression and alcohol.

in.eng_def: from outside, or towards the centre
in.eg: Could you bring the clothes in for me?

in.eng_def: to often be staying in and receiving treatment in a particular place
in.eg: She's been in and out of hospitals ever since the accident.

in.eng_def: at home or at work
in.eg: When did you get home? I never heard you come in.

in.eng_def: within an object, area, or substance
in.chi_def: 在（某個物體、地區或物質）裡面
in.eg: We've been shut in all day.

in.eng_def: having arrived at the place where people can get on or off
in.eg: What time is Roz's flight due in?

in.eng_def: given or sent to someone official in order to be read
in.eg: When does your essay have to be in?

in.eng_def: towards the coast, beach, or harbour
in.chi_def: 接近，抵達（海岸、沙灘或港口）
in.eg: The tide comes in very quickly here and you can soon find yourself stranded.

in.eng_def: used to refer to an activity that makes something complete
in.eg: Just pencil in the answer unless you're sure it's correct.

in.eng_def: If the ball is in during a game of tennis or a similar sport, it has not gone outside the edges of the area on which the game is played.
in.eg: I won that point, I'm telling you! The ball was definitely in!

in.eng_def: taking your turn to play, especially taking your turn to hit the ball
in.eg: Who's in next for our team?

in.eng_def: fashionable or popular
in.eg: High heels are in this season.

in.eng_def: written abbreviation for  inch
used to add the meaning "not", "lacking", or "the opposite of" to adjectives and to words formed from adjectives
in.chi_def: （加在形容詞及由形容詞轉化而來的詞前）不，無，非
in.eg: incomplete/incompletely

in.eng_def: abbreviation for intranasal: through the nose
in.eg: IN drug delivery offers advantages such as ease of administration and rapid onset of action.

in.eng_def: written abbreviation for the US state of Indiana: used in addresses
in.chi_def: （美國）印第安那州，印第安拿州（寫地址時Indiana的縮寫）

in.eng_def: used to form a noun which describes an activity in which many people take part
in.chi_def: （構成名詞，描述某種很多人參加的活動）
in.eg: a sit-in/phone-in

incense.eng_def: a substance that is burnt to produce a sweet smell, especially as part of a religious ceremony
incense.chi_def: （尤指在宗教儀式上焚燒的）香

incense.eng_def: to cause someone to be extremely angry
incense.eg: The editor said a lot of readers would be incensed by my article on class.
The villagers are incensed at the decision to close the railway station.

incentive.eng_def: something that encourages a person to do something
incentive.eg: Tax incentives have been very effective in encouraging people to save and invest more of their income.

inch.eng_def: a unit used for measuring length, approximately equal to 2.54 centimetres, sometimes shown by the symbol ″
inch.chi_def: 英寸（約合2.54厘米，有時用符號''表示）
inch.eg: Twelve inches are equal to one foot.

inch.eng_def: to move very slowly or in a lot of short stages
inch.eg: We are inching towards an agreement.

incident.eng_def: an event that is either unpleasant or unusual
with nothing unpleasant or unusual happening
incident.eg: Despite fears of violence, the demonstration passed off without incident.

incident.eng_def: touching or hitting the surface of something

incidental.eng_def: less important than the thing something is connected with or part of
incidental.eg: Try not to be distracted by incidental details.

incline.eng_def: to (make someone) feel something or want to do something
incline.eg: The prime minister is believed to be inclining towards an April election.

incline.eng_def: to (cause to) slope at a particular angle
incline.eg: The ground inclined steeply towards the ridge in the distance.

incline.eng_def: to bend your head slightly forward and down
incline.eg: He inclined his head and said nothing.

include.eng_def: to contain something as a part of something else, or to make something part of something else
include.eg: The bill includes tax and service.

including.eng_def: used for saying that a person or thing is part of a particular group or amount
including.eg: Eight people, including two children, were injured in the explosion.

inclusive.eng_def: An inclusive price or amount includes everything.
inclusive.eg: My rent is $700 a month inclusive (of bills).

inclusive.eng_def: including the first and last date or number stated
inclusive.chi_def: 包括首尾兩天（或兩個數字）的
inclusive.eg: I'll be away from 20 to 31 May inclusive.

inclusive.eng_def: An inclusive group or organization tries to include many different types of people and treat them all fairly and equally.
inclusive.chi_def: （團體或組織）可以包容各種人的
inclusive.eg: Our aim is to create a fairer, more inclusive society.

income.eng_def: money that is earned from doing work or received from investments
income.eg: Average incomes have risen by 4.5 percent over the past year.

income.eng_def: a company's profit in a particular period of time
income.eg: The company's income has greatly improved: profit rose more than 50 percent last year.

increase.eng_def: to (make something) become larger in amount or size
increase.eg: Incidents of armed robbery have increased over the last few years.

increase.eng_def: a rise in the amount or size of something

increase.eg: Homelessness is on the increase in many cities.

increasingly.chi_def: 越來越多地，不斷增加地

indeed.eng_def: really or certainly, often used to emphasize something
indeed.eg: Indeed, it could be the worst environmental disaster in Europe this century.

indeed.eng_def: used to express that something is correct
indeed.eg: "Is this your dog?" "It is indeed."/"Indeed it is."

indeed.eng_def: used to add some extra information that develops or supports something you have just said
indeed.eg: For such creatures, speed is not important - indeed it is counterproductive.

indeed.eng_def: used to express surprise, anger, or lack of belief or interest
indeed.chi_def: （表示驚訝、惱怒、不相信、不感興趣）
indeed.eg: "She said she won't come back until Monday." "Won't she, indeed?"

independence.eng_def: freedom from being governed or ruled by another country
independence.eg: Mexico gained its independence from Spain in 1821.

independence.eng_def: the ability to live your life without being helped or influenced by other people
independence.eg: It's important that parents should allow their children some independence.

independent.eng_def: not influenced or controlled in any way by other people, events, or things
An independent politician does not agree or vote with any particular political party.
An independent country is not governed or ruled by another country.
independent.eg: Belize became fully independent from Britain in 1981.

independent.eng_def: not taking help or money from other people
independent.eg: Grandma's very independent and does all her own shopping and cooking.

independent.eng_def: An independent grammatical clause forms part of a sentence but can also form a separate sentence.
a politician who does not represent a political party
independent.chi_def: （不代表任何黨派的）獨立政客
independent.eg: He left the Conservatives and stood as an independent.

independent.eng_def: a voter who does not belong to a political party
independent.chi_def: 不屬於任何黨派的投票人
independent.eg: She is gaining support among independents who have no political preference or who lean Democratic.

independent.eng_def: a shop, small business, etc. that is not part of a large company
independent.chi_def: （不屬於大企業的）獨立經營店鋪，獨立小企業
independent.eg: The band would rather sign to an independent than a major record label.

index.eng_def: an alphabetical list, such as one printed at the back of a book showing which page a subject, name, etc. is on
index.chi_def: （書後關於主題、姓名等的）索引
index.eg: Try looking up "heart disease" in the index.

index.eng_def: a collection of information stored on a computer or on a set of cards, in alphabetical order
index.eg: He still has all his friends' names and addresses on a card index.

index.eng_def: a system of numbers used for comparing values of things that change according to each other or a fixed standard
something that shows how strong or common a condition or feeling is
index.eg: Consumer spending is often a good index of public confidence in the economy.

index.eng_def: to prepare an index for a book or collection, or arrange it in an index
index.eg: Our computer indexes several thousand new records every second.

index.eng_def: to change a system of numbers according to each other or a fixed standard
index.eg: Living expenses will be indexed to/in line with inflation (= to take inflation into consideration).

indicate.eng_def: to show, point, or make clear in another way
indicate.eg: Exploratory investigations have indicated large amounts of oil below the sea bed.

indicate.eng_def: to show other road users that you intend to turn left or right when you are driving a vehicle
indicate.chi_def: 打方向燈指示（車行方向）

indicate.eng_def: When a device indicates a value or change, it signals it.
indicate.eg: The gauge indicates a temperature below freezing.

indicate.eng_def: to suggest something as being suitable
indicate.eg: Antihistamine is indicated for this patient as a treatment for her allergies.

indication.eng_def: a sign that something exists, is true, or is likely to happen
indication.eg: There are few indications (that) the economy is on an upswing.

indication.eng_def: a suitable action that is suggested by something
indication.eg: The indication from the trade figures is to reduce stock by at least 30 percent.

indifference.eng_def: lack of interest in someone or something
indifference.chi_def: 不感興趣；漠不關心，冷淡
indifference.eg: Many native speakers of a language show indifference to/towards grammatical points.

indifferent.eng_def: not thinking about or interested in someone or something
indifferent.chi_def: 不感興趣的；不關心的，冷淡的
indifferent.eg: Why don't you vote - how can you be so indifferent (to what is going on)?

indifferent.eng_def: not good, but not very bad
indifferent.eg: We didn't like the restaurant much - the food was indifferent and the service rather slow.

indignant.eng_def: angry because of something that is wrong or not fair
indignant.eg: She wrote an indignant letter to the paper complaining about the council's action.
